questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the embryology of sexual differentiation are true? 

 

  1. The gonadal ridge arises from intermediate mesoderm along the medial aspect of the mesonephros.
  2. Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) secreted by Sertoli cells causes regression of paramesonephric ducts, while Leydig cell–derived testosterone stabilizes mesonephric ducts.
  3. The urogenital sinus gives rise to the lower 1/3 of the vagina, whereas the upper 2/3 develops from the mesonephric ducts.
  4. In the absence of SRY gene expression, the indifferent gonad develops into an ovary by the 6th week of gestation.
  5. 5α-reductase deficiency leads to failure of conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), resulting in undervirilized external genitalia despite normal Wolffian derivatives.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4 and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1. The gonadal ridge arises from intermediate mesoderm along the medial aspect of the mesonephros: True. The indifferent gonad develops from the gonadal ridge, derived from intermediate mesoderm, adjacent to the mesonephros.

 

Statement 2. Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) secreted by Sertoli cells causes regression of paramesonephric ducts, while Leydig cell–derived testosterone stabilizes mesonephric ducts: True. AMH prevents Müllerian structures (uterus, fallopian tubes) from developing in males, while testosterone preserves Wolffian derivatives (epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles).

 

Statement 4. In the absence of SRY gene expression, the indifferent gonad develops into an ovary by the 6th week of gestation: True. Without SRY (and thus without testis-determining factor), gonads differentiate into ovaries.

 

Statement 5. 5α-reductase deficiency leads to failure of conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), resulting in undervirilized external genitalia despite normal Wolffian derivatives: True. Wolffian (mesonephric) ducts still develop under testosterone, but external genitalia remain ambiguous due to absent DHT action.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. The urogenital sinus gives rise to the lower 1/3 of the vagina, whereas the upper 2/3 develops from the mesonephric ducts: False. The upper 2/3 of the vagina is derived from the paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts, not from mesonephric ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sexual differentiation, AMH from Sertoli cells suppresses paramesonephric ducts, testosterone from Leydig cells maintains mesonephric ducts, the upper 2/3 of the vagina derives from paramesonephric ducts, and 5α-reductase is required for external genitalia masculinization.

questions.text:
A study evaluates a new rapid test for detecting tuberculosis (TB). The results are shown below:

 

 

Based on this data, which of the following statements is true?

1. Sensitivity = 75% and Specificity = 70%
2. Sensitivity = 90% and Specificity = 70%
3. PPV = 75% and NPV = 87.5%
4. PPV = 70% and NPV = 80%
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

Statement 2. Sensitivity = 90% and Specificity = 70%: True.

  • Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) = 180 / (180 + 20) = 90%
  • Specificity = TN / (TN + FP) = 140 / (140 + 60) = 70%

 

Statement 3. PPV = 75% and NPV = 87.5%: True.

  • PPV = TP / (TP + FP) = 180 / (180 + 60) = 180/240 = 75%
  • NPV = TN / (TN + FN) = 140 / (140 + 20) = 140/160 = 87.5%

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect: True negatives. 
  • Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect: True positives
  • ‘Usefulness of a screening test’ is given by: Sensitivity
  • Statistical index of diagnostic accuracy: Sensitivity
  • Out of those shown positive by a screening test in a population, those who actually have the disease, this is: PPV of a screening test
  • Out of those shown negative by a screening test in a population, those who actually do not have the disease.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl presents with a rash over her legs and buttocks for four
days, along with pain and swelling in her knees and ankles and dark-colored urine. Her blood pressure is 129/87 mmHg. On examination, there is a palpable purpuric rash over the lower limbs and buttocks and tender swollen joints in the knees and ankles. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Henoch–Schönlein purpura
 

  • This presentation is characteristic of Henoch–Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, a small-vessel vasculitis caused by IgA immune complex deposition.
     

 

Classic tetrad of HSP:
 

  • Palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), typically on the buttocks
    and lower limbs
  • Arthritis/arthralgia of knees and ankles
  • Abdominal pain (sometimes with GI bleeding or intussusception)
  • Renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria, mild hypertension due to IgA nephropathy-like lesions)
     

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Triggered by a preceding upper respiratory tract infection
  • Deposition of IgA immune complexes in skin, kidneys, joints, and GI tract causes inflammation and vasculitis.
     

Other Options:
 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: Drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction
with fever, rash, eosinophilia, and eosinophiluria; does not cause palpable
purpura or arthritis.

 

Option B. Acute tubular necrosis: Results from ischemia or toxins; presents
with oliguria and muddy brown casts, not skin or joint findings.
Option D. IgA nephropathy: Causes isolated hematuria following infection but lacks rash and joint symptoms.
 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Henoch–Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis) is a systemic small-vessel
    vasculitis predominantly affecting children, characterized by palpable
    purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and hematuria.
  • Most cases are self-limiting, but renal involvement requires close
    monitoring and, if severe, may warrant corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child is undergoing surgical repair of umbilical hernia under general anesthesia. Identify the procedure performed in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caudal Anaesthesia

 

  • Caudal anesthesiais a common regional anesthetic technique used in children (<8 yrs of age) for surgeries below the umbilicus. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle through the sacral hiatus to access the epidural space at the caudal end of the spinal column. 
  • This matches the procedure depicted in the image, where the landmarks of the sacral cornua are used to guide needle insertion.
  • The above image shows a caudal block which is a type of central neuraxial block, most commonly used in pediatrics to provide analgesia for surgeries up to the umbilicus. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spinal anesthesia: Involves the injection of anesthetic into the subarachnoid space and is typically performed at higher levels of the spine, not at the sacral hiatus. Spinal anesthesia is not commonly used in infants due to the risks associated with administering a spinal block at such a young age.

 

Option C. Epidural anesthesia: Similar to caudal anesthesia, Epidural anesthesia technique involves the injection of anesthetic into the epidural space, but it is usually performed at higher vertebral levels. While the caudal block is a type of epidural anesthesia, the term "epidural anesthesia" alone usually refers to lumbar or thoracic epidural injections.

 

Option D. Saddle anesthesia: Is a specific type of spinal anesthesia that affects only the lower extremities and perineal area, resembling the area where a saddle would be. This type of block is not depicted in the image, as it would not be performed in the sacral area for an umbilical hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Caudal anesthesia is a form of regional anesthesia used primarily in the pediatric population for procedures below the umbilicus, utilizing the sacral hiatus as the entry point for the anesthetic. 
  • It is commonly used due to its safety and effectiveness for sub-umbilical surgical procedures in children.

choices.text: 37.5% of MIs in sedentary individuals are due to lack of exercise
Sedentary lifestyle increases MI risk by 1.6-fold
62.5% of MIs in active individuals can be attributed to exercise
37.5% of MIs in the general population are due to sedentary lifestyle

questions.text: A cohort study evaluates the effect of physical activity on cardiovascular outcomes. The incidence of myocardial infarction is 80 per 10,000 in sedentary individuals and 50 per 10,000 in active individuals. Which of the following best represents the attributable risk percent (AR%) of a sedentary lifestyle on myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 37.5% of MIs in sedentary individuals are due to lack of exercise

 

  • Attributable Risk Percent (AR%) measures the proportion of disease among the exposed group that is due to the exposure.

 

 

  • Thus, 37.5% of myocardial infarctions among sedentary individuals are attributable to lack of exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedentary lifestyle increases MI risk by 1.6-fold: This describes Relative Risk (RR = 80/50 = 1.6), not AR%.

 

Option C. 62.5% of MIs in active individuals can be attributed to exercise: AR% applies to the exposed group (sedentary), not the unexposed.

 

Option D. 37.5% of MIs in the general population are due to sedentary lifestyle: This refers to Population Attributable Risk (PAR%), which requires data on exposure prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Attributable Risk Percent (AR%) quantifies the proportion of disease among exposed individuals that can be attributed to the exposure. 
  • It differs from Relative Risk (RR), which measures strength of association, and from Population Attributable Risk (PAR%), which accounts for exposure prevalence in the whole population.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with schizophrenia presents for follow-up. She has shown partial improvement on olanzapine but has gained 8 kg over the past 4 months. Her BMI is now 31 kg/m². She is concerned about weight gain and requests a change in medication. Which of the following antipsychotics is most appropriate for this patient, considering her obesity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aripiprazole

 

  • This 29-year-old woman with schizophrenia is experiencing significant weight gain on olanzapine, which is known for its high risk of metabolic side effects such as increased appetite, weight gain, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance. 
  • Her BMI is now in the obese range (31 kg/m²), and she is appropriately concerned.
  • Among antipsychotics, aripiprazole is associated with the lowest risk of weight gain and metabolic complications, making it the most appropriate alternative in this case. 
  • It is a partial dopamine D2 agonist, with lesser antagonism at histamine and muscarinic receptors, which explains its favorable metabolic profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quetiapine: Quetiapine is associated with moderate weight gain and sedation. It is not a suitable switch in someone already gaining weight on olanzapine.


Option B. Clozapine: Clozapine has the highest risk of weight gain and metabolic syndrome among all antipsychotics. It is reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is not appropriate here, given her partial response to olanzapine and concerns about weight.


Option D. Risperidone: Risperidone causes less weight gain than olanzapine or clozapine, but more than aripiprazole. It may also cause hyperprolactinemia, which can lead to menstrual irregularities or galactorrhea, especially in young women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aripiprazole and ziprasidone are two antipsychotics with a relatively lower risk of weight gain compared to others. 
  • Olanzapine and clozapine are most associated with weight gain.

questions.text: A woman undergoing fertility evaluation is found to have normal ovulation and tubal patency. Endometrial biopsy shows the presence of pinopods. The development of these structures is dependent on which hormone?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Progesterone

 

  • Pinopods are small, finger-like epithelial projections that appear on the apical surface of endometrial cells during the window of implantation.
  • Their development is primarily under the influence of progesterone, which transforms the estrogen-primed endometrium into a secretory state.
  • Progesterone increases glandular secretion, vascularity, and stromal decidualization, all of which are necessary for implantation and maintenance of early pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estradiol: While estradiol plays a critical role in proliferation of the endometrium and upregulation of progesterone receptors, it does not directly induce pinopod formation.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Has immunomodulatory functions and supports implantation indirectly but is not the primary driver of pinopod formation.

 

Option D. Estriol: This weak estrogen is produced in significant amounts during pregnancy from the placenta and fetal adrenal precursors but is not involved in the initiation of pinopod development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone is the key hormone responsible for the formation of endometrial pinopods, which are essential for embryo implantation during the window of receptivity.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with a 12-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for routine follow-up. He reports mild exertional dyspnea but no orthopnea or chest pain. His current medications include metformin and glimepiride. Laboratory investigations reveal: HbA1c: 7.8%, Serum creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL, eGFR: 42 mL/min/1.73 m², Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio: 520 mg/g. Echocardiography shows mild left ventricular diastolic dysfunction (EF 55%). Which of the following medications are most recommended to reduce the risk of heart failure hospitalization in this patient?

 

1. Dapagliflozin 

2. Pioglitazone 

3. Ivabradine 

4. Finrenone
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

2. Pioglitazone: Causes fluid retention → increases HF risk, especially in CKD or existing LV dysfunction.

 

3. Ivabradine: Used in HFrEF with sinus rhythm and HR ≥70 bpm, not for CKD-related HF prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In T2DM with CKD and albuminuria, SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) and non-steroidal MRAs (finerenone) are the most effective agents for reducing heart failure hospitalization and slowing renal disease progression, as demonstrated in major outcome trials.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the OPD with a sudden onset of excruciating pain, swelling, and redness in his right great toe that began overnight. He has a history of obesity and admits to having consumed a significant amount of alcohol and red meat at a party the previous day. Aspiration of the joint reveals negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals within leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gout

 

The triad of: 

 

  • Acute onset, monoarticular arthritis (Podagra) in a high-risk patient (male, older, obesity, CKD, recent high-purine load/alcohol), 
  • Predilection for the first MTP joint, and 
  • The presence of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals (monosodium urate) on joint aspiration is pathognomonic for gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudogout:

 

  • This is the primary crystal-induced differential. 
  • Clinically, it often affects larger joints like the knee or wrist.
  • Microscopically, the crystals are calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD), which are characteristically positively birefringent and rhomboid shaped.

 

Option B. Septic Arthritis:

 

  • While septic arthritis presents with acute, hot, swollen joints, it is often associated with fever and systemic illness. 
  • Critically, joint aspiration in septic arthritis would show leukocytosis with a positive bacterial culture, not crystals. 
  • The patient's presentation with crystal analysis makes a primary septic joint highly unlikely, though it can co-exist.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

  • RA is a chronic, systemic inflammatory arthritis that typically presents as symmetric polyarthritis affecting the small joints of the hands and feet over weeks to months, not a sudden, monoarticular flare. 
  • X-rays would eventually show marginal erosions and joint space narrowing, but the acute monoarticular onset is inconsistent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic clinical and microscopic triad of acute gouty arthritis and to distinguish it from its primary differential diagnoses based on patient factors, symptom onset, and crystal analysis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy is scheduled for chemotherapy with a known cardiotoxic agent. Echocardiography reveals poor acoustic windows. Which of the following is the most accurate and reproducible method to monitor his left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) during therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MUGA scan using 99mTc-labeled RBCs

 

  • The MUGA scan (Multiple Gated Acquisition scan), also known as equilibrium radionuclide angiography, is the most accurate and reproducible non-invasive technique for measuring left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), especially in patients with poor echocardiographic windows.
  • It uses 99mTc-labeled red blood cells to trace blood pool activity in the heart chambers.
  • It allows beat averaging and high temporal resolution, producing consistent and quantifiable data on cardiac function.
  • Especially favored in oncology settings, it is widely used to monitor patients receiving cardiotoxic chemotherapy (e.g., doxorubicin).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First-pass radionuclide ventriculography: Although useful, it provides limited temporal resolution and image quality because it captures only a few cardiac cycles. Less reproducible compared to equilibrium MUGA.

 

Option B. Transesophageal echocardiography: Provides better anatomical detail than transthoracic echo but is semi-invasive, uncomfortable, and not typically used solely for ejection fraction measurement.

 

Option D. Cardiac CT angiography: Offers detailed anatomical imaging of coronary arteries but is not optimized for LVEF measurement and involves higher radiation exposure and iodinated contrast, which is not ideal for repeated monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MUGA scans are the gold standard for reliable and reproducible measurement of LVEF, especially in patients with poor acoustic windows or those undergoing chemotherapy requiring cardiotoxicity monitoring.

choices.text: These drugs inhibit glucose reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule and commonly cause hypoglycemia and weight gain.
These drugs inhibit SGLT2 transporters in the proximal tubule, promote glycosuria, cause mild osmotic diuresis, and reduce cardiovascular and renal events even in non-diabetic patients.
These drugs act by increasing insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells and are contraindicated in heart failure due to fluid retention.
These drugs block intestinal glucose absorption and are useful for rapid correction of severe hyperglycemia in diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus, ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 35%), and chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m²) is evaluated for optimization of therapy. He is currently on metformin, enalapril, and a β-blocker. His HbA1c is 7.5%, and fasting glucose is 140 mg/dL. The physician decides to start a drug that provides glycemic control, cardio-renal protection, and reduces heart failure hospitalizations. After 2 weeks, the patient reports increased urination, mild genital itching, and a drop in systolic BP by 8 mmHg. Which of the following statements regarding the newly added drug class is most correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) These drugs inhibit SGLT2 transporters in the proximal tubule, promote glycosuria, cause mild osmotic diuresis, and reduce cardiovascular and renal events even in non-diabetic patients

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin, Canagliflozin, Ertugliflozin)
  • Inhibit Sodium–Glucose Co-Transporter 2 in the proximal convoluted tubule, ↓ glucose reabsorption → ↑ urinary glucose loss.
  • Leads to lower plasma glucose, osmotic diuresis, and natriuresis.

 

Metabolic & Non-diabetic Benefits:

 

 

Adverse effects:

 

  • Genital mycotic infections (Candida vulvovaginitis, balanitis)
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Polyuria, hypotension (volume loss)
  • Euglycemic ketoacidosis (rare but important)
  • Canagliflozin: ↑ risk of lower limb amputation and bone fractures

 

Contraindications:

 

  • eGFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m² (ineffective)
  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus (↑ risk of ketoacidosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. These drugs inhibit glucose reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule and commonly cause hypoglycemia and weight gain: Incorrect. Glucose reabsorption occurs mainly in the proximal tubule, not the distal convoluted tubule. SGLT2 inhibitors cause weight loss, not weight gain, and rarely cause hypoglycemia because their action is insulin-independent.

 

Option C. These drugs act by increasing insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells and are contraindicated in heart failure due to fluid retention: Incorrect. This describes sulfonylureas or meglitinides, which increase insulin secretion. These agents may cause weight gain, hypoglycemia, and are contraindicated in heart failure due to the risk of fluid retention.

 

Option D. These drugs block intestinal glucose absorption and are useful for rapid correction of severe hyperglycemia in diabetic ketoacidosis: Incorrect. This describes α-glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose, miglitol), which delay intestinal carbohydrate absorption. They are not used for rapid correction of hyperglycemia or in diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SGLT2 inhibitors block glucose and sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, producing glycosuria and osmotic diuresis. 
  • They improve glycemic control while providing significant cardiovascular and renal protection, even in non-diabetic patients.

choices.text: Aspirin is present in mainly non-ionised form in stomach, hence can be easily absorbed
Diazepam is mostly absorbed from intestine
Phenobarbitone can be absorbed from the stomach but most of the absorption occurs in small intestine due to its large surface area
Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhea will increase the drug absorption in the intestine

questions.text: Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs whereas diazepam is a basic drug. All of the following statements are correct about these drugs except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhea will increase the drug absorption in the intestine

 

  • In similar medium, the drugs are in non-ionized (and hence lipid soluble) form. It means acidic drugs are lipid soluble in acidic medium and basic drugs are lipid soluble in basic medium.
  • pH of the stomach is acidic and that of intestine is basic.
  • Therefore, acidic drugs like aspirin are non-ionized and thus easily absorbed from stomach and basic drugs like diazepam are mostly absorbed from intestine.
  • But most of the drugs (even acidic drugs like phenobarbitone and aspirin) are absorbed more from intestine because:
    • It has large surface area.
    • The drug stays in the intestine for long period (transit time)
  • However, in conditions like diarrhea, when transit time in intestine decreases, the absorption of drugs may decrease because they get less time to be absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin is present in mainly non-ionised form in stomach, hence can be easily absorbed: Correct. Aspirin is a weak acid that remains non-ionized in the stomach and can be absorbed there.

 

Option B. Diazepam is mostly absorbed from intestine: Correct. Diazepam, a weak base, is non-ionized in the alkaline intestine and absorbed efficiently from there.

 

Option C. Phenobarbitone can be absorbed from the stomach but most of the absorption occurs in small intestine due to its large surface area: Correct. Phenobarbital can be absorbed in the stomach, but most absorption occurs in the small intestine due to its large surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Weak acids are better absorbed in acidic environments, and weak bases in basic environments. 
  • Most absorption occurs in the small intestine due to large surface area.
  • Conditions like diarrhea decrease transit time and thus reduce intestinal drug absorption.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for lymphoma develops meningitis. His cerebrospinal fluid shows Gram-positive rods with tumbling motility. Which of the following features best helps to differentiate this pathogen from Corynebacterium diphtheriae in the lab?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Growth at cold temperatures

 

  • While both Listeria monocytogenes and Corynebacterium diphtheriae are Gram-positive rods, Listeria uniquely exhibits cold enhancement and can grow at low temperatures (e.g., 4°C). 
  • This trait helps isolate the organism in the lab, particularly when bacterial numbers are low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positivity: Incorrect. Both organisms are catalase-positive.

 

Option B. Growth on blood agar: Incorrect. Both can grow on blood agar.

 

Option C. Gram staining: Incorrect as both are Gram-positive rods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes demonstrates cold enrichment—growth in refrigerated cultures like thioglycollate broth at 4°C.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4P3 woman at 36 weeks gestation suddenly develops severe abdominal pain followed by vaginal bleeding and loss of fetal movements. She has a history of prior lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). On examination, the uterus is tender, and fetal parts are easily palpable. No fetal heart sounds are detected. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine rupture

 

  • This patient is a 30-year-old multiparous woman (G4P3) at 36 weeks gestation with a history of prior LSCS (lower segment cesarean section). She presents with sudden severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and cessation of fetal movements.
  • On examination, the uterus is tender, and fetal parts are easily palpable, which strongly suggests loss of uterine integrity. 
  • The absence of fetal heart sounds indicates intrauterine fetal demise, a common outcome of catastrophic rupture.
  • The key clue is the history of prior LSCS, which predisposes to uterine rupture due to weakening of the myometrial scar. 
  • The clinical triad of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and abnormal palpability of fetal parts with absent fetal heart sounds is classic for uterine rupture.
  • Thus, the most likely diagnosis is uterine rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the third trimester. In this case, the patient had sudden severe abdominal pain, which is not consistent with placenta previa. Furthermore, fetal parts easily palpable and uterine tenderness are not typical findings in placenta previa.

 

Option C. Vasa previa: Vasa previa is characterized by painless vaginal bleeding at membrane rupture with fetal distress or demise. However, this condition is not associated with a tender uterus or palpable fetal parts, and it is not linked to a history of prior LSCS. The presentation here is inconsistent with vasa previa.

 

Option D. Abruptio placentae: Abruptio placentae usually causes painful vaginal bleeding with a tense, rigid uterus and ongoing fetal distress. However, in this case, the description of easily palpable fetal parts and a history of prior LSCS points more toward uterine rupture rather than abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with a history of prior cesarean section, the triad of sudden severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and easily palpable fetal parts with absent fetal heart sounds at 36 weeks gestation is most consistent with uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is evaluated for poor weight gain over the past year. She has a history of chronic nonproductive cough, repeated antibiotic use, and diarrhea with foul-smelling stools. She is diagnosed with cystic fibrosis. Based on her clinical presentation, she is most likely deficient in which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Cystic fibrosis leads to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency due to plugging and destruction of pancreatic ducts. 
  • This results in fat malabsorption because pancreatic enzymes and bile salts are required to digest and absorb dietary lipids.
  • Poor fat absorption particularly affects the fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K).
  • Among these, Vitamin K deficiency is especially common and clinically important because it causes impaired activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, leading to bleeding tendencies.
  • The child’s symptoms of poor weight gain and foul-smelling stools (steatorrhea) are classic indicators of fat malabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B7: Incorrect. Vitamin B7 (Biotin) deficiency is rare, usually caused by raw egg white ingestion or chronic antibiotic use. It does not explain fat malabsorption in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Incorrect. Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy (bleeding gums, petechiae, poor wound healing). It is water-soluble and not dependent on fat absorption.

 

Option D. Vitamin B9: Incorrect. Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) deficiency is linked to megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects. Like vitamin C, it is water-soluble and unaffected by fat malabsorption.


Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis causes fat malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, leading to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). Vitamin K deficiency is especially important because it results in coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man undergoes colonoscopy during routine screening. A polyp is identified and removed. Histologic examination of the polyp is shown below. Which of the following best describes this type of polyp?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubulo-villous adenoma

 

  • This 62-year-old man underwent colonoscopy as part of routine screening. A polyp was discovered and examined histologically. 
  • The biopsy revealed both tubular glandular elements and villous (finger-like) projections with dysplastic epithelium, which is the defining feature of a tubulo-villous adenoma.
  • A tubulo-villous adenoma represents an intermediate form between tubular adenomas and villous adenomas. 
  • These lesions carry an intermediate malignant potential — higher than that of a tubular adenoma but lower than that of a pure villous adenoma.
  • Recognition is important because these adenomas, like all adenomatous polyps, can progress through the adenoma–carcinoma sequence to invasive colorectal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are composed almost entirely of elongated, finger-like villous projections and have the highest malignant potential (“villous is villainous”). However, in this case, the histology specifically described a mixture of tubular and villous patterns, not purely villous.

 

Option B. Hyperplastic polyp: A hyperplastic polyp shows a serrated (saw-tooth) architecture with no dysplasia. It is benign with no malignant potential. The finding of dysplasia and mixed tubular/villous growth rules this out.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are the most common adenomatous polyps and show rounded tubular glandular architecture. They have malignant potential, but less than villous or tubulo-villous types. The presence of both tubular and villous elements makes this diagnosis incomplete here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tubulo-villous adenoma is a colonic polyp with both tubular and villous architectural elements, carrying an intermediate malignant potential between tubular adenoma and villous adenoma.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents after a fall at home. She reports several similar falls over the past six months and notes increasing stiffness and slowness of movement. Examination reveals a bilateral tremor, symmetrical bradykinesia, rigidity, shuffling gait, and a masked facies, but normal strength and reflexes. She has been taking cinnarizine for the past five years for dizziness, which has since resolved. There is no cognitive impairment or orthostatic hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drug-induced Parkinsonism

 

  • This patient presents with symmetrical Parkinsonian features (bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor) and a history of prolonged cinnarizine use—a calcium channel blocker with dopamine receptor–blocking properties.
  • These features point to drug-induced Parkinsonism, a common reversible cause of secondary Parkinsonism.

 

Key differentiating features:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebrovascular disease: Would present with focal neurological deficits or stepwise decline, not symmetrical Parkinsonism without other signs.

 

Option C. Essential tremor: Causes bilateral action tremor without bradykinesia, rigidity, or gait disturbance.

 

Option D. Idiopathic Parkinson’s disease: Typically asymmetric, with rest tremor and progressive course; no history of offending medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug-induced Parkinsonism should be suspected in elderly patients—especially women—with symmetrical Parkinsonian symptoms and exposure to dopamine-blocking drugs (e.g., cinnarizine, metoclopramide, antipsychotics). 
  • Discontinuation of the offending agent usually leads to improvement.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old plumber with ulcerative colitis presents with severe rectal bleeding. He reports bowel movements over 20 times a day, including at least five times at night, passing only blood and mucus. He also complains of generalized abdominal pain.

On examination, he looks unwell.

Vital Signs:

 

 

His abdomen is markedly tender in the left iliac fossa but soft.

Blood Tests:

 

 

Which of the following is the most urgent initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal X-ray

 

  • This patient has fulminant (severe) ulcerative colitis. The major concern is toxic dilatation of the colon, which can be quickly and reliably assessed with an abdominal X-ray.
  • While these patients may also require an abdominal CT later, an X-ray is the most urgent first-line investigation.
  • Stool microscopy, culture, and sensitivity should be sent, but results take time.
  • Urgent flexible sigmoidoscopy is not essential during initial assessment, as the diagnosis is already known.
  • Faecal calprotectin is not helpful in this acute scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal CT: Useful for assessing complications but not the first urgent step; X-ray should precede it to rule out toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Faecal Calprotectin: Marker of chronic mucosal inflammation; not helpful in acute severe colitis.

 

Option D. Stool Microscopy, Culture and Sensitivity: Important to exclude infection but not immediately diagnostic or lifesaving in fulminant cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In acute severe ulcerative colitis, the immediate priority is to exclude toxic megacolon, a life-threatening complication.
  • Abdominal X-ray is the fastest and most accessible bedside investigation to assess colonic dilatation (>6 cm transverse colon diameter).
  • Early recognition allows prompt medical therapy (IV steroids, fluids) and surgical consultation if perforation risk is high.

questions.text: During ERCP for CBD stone, which of the following scopes is commonly used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Side viewing 

 

  • Duodenoscope, Preferred for ERCP, Allows optimal visualization and cannulation of the ampulla of Vater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forward viewing: Standard gastroscope, not ideal for ERCP. Limited visualization of ampulla; used in upper GI endoscopy.

 

Option C. Double balloon: Enteroscope, not routine for ERCP. Used in altered anatomy (e.g., post-Roux-en-Y) to reach biliary tree.

 

Option D. Backward viewing: Rare terminology, not applicable. Not a recognized scope type in ERCP practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ERCP requires precise access to the major duodenal papilla, which lies on the medial wall of the second part of the duodenum.
  • Side-viewing duodenoscopes provide the best angle for cannulation of the common bile duct (CBD) and pancreatic duct.

choices.text: External beam pelvic radiotherapy with brachytherapy boost
High-dose progestin therapy with strict follow-up biopsies every 3–6 months
Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with lymphadenectomy
Hysteroscopic resection of endometrium followed by LNG-IUS insertion

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with irregular heavy menstrual bleeding. Endometrial biopsy demonstrates atypical complex hyperplasia with focal adenocarcinoma. MRI of the pelvis shows a lesion confined to the endometrium, with no evidence of myometrial invasion and no lymphadenopathy. She does not wish to preserve fertility. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with lymphadenectomy

 

  • This 46-year-old woman has irregular heavy bleeding, and her endometrial biopsy shows atypical complex hyperplasia with a focus of adenocarcinoma.
  • Pelvic MRI confirms confinement to the endometrium with no myometrial invasion and no lymphadenopathy. Importantly, she is not interested in fertility preservation.
  • For women who do not wish to preserve fertility, the standard of care is definitive surgery:
    • Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) and lymphadenectomy.
    • Lymphadenectomy is recommended for staging, even if MRI shows no nodal disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External beam pelvic radiotherapy with brachytherapy boost: Incorrect. Radiation therapy is reserved for inoperable cases (e.g., poor surgical candidates) or more advanced disease. This patient is operable with early disease, so radiotherapy is not first-line.

 

Option B. High-dose progestin therapy with strict follow-up biopsies every 3–6 months: Incorrect. Progestin therapy is used in younger women desiring fertility preservation or in patients unfit for surgery. This patient does not want fertility preservation.

 

Option D. Hysteroscopic resection of endometrium followed by LNG-IUS insertion: Incorrect. LNG-IUS (levonorgestrel intrauterine system) may be considered in hyperplasia or very early carcinoma for women strongly desiring fertility or unfit for surgery. This patient is suitable for definitive surgical management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial carcinoma confined to the endometrium in women not desiring fertility preservation should be managed with total hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and lymphadenectomy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a fungating ulcer on the glans penis that has progressively enlarged over several months. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. Which of these is not a premalignant lesion for it?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) History of circumcision

 

Protective factor; reduces risk of penile cancer by lowering chronic irritation and HPV exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bowen’s disease: Carcinoma in situ of the penile shaft or glans; high risk of progression to invasive SCC.

 

Option B. Penile leukoplakia: White plaques with dysplastic potential; considered premalignant.

 

Option C. Balanoposthitis: Chronic inflammation may predispose to malignancy, especially in uncircumcised men.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Circumcision in infancy or early childhood is associated with a significantly lower risk of penile cancer.
  • Premalignant lesions often arise in the context of chronic inflammation, poor hygiene, HPV infection, or phimosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following correctly describe ATP synthesis and growth characteristics of these atypical bacteria?

 

  1. Mycoplasma synthesizes ATP and grows on artificial media
  2. Rickettsia synthesizes no ATP and cannot grow on artificial media
  3. Chlamydia does not synthesize ATP and cannot grow on artificial media
  4. Mycoplasma contains modified peptidoglycan in its cell wall
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. Mycoplasma synthesizes ATP and grows on artificial media: Correct. Mycoplasma species (like M. pneumoniae) are unique in that they lack a cell wall but are capable of synthesizing ATP and can grow on artificial media enriched with sterols.

 

Statement 2. Rickettsia synthesizes no ATP and cannot grow on artificial media: Correct. Rickettsia are obligate intracellular pathogens and rely on host cell machinery for energy; they are unable to synthesize their own ATP (energy parasites) and cannot be cultured on artificial media.

 

Statement 3. Chlamydia does not synthesize ATP and cannot grow on artificial media: Correct. Chlamydia also lacks the machinery for ATP synthesis and is obligate intracellular, thus it cannot grow outside host cells.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Mycoplasma contains modified peptidoglycan in its cell wall: Incorrect. Mycoplasma does not contain peptidoglycan, modified or otherwise, in its cell membrane. That is a defining characteristic and is the reason beta-lactam antibiotics are ineffective against them. Modified peptidoglycan is seen in chlamydia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chlamydia and Rickettsia are obligate intracellular organisms that cannot grow on artificial media. Mycoplasma, though atypical, is free-living, can grow on artificial media, and synthesizes its own ATP but lacks a cell wall.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Asbestos exposure increases the risk of bronchogenic carcinoma more than mesothelioma.


Reason (R): Amphibole asbestos is more fibrogenic than chrysotile asbestos.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

 

  • Assertion (A). Asbestos exposure increases the risk of bronchogenic carcinoma more than mesothelioma: True. Asbestos exposure increases risk of bronchogenic carcinoma (≈5-fold), and in smokers this risk can rise to >50-fold. Mesothelioma risk is also increased, but comparatively bronchogenic carcinoma is more common.
  • Reason (R). Amphibole asbestos is more fibrogenic than chrysotile asbestos: True. Amphibole asbestos (e.g., crocidolite, amosite) is more fibrogenic and carcinogenic than chrysotile, and has stronger links to mesothelioma.
  • However, the excess bronchogenic carcinoma risk is not explained simply by the fibrogenicity difference, but rather by the synergistic effect with smoking and general carcinogenic potential of asbestos.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asbestos exposure increases the risk of both bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma.
  • Bronchogenic carcinoma is more common, especially with concurrent smoking.
  • Amphibole asbestos is more fibrogenic and more strongly associated with mesothelioma than chrysotile, but this does not fully explain the excess of bronchogenic carcinoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with ulcerative colitis and gout presents with 2 weeks of progressive dyspnea and dry cough. He is on infliximab therapy. Past reactions include Stevens–Johnson syndrome with sulfasalazine and a hemolytic episode after starting rasburicase for gout. Vitals: RR 32/min, SpO₂ 85% on room air. ABG: PaO₂ 55 mm Hg. CXR is shown below. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pentamidine

 

  • The patient has severe Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), a recognized complication of immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., infliximab). The PaO₂ <70 mm Hg indicates severe disease.
  • First-line treatment is TMP-SMX, but it should be avoided due to his previous severe sulfa allergy (Stevens–Johnson syndrome). 
  • His hemolytic reaction to rasburicase suggests G6PD deficiency, ruling out primaquine and dapsone-based regimens. 
  • Therefore, IV pentamidine is the safest and most effective alternative for severe PCP.
  • Adjunctive systemic corticosteroids are indicated for severe PCP (e.g., PaO₂ <70 mm Hg or A–a gradient ≥35 mm Hg).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atovaquone: Used only for mild PCP; ineffective in severe disease.

 

Option B. Clindamycin and primaquine: Suitable for severe PCP, but primaquine is contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

 

Option D. TMP-SMX: First-line for PCP, but contraindicated due to sulfa-induced Stevens–Johnson syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe PCP, TMP-SMX remains the treatment of choice. However, in patients with severe sulfa allergy or G6PD deficiency, IV pentamidine is the preferred alternative.

choices.text: Perampanel inhibits AMPA receptors on the postsynaptic membrane
Gabapentin exerts its effect by directly blocking T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons
Levetiracetam inhibits vesicle fusion by binding to SV2A protein
Tiagabine enhances GABAergic transmission by inhibiting the GAT-1 transporter

questions.text: Which of the following statements about antiepileptic drug mechanisms is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin exerts its effect by directly blocking T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons

 

  • Gabapentin, although commonly misunderstood, does not block T-type calcium channels.
  • Instead, it binds to the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, modulating their activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perampanel inhibits AMPA receptors on the postsynaptic membrane: Perampanel is a selective, non-competitive antagonist of the AMPA-type glutamate receptor, which inhibits excitatory neurotransmission.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam inhibits vesicle fusion by binding to SV2A protein: Levetiracetam binds to SV2A, a synaptic vesicle protein, thereby reducing neurotransmitter release and contributing to seizure suppression.

 

Option D. Tiagabine enhances GABAergic transmission by inhibiting the GAT-1 transporter: Tiagabine inhibits GAT-1, a GABA reuptake transporter, prolonging GABA activity in the synaptic cleft, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The precise mechanisms of action of antiepileptic drugs:

 

  • Perampanel inhibits AMPA receptors (excitatory).
  • Levetiracetam binds SV2A to reduce neurotransmitter release.
  • Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake via GAT-1.
  • Gabapentin binds α2δ subunit of Ca²⁺ channels, not T-type channels.

questions.text: Match each drug classification in Column A with its corresponding definition in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1–c, 2–d, 3–e, 4–b, 5–a

 

  • 1. Adulterated Drug → (c) Contains harmful ingredients: Adulterated drugs are those that are contaminated or prepared under unsanitary conditions, contain decomposed substances, or fail to meet purity and quality standards. This can pose direct harm to patients.
  • 2. Spurious Drug → (d) Falsely claims to be from a known brand or another product: A spurious drug is fraudulent—manufactured under the name of another drug, or intentionally mislabeled to mislead consumers. These are illegal imitations of genuine products.
  • 3. Misbranded Drug → (e) Labeling is misleading or violates regulatory standards: Misbranded drugs are correctly composed in terms of content, but their packaging, labeling, or promotional claims are deceptive, incomplete, or non-compliant with regulatory norms (e.g., missing warnings).
  • 4. Orphan Drug → (b) Developed for rare diseases: Orphan drugs are intended for the treatment of rare diseases. Due to limited commercial interest, they are supported through incentives under legislations like the Orphan Drug Act (1983, USA).
  • 5. Me-too Drug → (a) Structurally similar drug to an existing one with minor modifications:  Me-too drugs are slightly modified versions of existing drugs that usually offer no major therapeutic advantage but may differ in side effect profiles or dosing schedules. They are often made for market competition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, associated with repeated episodes of bilious vomiting. Imaging reveals no significant free air under the diaphragm. Further evaluation confirms a bleeding posterior duodenal ulcer. Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery 

 

  • A posterior duodenal ulcer erodes through the posterior wall of the first part of the duodenum.
  • The posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery, a branch of the gastroduodenal artery, runs in close proximity to this region.
  • Because of this anatomical relationship, the artery is at high risk of erosion, leading to severe upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • The clinical features described — epigastric pain, bilious vomiting, tachycardia, shortness of breath, posterior duodenal ulcer — all point toward this vascular complication.
  • Therefore, the structure most commonly damaged in this clinical condition is the posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (branch of gastroduodenal artery).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right gastroepiploic artery:

 

  • The right gastroepiploic artery supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • While it is indeed a branch of the gastroduodenal artery, it is not located directly posterior to the first part of the duodenum, and therefore it is not the vessel typically eroded in a posterior duodenal ulcer.

 

Option C. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery: 

 

  • The inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery arises from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), not the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • It supplies the lower duodenum and head of the pancreas.
  • However, it is not the primary vessel involved in posterior duodenal ulcers.

 

Option D. Peritoneum around the proximal duodenum:

 

  • While ulcer perforation could involve peritoneum, the question specifies bleeding as the complication of a posterior duodenal ulcer, which implicates an arterial source rather than just peritoneal involvement.
  • Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior duodenal ulcers most commonly erode into the posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (a branch of the gastroduodenal artery), causing massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage.

choices.text: Normal pupillary size and absence of bradycardia

questions.text: Which of the following findings would most strongly suggest pyrethroid toxicity rather than organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal pupillary size and absence of bradycardia

 

  • Organophosphate compounds inhibit acetylcholinesterase, resulting in cholinergic overstimulation of both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Classic findings include:
    • Miosis (pinpoint pupils)
    • Bradycardia
    • Salivation, lacrimation
    • Fasciculations, weakness
    • Diarrhea, bronchorrhea, and respiratory distress
  • In contrast, pyrethroids (common in household insecticides like mosquito repellents) are neurotoxic agents that do not inhibit acetylcholinesterase.
  • They act by prolonging sodium channel opening, leading to:
    • Tremors, agitation, seizures (CNS excitability)
    • Normal pupils
    • No bradycardia
    • Minimal cholinergic effects
  • Thus, normal pupils and absence of bradycardia is a key distinguishing feature favoring pyrethroid toxicity over organophosphate poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Excessive salivation and fasciculations: While both toxidromes may present with fasciculations, excessive salivation is a hallmark of organophosphate toxicity, making this finding nonspecific or favoring organophosphate.

 

Option C. Acute respiratory distress and wheezing: Can occur in both poisonings. However, organophosphates more commonly cause bronchorrhea and bronchospasm due to muscarinic overstimulation. Thus, not a specific differentiator.

 

Option D. Rapid improvement after atropine administration: Atropine is effective only in organophosphate poisoning, not in pyrethroid toxicity. Lack of response to atropine would suggest pyrethroid poisoning, but response to atropine indicates muscarinic involvement (thus organophosphate), not pyrethroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyrethroid toxicity is characterized by normal pupils, lack of bradycardia, and predominantly neurotoxic symptoms like tremors or seizures, without signs of cholinergic excess. 
  • In contrast, organophosphates cause a cholinergic toxidrome with miosis, bradycardia, salivation, and respiratory distress.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy develops abdominal pain lasting for 10 days, dark-colored urine, and purplish spots on the skin. Urinalysis demonstrates hematuria and proteinuria. Testing for P-ANCA and C-ANCA autoantibodies is negative. A skin biopsy shows necrotizing inflammation of small dermal vessels, and kidney biopsy demonstrates immune complex deposition containing IgA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA vasculitis 

 

  • This 7-year-old child presents with a constellation of abdominal pain for 10 days, dark urine, and purpuric skin lesions. 
  • Laboratory evidence shows hematuria and proteinuria, indicating renal involvement. 
  • Serologic tests are negative for P-ANCA and C-ANCA, which rules out ANCA-associated vasculitides. 
  • Pathology shows necrotizing vasculitis of small dermal vessels and IgA-rich immune complex deposition in renal biopsy, which are classic for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis.
  • HSP is a small-vessel vasculitis seen in children, characterized by:
    • Palpable purpura on lower extremities
    • Abdominal pain often due to intestinal involvement
    • Renal disease with hematuria and proteinuria (IgA nephropathy-like picture)
    • Histology: necrotizing small vessel vasculitis with IgA deposition

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener granulomatosis: Also known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this involves necrotizing granulomatous inflammation of the upper and lower respiratory tract, along with renal disease. It is strongly associated with C-ANCA positivity. In this case, serology was negative for C-ANCA, and there was no mention of sinus or respiratory tract disease, making Wegener granulomatosis incorrect.

 

Option B. Giant cell arteritis: This is a large-vessel vasculitis, primarily affecting elderly patients, often women. It typically causes headache, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, and temporal artery tenderness. It does not occur in children, does not cause IgA immune complex deposition, and is unrelated to hematuria, proteinuria, or necrotizing vasculitis of dermal vessels.

 

Option D. Takayasu arteritis: Another large-vessel vasculitis, this affects young women (often of Asian descent) and involves the aortic arch and its branches, leading to diminished pulses (“pulseless disease”). It does not present with purpuric skin lesions, abdominal pain, hematuria, proteinuria, or IgA-rich immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA vasculitis (HSP) in children presents with abdominal pain, purpuric skin lesions, hematuria, proteinuria, and is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition and necrotizing small vessel vasculitis, with negative P-ANCA and C-ANCA serology.

questions.text: Based on this image, the structure most likely belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Escherichia coli

 

  • The image is characteristic of a Gram-negative bacterial cell wall, indicated by the presence of:
    • Outer membrane
    • LPS (lipopolysaccharide) with Lipid A and O-antigen
    • Thin peptidoglycan layer in the periplasmic space
    • Polysaccharide capsule (K antigen)
  • E. coli is a classic example of a Gram-negative bacillus with all these structural features:
    • Lipid A → responsible for endotoxin effects
    • O antigen → used in serotyping
    • K capsule → important for immune evasion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: A Gram-positive cocci lacks outer membrane and LPS. Its cell wall contains thick peptidoglycan and teichoic acids.

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: While also Gram-negative cocci and uses LOS (lipooligosaccharide), which lacks O antigen.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Gram-positive bacillus, and has mycolic acids and lipoarabinomannan in their structure. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gram-negative bacteria have a characteristic outer membrane containing LPS with Lipid A, O-antigen, and sometimes a K antigen capsule.
  • Escherichia coli is a prototypical organism with this complete structure.

questions.text: Which MRI finding best confirms the diagnosis of neurocysticercosis on the image provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scolex within the cyst

 

  • The scolex, visible as a bright eccentric mural nodule within a cyst on MRI (especially on T2-weighted or FLAIR images), is pathognomonic for viable neurocysticercosis. 
  • This feature confirms the presence of the larval form of Taenia solium and helps differentiate NCC from other causes of ring-enhancing or cystic brain lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perilesional edema: Seen in the colloidal stage of NCC or in inflammatory conditions but is nonspecific.

 

Option B. T2 hypointense ring: Can occur in tuberculomas or abscesses as well; lacks specificity for NCC.

 

Option D. Ring enhancement with central necrosis: Suggestive of abscesses or granulomatous infections, but not diagnostic of NCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a scolex (eccentric dot) within a cyst on MRI is the most definitive imaging feature of neurocysticercosis, particularly in the vesicular stage. 
  • This finding helps distinguish NCC from other cystic or granulomatous CNS lesions such as tuberculomas or abscesses.

questions.text: Identify the provided histological slide:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymus

 

  • The image clearly displays the lobular architecture typical of the thymus, where each lobule is separated by trabeculae - thin layers of connective tissue.
  • In this image, there are several key structural components:
    • Capsule: A dense, fibrous layer that encloses the thymus, visible at the top of the image.
    • Cortex: The darker, outer regions of the lobules where the majority of thymocytes (immature T cells) are located. The cortex appears denser due to the high density of lymphocytes.
    • Medulla: The lighter, central areas within the lobules, where thymocytes mature and where fewer lymphocytes are packed compared to the cortex.
    • Trabeculae (septa): These are extensions of the capsule that divide the thymus into lobules. They are made of connective tissue and help in structuring the organ into distinct compartments.

This structural characteristic is significant for the thymus gland, which is centrally involved in the immune system, specifically in the maturation of T-lymphocytes. Unlike other glands which may present varied structural features, the thymus' unique lobular division is key to its identification.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: Incorrect. A histological slide of the thyroid gland would display follicles lined with epithelial cells and filled with colloid, distinctly different from the trabecular and lobular structure shown in this image. The thyroid's role in hormone production is not aligned with the immune maturation depicted.

 

Option C. Spleen: Incorrect. The spleen would typically show a different histological appearance, characterized by areas of white and red pulp, which are not visible in the provided image. The spleen's structure facilitates its role in filtering blood and mounting immune responses, which differs from the lobular and trabecular structure seen in the image.

 

Option D. Tongue: Incorrect. The tongue's primary histological features include striated muscle fibers and taste buds in certain sections, none of which are present in this image. The tongue's muscular structure supports its functions in taste, speech, and food manipulation, not the immune function depicted here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus gland is characterized by its unique lobular structure divided by trabeculae, playing a vital role in the immune system through the maturation of T-lymphocytes.

choices.text: Septate hyphae with acute-angle dichotomous branching
Budding yeast with thick polysaccharide capsule
Spherules with endospores in lung tissue

questions.text: A 62-year-old man undergoing induction chemotherapy for acute leukemia develops fever and pleuritic chest pain. CT scan shows a halo sign in the right upper lobe. A bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, and the GMS stain reveals the fungal structures seen in the image. Which of the following morphological features is most consistent with this fungal pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septate hyphae with acute-angle dichotomous branching

 

  • The image and clinical scenario are classic for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, a condition that commonly occurs in immunocompromised hosts, especially those who are neutropenic or undergoing chemotherapy.
  • The GMS stain highlights narrow (3–6 μm), septate hyphae that branch at acute angles (~45°) in a dichotomous (Y-shaped) pattern. This is pathognomonic for Aspergillus species, particularly Aspergillus fumigatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Broad, non-septate hyphae with 90° branching: Seen in Mucorales (e.g., Mucor, Rhizopus), which cause mucormycosis, not Aspergillus. Pulmonary infection is less commonly seen.

 

Option C. Budding yeast with thick polysaccharide capsule: Characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, seen with India ink or mucicarmine stain, not GMS. Meningitis is seen more commonly than pulmonary infections.

 

Option D. Spherules with endospores in lung tissue: Classic for Rhinosporidium seeberi, usually seen in lung or CNS tissue, and looks completely different histologically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus species cause invasive pulmonary disease in neutropenic patients, and are identified by septate hyphae with acute-angle, dichotomous branching on GMS stain. 
  • This is distinct from Mucor, Cryptococcus, and Coccidioides, which each have unique histopathological appearances.

questions.text: Match the scientist/doctor with their achievement:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

  • 1-c. Sushruta → Father of Indian Surgery: Known for ancient surgical techniques, described in Sushruta Samhita.
  • 2-d. John Snow → Father of Epidemiology: Pioneered outbreak investigation during the London cholera epidemic.
  • 3-b. Avicenna → Author of Canon of Medicine: Also known as Ibn Sina, his works influenced medieval medicine for centuries.
  • 4-a. Samuel Hahnemann → Father of Homeopathy: Founder of homeopathy, based on the principle “like cures like.”

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sushruta → Indian Surgery
  • John Snow → Epidemiology
  • Avicenna → Canon of Medicine
  • Hahnemann → Homeopathy

choices.text: An outbreak of measles in a school
A cholera outbreak in a community with poor sanitation
A diphtheria outbreak in a vaccinated population
A pertussis outbreak in a hospital pediatric ward

questions.text: In which situation would healthy carriers pose the greatest threat to public health surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A cholera outbreak in a community with poor sanitation

 

  • Healthy carriers are individuals who never develop overt symptoms but still shed pathogens.
  • In cholera, healthy carriers can excrete large numbers of Vibrio cholerae into the environment.
  • In areas with poor sanitation, this leads to contamination of community water sources and rapid epidemic spread, while escaping detection by standard surveillance systems (which focus on symptomatic cases).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. An outbreak of measles in a school: Incorrect. Transmission is primarily from incubatory carriers before rash onset, not healthy carriers.

 

Option C. A Diphtheria outbreak in a vaccinated population: Incorrect. Vaccination reduces disease severity, but healthy carriers are not the main threat; rather, asymptomatic incubatory or convalescent carriers may play a role.

 

Option D. A Pertussis outbreak in a hospital pediatric ward: Incorrect. Pertussis has incubatory and convalescent carriers, but healthy carriers are not the dominant source of spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Healthy carriers play a critical role in sustaining epidemics of diseases where asymptomatic shedding + environmental factors (like poor sanitation) amplify transmission.
  • Cholera is the classic example: asymptomatic carriers contaminate water supplies, creating large-scale outbreaks.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man sustains a shoulder injury after falling backward with his arm in forced hyperextension. He presents with posterior shoulder pain and difficulty with elbow extension. Imaging suggests that the long head of the triceps brachii has been avulsed from its normal attachment site. From which anatomical location is this tendon most likely detached?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Infraglenoid tubercle

 

  • The long head of the triceps brachii originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.
  • During forced hyperextension injuries, there is tension at this origin, which can lead to detachment or avulsion.
  • The clinical findings of pain at the posterior shoulder and weakness in elbow extension further support detachment at the long head’s origin site.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraglenoid tubercle: This is the origin of the long head of the biceps brachii, not the triceps. It is unrelated to the described injury.

 

Option B. Shaft of the humerus: The lateral and medial heads of the triceps originate from the posterior surface of the humerus, but these are not affected in hyperextension injuries that specifically involve the scapular attachment.

 

Option C. Olecranon process: This is the insertion site of all three heads of the triceps brachii, not the origin. An avulsion here would affect the distal tendon, not the long head’s origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long head of the triceps brachii originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula, and hyperextension injuries can lead to avulsion from this site.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatrician for a routine examination. On physical examination, the right side of the scrotum is empty, and the testis is palpated in the inguinal canal. The parents are concerned and ask about possible complications their child may face in the future if this condition is left untreated. Which of the following is the least likely complication associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal hydrocele

 

  • A vaginal hydrocele occurs when there is to fluid accumulation around the testis only in the scrotum (tunica vaginalis). 
  • However, in the case of an undescended testis, a patent processus vaginalis will lead to a “congenital” hydrocele which will extend from the scrotum up to the deep ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indirect inguinal hernia: Highly likely. About 90% of undescended testes are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, predisposing to indirect inguinal hernias.

 

Option B. Infertility: Common in undescended testes due to impaired spermatogenesis from higher intra-abdominal temperature. Even after orchidopexy, fertility may still be affected, particularly in bilateral cases.

 

Option C. Testicular torsion: More likely to occur in undescended testes due to inadequate fixation and abnormal mesentery, making them prone to rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is associated with several complications if not surgically corrected early, including infertility, malignancy risk, inguinal hernia, and testicular torsion. 
  • However, a vaginal hydrocele is less likely in this condition since it typically involves the scrotal testis.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man with HIV presents with 5 days of myalgia progressing proximally, fatigue, and polyuria. He is on tenofovir disoproxil fumarate/emtricitabine + raltegravir for the past year.

Investigations:

 

 

HLA-B*5701: negative
HBsAg: positive

What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abacavir/lamivudine + raltegravir + entecavir

 

  • The patient has proximal tubular injury (Fanconi syndrome) from TDF: hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, normal-glycemia glucosuria, low-grade proteinuria, metabolic acidosis, and acute kidney injury. 
  • TDF should be stopped.
  • In HIV/HBV coinfection, if tenofovir (TDF/TAF) cannot be used, guidelines recommend a fully suppressive ART regimen for HIV and adding entecavir for HBV. 
  • A suitable HIV regimen here is abacavir/lamivudine + raltegravir (HLA-B*5701 negative, no baseline resistance), with entecavir added for HBV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tenofovir alafenamide/emtricitabine + entecavir: TAF is less nephrotoxic than TDF, but with active tubular toxicity and AKI, the safer approach is to avoid tenofovir; adding entecavir is unnecessary if tenofovir is used.

 

Option B. Abacavir/lamivudine + entecavir: Lacks a third active agent for HIV; not a fully suppressive ART regimen.

 

Option D. Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate/emtricitabine + entecavir: Continues the offending drug (TDF) causing Fanconi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV/HBV coinfection with TDF-induced Fanconi syndrome or tenofovir intolerance, stop TDF and use a fully suppressive non-tenofovir ART regimen (e.g., ABC/3TC + INSTI) and add entecavir for HBV treatment.

questions.text: Match the antifungal drugs with their mechanism of action:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1–d, 2–b, 3–c, 4–a

 

  • 1–d. Polyenes (e.g., Amphotericin B, Nystatin) bind to ergosterol in fungal membranes, forming pores that cause electrolyte leakage and cell death.
  • 2–b. Echinocandins (e.g., Caspofungin) inhibit the synthesis of β-1,3-glucan, an essential component of the fungal cell wall, leading to lysis.
  • 3–c. Azoles (like itraconazole) inhibit lanosterol-14-α-demethylase, blocking ergosterol synthesis and impairing membrane integrity.
  • 4–a. 5-Flucytosine, an antimetabolite, is converted into 5-FU inside fungal cells, which interferes with nucleic acid synthesis by inhibiting thymidylate synthase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mechanism of action and cellular targets of key antifungal drug classes:

 

  • Polyenes bind to ergosterol and disrupt fungal membranes,
  • Echinocandins inhibit β-1,3-glucan synthesis affecting the fungal cell wall,
  • Azoles inhibit ergosterol synthesis via lanosterol-14-α-demethylase inhibition, and
  • 5-Flucytosine impairs fungal DNA/RNA synthesis.

choices.text: No movement of image with mirror
Reflex can move to any side

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a refractive error of –0.5 diopters (D) of myopia undergoes retinoscopy at a distance of 1 meter. The examiner observes the movement of the red reflex in response to lateral mirror movement. What will be the expected movement of the reflex in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Moves with the mirror

 

  • Retinoscopy is based on the relative position of the far point of the patient’s eye with respect to the observer (typically 1 meter away).
  • At 1 meter, the neutral point corresponds to –1.0 D (because 1/1 = 1 D).
  • If the patient is less myopic than –1.0 D (i.e., –0.5 D in this case), the far point lies behind the observer.
  • When the far point is behind the mirror (observer), the light rays diverge when entering the observer's pupil, and the reflex moves WITH the mirror.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Moves opposite to the mirror: Incorrect. This occurs in myopia > –1.0 D (e.g., –2.0 D), where the far point lies in front of the observer.

 

Option C. No movement of image with mirror: Incorrect. Seen in –1.0 D myopia only — at this power, the far point of the eye coincides exactly with the 1-meter observation distance.

 

Option D. Reflex can move to any side: Incorrect. Reflex movement in retinoscopy is directional and based on optics, not random or variable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In retinoscopy at 1 meter, if the eye has < –1.0 D myopia, the reflex will move with the mirror.
  • If the eye has > –1.0 D myopia, the reflex will move against the mirror.
    At exactly –1.0 D, there will be no movement (neutral point).

questions.text:
Regarding Fishbone Diagrams, which of the following statements are correct?

 

  1. They are also known as Ishikawa diagrams.
  2. They are most useful in identifying correlation between variables.
  3. They are often used in Six Sigma and Total Quality Management (TQM).
  4. They require precise numerical data to be effective.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3 only

 

 

  • Statement 1. They are also known as Ishikawa diagrams: Correct. The Fishbone Diagram is also called the Ishikawa diagram after Kaoru Ishikawa, who popularized its use in quality control.
  • Statement 3. They are often used in Six Sigma and Total Quality Management (TQM): Correct. It is widely applied in Six Sigma, Lean, and TQM as a structured method to explore root causes.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 2. They are most useful in identifying correlation between variables: Incorrect. Fishbone diagrams do not identify correlations; they help categorize possible causes of a problem for brainstorming.

 

Statement 4. They require precise numerical data to be effective: Incorrect. They do not require precise numerical data; they are qualitative tools, often used in early problem analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Fishbone Diagram (Ishikawa Diagram) is a root cause analysis tool.
  • It organizes possible causes into categories (e.g., People, Process, Equipment, Environment) to identify underlying problems.
  • It is a qualitative brainstorming tool, not a quantitative one.

questions.text: A woman undergoing hysteroscopic resection of an endometrial polyp is scheduled for surgery using a monopolar resectoscope. Which of the following distension media is not appropriate for use in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal saline

 

  • In hysteroscopic surgery, the type of energy source determines which fluid medium can be safely used for uterine distension:
    • Monopolar resectoscopes require nonelectrolyte, non-conductive solutions such as glycine, sorbitol, or mannitol. These media prevent current dispersion and allow safe monopolar energy application.
    • Normal saline is an electrolyte-containing solution and is therefore contraindicated with monopolar systems because it conducts current, risking burns, ineffective resection, and complications.
    • Saline is, however, the medium of choice when bipolar resectoscopes are used.
  • Thus, in a monopolar hysteroscopic procedure, normal saline should not be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorbitol: A nonelectrolyte, non-conductive solution that can be safely used as a distension medium in monopolar hysteroscopic surgery.

 

Option C. Mannitol: Another nonelectrolyte solution, commonly used in monopolar hysteroscopy, which prevents current conduction.

 

Option D. Glycine: A widely used medium for monopolar resection; it is non-conductive and safe in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In hysteroscopic surgery using a monopolar resectoscope, only nonelectrolyte solutions such as glycine, sorbitol, or mannitol are used.
  • Normal saline is contraindicated because it conducts electrical current.

choices.text: They act as transcription factors that increase mRNA synthesis
They regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally by inhibiting translation
They serve as primers for DNA replication
They splice pre-mRNA to form mature mRNA

questions.text: A researcher is studying a patient’s tumor sample and finds that certain small, non-coding RNAs are abnormally expressed. These RNAs bind to complementary sequences on target mRNAs, leading to repression of protein translation. Overexpression of these RNAs is found to silence tumor-suppressor genes, contributing to carcinogenesis. Which of the following best describes the function of these molecules?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally by inhibiting translation 

 

  • MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small, non-coding RNAs (≈22 nucleotides) that bind to complementary sequences on target mRNAs. 
  • They either block translation or promote degradation of the mRNA, thus acting as post-transcriptional gene regulators.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They act as transcription factors that increase mRNA synthesis: Transcription factors are proteins that bind DNA to promote or repress transcription. MicroRNAs do not act at the transcriptional level; they function after mRNA is made.

 

Option C. They serve as primers for DNA replication: Primers in DNA replication are short RNA sequences synthesized by primase, not microRNAs.

 

Option D. They splice pre-mRNA to form mature mRNA: Splicing is carried out by the spliceosome (snRNPs), not by microRNAs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MicroRNAs (miRNAs) regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally by binding to complementary sequences on target mRNAs, leading to translational repression or degradation. 
  • Dysregulation of miRNAs can promote carcinogenesis by silencing tumor suppressor genes.

choices.text: The lens becomes thinner and more curved, increasing dioptric power
Suspensory ligaments (zonules) become stretched, increasing lens tension
Ciliary muscle contracts, reducing zonular tension and allowing the lens to become thicker
Tension on the lens increases due to sympathetic stimulation

questions.text: A 22-year-old medical student shifts his gaze from a distant screen to read small text in a book placed 25 cm away. Which of the following physiological changes correctly occurs in the eye during this near response?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ciliary muscle contracts, reducing zonular tension and allowing the lens to become thicker

 

  • When focusing on near objects, the eye undergoes accommodation:
    • The ciliary muscle contracts (parasympathetic action via cranial nerve III).
    • This relaxes the suspensory ligaments (zonules of Zinn).
    • As a result, the lens becomes thicker and more convex due to its natural elasticity.
    • This increases its refractive (dioptric) power, allowing convergence of light rays from near objects onto the retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The lens becomes thinner and more curved, increasing dioptric power: Incorrect. The lens becomes thicker and more curved, not thinner, during accommodation.
