questions.text: A 19-year-old with a confirmed 7-week intrauterine pregnancy requests termination. She is counselled about available approaches. Which of the following represents the best option for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) at this gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mifepristone 200 mg and Misoprostol 800 mcg after 48 hours

 

  • At 7 weeks pregnancy, the most effective regimen for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) is Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed 48 hours later by Misoprostol 800 mcg.
  • Mifepristone (200 mg) acts as a progesterone receptor antagonist, causing breakdown of the decidua, detachment of the gestational sac, and cervical softening.
  • After 48 hours, Misoprostol (800 mcg), a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces strong uterine contractions, leading to expulsion of products of conception.
  • This sequential regimen is safe, effective, and specifically recommended for pregnancies up to 7 weeks, exactly as described in the case of this 19-year-old.
  • Therefore, the best option is Mifepristone 200 mg followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg after 48 hours.

 

Note: Methotrexate has been studied for early MTP, but it is not the standard regimen compared with Mifepristone and Misoprostol. It acts more slowly, is less effective, and is rarely used in current practice for a 7-week pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) at ≤7 weeks gestation, the best regimen is Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed 48 hours later by Misoprostol 800 mcg.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old primigravida at term presents in labor. During intrapartum monitoring, the fetal head is persistently noted to be in the occiput posterior position. Which of the following maternal or fetal factors are known to favor posterior position of the vertex?

 

  1. Anthropoid pelvis
  2. Low inclination pelvis
  3. Attachment of placenta on the anterior wall
  4. Primary brachycephaly
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4

 

  • The posterior position of the vertex (occiput posterior) is influenced by several maternal and fetal factors that alter fetal head engagement and rotation.
    • A high inclination pelvis predisposes to malrotation and posterior positioning.
    • Anterior wall placental attachment may mechanically affect fetal orientation, favoring posterior positions.
    • Primary brachycephaly (a shortened anteroposterior diameter of the fetal skull) increases the likelihood of posterior vertex persistence.
    • Anthropoid pelvis
  • Therefore, the combination 1, 3, and 4 are recognized factors favoring posterior position of the vertex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior position of the vertex is favoured by high inclination pelvis, anterior wall placental attachment, and primary brachycephaly and anthropoid pelvis

questions.text: A patient with a history of consuming tobacco presents with a lesion on his tongue. It is 3 x 2 cm in size. Biopsy confirms the lesion to be a squamous cell carcinoma. Imaging reveals that the tumor depth is 12 mm, without invasion into the floor of mouth or mandible. What is the T stage of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T3

 

  • Tumor of size 3 x 2 cm with DOI of 12 mm is T3.
  • Tumors >4 cm in size, or those with DOI >10 mm, are classified as T3. 
  • In this case, the tumor has a DOI of 12 mm, which places it in the T3 category, regardless of its size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1: Tumors that are ≤2 cm in greatest dimension and have a depth of invasion (DOI) ≤5 mm fall under this category. Since the tumor is 3 cm in size and has a DOI of 12 mm, this stage does not apply.

 

Option B. T2: Tumors >2 cm but ≤4 cm in size, or those with DOI >5 mm but ≤10 mm are classified as T2. Although the tumor is within the size range for T2 (3 cm), its depth of invasion exceeds the upper limit of 10 mm, so T2 does not apply.

 

Option D. T4a: Tumors with invasion into adjacent structures, such as the floor of the mouth, mandible, or skin, fall into this stage. Since the imaging confirms no invasion into surrounding structures, T4a does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with gradually increasing unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. MRI with gadolinium contrast reveals a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. Which cranial nerve is most likely the initial origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior vestibular nerve

 

  • The most common tumor in the cerebellopontine (CP) angle is a vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). 
  • These tumors most often arise from the Schwann cells of the inferior vestibular nerve, a branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). 
  • Gradual unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes imbalance are the hallmark symptoms.
  • Key findings:
    • MRI with gadolinium confirms the diagnosis by identifying the mass.
    • Acoustic neuroma typically originates from the inferior vestibular nerve, even though it may later compress the cochlear nerve (causing hearing loss) and the facial nerve (causing facial symptoms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear nerve: The cochlear nerve transmits auditory signals and is often affected secondarily by compression in cases of vestibular schwannoma. However, it is not the primary site of origin.

 

Option B. Superior vestibular nerve: While part of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the superior vestibular nerve is less commonly the origin of vestibular schwannomas compared to the inferior vestibular nerve.

 

Option D. Facial nerve: The facial nerve passes through the CP angle but is not the origin of vestibular schwannomas. However, it can be compressed by the tumor as it grows, leading to facial numbness or weakness in advanced cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) most commonly originate from the inferior vestibular nerve and present with gradual unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and a mass in the cerebellopontine angle.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the Triangle of Koch is/are incorrect? 

 

  1. The Triangle of Koch is located in the lower part of the septal wall of the right atrium.
  2. It is bounded by the tendon of Todaro, ostium of the coronary sinus, and the septal cusp of the tricuspid valve.
  3. The atrioventricular (AV) node and its atrial connections are found within this triangle.
  4. The Triangle of Koch lies in the lower part of the septal wall of the left atrium.
  5. The tendon of Todaro forms the posterior boundary of this anatomical triangle.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 only

 

  • The Triangle of Koch is an important anatomical landmark located in the lower part of the septal wall of the right atrium. 
  • It is bounded by three key structures:
    • Tendon of Todaro (posteriorly),
    • Ostium of the coronary sinus (inferiorly),
    • Septal cusp of the tricuspid valve (anteriorly).
  • Within this triangle lies the atrioventricular (AV) node and its atrial connections, making it a critical area for cardiac conduction physiology.

 

 

Statement 4. The Triangle of Koch lies in the lower part of the septal wall of the left atrium: This is the incorrect statement. It is confined to the right atrium, not the left.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. The Triangle of Koch is located in the lower part of the septal wall of the right atrium: This is correct and defines the anatomical site precisely.

 

Statement 2. It is bounded by the tendon of Todaro, ostium of the coronary sinus, and the septal cusp of the tricuspid valve: This statement is correct. These three boundaries form the triangular area.

 

Statement 3. The atrioventricular (AV) node and its atrial connections are found within this triangle: This is correct. The AV node lies within this triangle and is crucial for electrical conduction between atria and ventricles.

 

Statement 5. The tendon of Todaro forms the posterior boundary of this anatomical triangle: This is correct. The tendon of Todaro indeed serves as the posterior landmark of the triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Triangle of Koch is a key anatomical landmark in the right atrium, bounded by the tendon of Todaro, ostium of the coronary sinus, and the septal cusp of the tricuspid valve. 
  • It houses the atrioventricular (AV) node, an essential component of the cardiac conduction system.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about methylnaltrexone is/are correct? 

 

  1. It reverses CNS depression in opioid overdose
  2. It crosses the blood-brain barrier and cause withdrawal
  3. It is used for treatment of opioid-induced constipation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 3 is correct

 

Statement 3. It is used for treatment of opioid-induced constipation: Correct. 

 

  • Clinical use: Treatment of opioid-induced constipation in patients receiving long-term opioid therapy (esp. palliative care or post-surgery).
  • By blocking peripheral μ-receptors in the gut, it restores normal bowel motility without affecting analgesia.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 1. It reverses CNS depression in opioid overdose: Incorrect.

 

  • Methylnaltrexone is a peripherally acting μ-opioid receptor antagonist (PAMORA).
  • It acts only on peripheral μ-receptors (especially in the GI tract) and does not cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB).
  • Therefore, it cannot reverse CNS effects such as respiratory depression or coma.
  • The drug used to reverse CNS depression in opioid overdose is Naloxone (centrally acting).

 

Statement 2. It crosses the blood-brain barrier and causes withdrawal: Incorrect.

 

  • Methylnaltrexone is a quaternary ammonium compound → polar, does not cross the BBB.
  • Because it stays peripheral, it does not precipitate opioid withdrawal or interfere with central analgesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylnaltrexone and alvimopan are peripheral μ-opioid receptor antagonists that treat opioid-induced constipation and postoperative ileus without affecting central opioid effects or causing withdrawal.

questions.text: A 12-month-old child weighing 5 kg is admitted to the pediatric ward with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). The child presents with lethargy, edema, and hypothermia. On examination, the child has severe wasting, sunken eyes, and a distended abdomen. The heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 35/min, and temperature is 35.5°C. The child is diagnosed to be in the stabilization phase of SAM management. Which of the following is contraindicated during this phase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron supplementation

 

  • Iron supplementation is strictly contraindicated during the stabilization phase of treating Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) for several important physiological reasons. 
  • Children with SAM often have compromised immune systems and are at high risk for infections, including sepsis. 
  • Iron is an essential nutrient for many pathogenic bacteria, and providing iron during this vulnerable period can potentially fuel bacterial growth and worsen infections that may already be present.
  • Additionally, in the context of severe malnutrition, children have reduced antioxidant capacity. 
  • Iron can catalyze the production of free radicals through Fenton chemistry, leading to oxidative stress that damages cells and tissues. 
  • The malnourished child's body lacks the protective mechanisms to handle this increased oxidative burden safely.
  • Another concern is that during the early stabilization phase, the intestinal barrier function is often compromised in children with SAM. 
  • This means that iron supplementation could lead to increased intestinal permeability, allowing more bacterial translocation and potentially worsening the child's condition.
  • Iron supplementation should only begin during the rehabilitation phase, when infections are under control, the child is metabolically stable, and has begun to show weight gain. 
  • At this point, the benefits of iron for treating anemia outweigh the risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: Far from being contraindicated, antibiotics are actually essential during the stabilization phase. Children with SAM have a compromised immune system and are at high risk for occult infections. Current WHO guidelines recommend routine antibiotics for all children with SAM, even without clinical signs of infection. Common regimens include amoxicillin for uncomplicated cases or ampicillin plus gentamicin for those with complications.

 

Option C. Vitamin A supplementation: Vitamin A is recommended during the stabilization phase as children with SAM are often vitamin A deficient. Vitamin A supplementation reduces mortality, improves immune function, and aids in epithelial tissue repair. The recommended dose is 100,000 IU for children 6-12 months or 200,000 IU for children >12 months, given on day 1 of treatment.

 

Option D. Folic acid supplementation: Folic acid is not contraindicated and is routinely provided during the stabilization phase. Many children with SAM have megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency. The recommended dose is 5mg on day 1 fb 1 mg per day for the duration of treatment. Unlike iron, folic acid doesn't increase infection risk and helps support red blood cell production.

 

Treatment Phases in SAM:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The treatment of SAM follows a carefully staged approach where certain interventions are deliberately withheld during the stabilization phase. 
  • Iron supplementation is specifically contraindicated during this critical initial period due to increased infection risk, potential for oxidative stress, and compromised intestinal barrier function. 
  • This highlights the principle that proper timing of nutritional interventions is as important as the interventions themselves.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. His serum lipase is moderately elevated, and CT abdomen reveals an abdominal mass. On examination, he has cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy, along with enlarged salivary glands. Laboratory investigations show a serum creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL and urinalysis shows minimal proteinuria, white cells present, no microscopic hematuria. Which of the following would be the most useful serological test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG4 levels

 

  • This patient most likely has IgG4-related disease, a systemic fibroinflammatory condition that often presents as tubulointerstitial nephritis on renal biopsy.
  • Common manifestations include:
    • Pancreatic mass or pancreatitis (autoimmune pancreatitis)
    • Sialadenitis (salivary gland enlargement)
    • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • The constellation of renal involvement, pancreatic mass, and salivary gland enlargement strongly supports IgG4-related disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum ANA level: Unlikely to be lupus; the patient is a middle-aged man without arthralgia, rash, or serositis. Pancreatic involvement is not typical of SLE.

 

Option B. Serum SSA and SSB testing: Useful for Sjögren’s syndrome, but this does not explain the pancreatic mass or renal involvement pattern.

 

Option C. ACE level: Elevated ACE may suggest sarcoidosis, which can mimic this presentation. However, IgG4-related disease is a better unifying diagnosis for the given findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IgG4-related disease is a multiorgan, immune-mediated disorder characterized by:
    • Elevated serum IgG4 levels
    • Storiform fibrosis and lymphoplasmacytic infiltration with IgG4-positive plasma cells
    • Commonly involves pancreas, kidneys, salivary glands, and lymph nodes
  • Renal involvement often presents as interstitial nephritis with mild renal dysfunction and minimal proteinuria. Early recognition is important, as the disease responds well to corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of irritability, vomiting, and tachypnea. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated blood ammonia. Plasma amino acid analysis reveals absence of citrulline, while urinary studies demonstrate elevated orotic acid. Urine screening for indole compounds is negative. Which of the following enzyme reactions is most likely impaired in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of ornithine to citrulline

 

  • The correct answer is conversion of ornithine to citrulline, which is catalyzed by ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC).
  • OTC deficiency is the most common inherited urea cycle disorder.
  • The clinical hallmarks are hyperammonemia, neurologic manifestations (irritability, confusion, vomiting, rapid breathing), absence of citrulline in plasma, and elevated urinary orotic acid.
  • Orotic acid accumulates because carbamoyl phosphate, unable to enter the urea cycle, is shunted into pyrimidine synthesis, leading to increased orotic acid excretion.
  • The child’s normal diet and absence of serotonin/indole abnormalities rule out alternative metabolic pathways, confirming urea cycle involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of citrulline to argininosuccinate: Incorrect. This step is catalyzed by argininosuccinate synthetase. A defect here causes citrullinemia, with high plasma citrulline levels, which contradicts this case (where citrulline is absent).

 

Option C. Conversion of arginine to ornithine: Incorrect. This reaction is mediated by arginase, deficiency of which presents with spasticity, growth delay, and elevated arginine. Hyperammonemia may occur, but orotic aciduria is not a feature.

 

Option D. Conversion of argininosuccinate to arginine: This step is catalyzed by argininosuccinate lyase. Deficiency leads to argininosuccinic aciduria, with elevated argininosuccinate levels, not absence of citrulline. Hence, this option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency) impairs the conversion of ornithine to citrulline, leading to hyperammonemia, absent plasma citrulline, and elevated urinary orotic acid.

choices.text: Compare two independent Kaplan-Meier survival curves
Visualize the uncertainty around the Kaplan-Meier survival estimate over time
Estimate hazard ratios between treatment groups
Correct for competing risk bias in survival analysis

questions.text: Hall-Wellner confidence bands in survival analysis are primarily used to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Visualize the uncertainty around the Kaplan-Meier survival estimate over time

 

  • Hall-Wellner bands provide simultaneous confidence intervals around a Kaplan-Meier survival curve.
  • They create a shaded region that represents the range of plausible values of the survival probability function at each time point, typically at the 95% confidence level.
  • This allows researchers to see how much uncertainty/variability exists in the estimate of survival across time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Compare two independent Kaplan-Meier survival curves: Incorrect. This is done with statistical tests such as the log-rank test, not confidence bands.

 

Option C. Estimate hazard ratios between treatment groups: Incorrect. Hazard ratios are estimated using models like the Cox proportional hazards model, not Kaplan-Meier bands.

 

Option D. Correct for competing risk bias in survival analysis: Incorrect. Competing risk analysis uses cumulative incidence functions (CIFs) and Fine-Gray models, not Hall-Wellner bands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hall-Wellner bands are used to create confidence regions around Kaplan-Meier survival curves, visualizing the uncertainty in survival probability estimates.
  • They are not tools for group comparison, hazard ratio estimation, or competing risk adjustment.

choices.text: Dopaminergic dysregulation in the mesolimbic pathway
Noradrenergic hyperactivity in the locus coeruleus
Cholinergic overactivity in the basal forebrain
Serotonin depletion in the substantia nigra

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset palpitations, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and a feeling of impending doom. These symptoms peaked within 10 minutes and resolved spontaneously. Cardiac and respiratory evaluations are normal. She reports experiencing similar episodes over the past 3 months, often without warning. Which of the following neurobiological abnormalities is most strongly implicated in the etiology of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Noradrenergic hyperactivity in the locus coeruleus

 

  • The patient's presentation — sudden onset of palpitations, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and sense of impending doom, peaking within 10 minutes and resolving spontaneously, with normal physical and lab evaluation — is classic for panic attacks, and the history of recurrent, untriggered episodes over 3 months confirms panic disorder.
  • Neurobiology of Panic Disorder:
    • The most strongly implicated neurobiological abnormality in panic disorder is hyperactivity of the noradrenergic system, particularly in the locus coeruleus (LC), a brainstem nucleus that is a major source of norepinephrine (NE). 
    • The LC plays a key role in fear and arousal, and its overactivation can trigger the autonomic symptoms of a panic attack (e.g., tachycardia, dyspnea, tremors).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopaminergic dysregulation in the mesolimbic pathway: This is associated with positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), not panic disorder.

 

Option C. Cholinergic overactivity in the basal forebrain: This is more relevant to cognitive processes, particularly Alzheimer’s disease and memory functions, not the fear/anxiety circuits of panic.

 

Option D. Serotonin depletion in the substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is a dopaminergic area implicated in Parkinson’s disease, not a serotonergic structure involved in panic disorder. While serotonin (5-HT) plays a modulatory role in anxiety and panic (and SSRIs are used in treatment), the core abnormality is not in the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurotransmitters and neuromodulators that have been hypothesised to be involved in the development of panic disorder include norepinephrine, serotonin, GABA, and cholecystokinin.

questions.text:
Which of the following test-principle pairings are correct?

 

  1. Direct Coombs test – Detects unbound maternal antibodies
  2. Reverse passive latex agglutination – Detects antigen using antibody-coated particles
  3. Indirect hemagglutination assay – Detects antibody using antigen-coated RBCs
  4. Cold agglutination test – Performed for Mycoplasma pneumoniae diagnosis
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

 

Pair 2. Reverse passive latex agglutination – Detects antigen using antibody-coated particles:

 

  • Uses antibodies coated on latex beads to detect specific antigens in clinical samples (e.g., CRP, HBsAg, bacterial capsular Ags).
  • Commonly used for antigen detection.

 

Pair 3. Indirect hemagglutination assay – Detects antibody using antigen-coated RBCs:

 

  • In this test, antigen is attached to RBCs, and the presence of serum antibodies leads to visible agglutination.
  • Used for detecting antibodies against various organisms.

 

Pair 4. Cold agglutination test – Performed for Mycoplasma pneumoniae diagnosis:

 

  • Detects IgM autoantibodies (cold agglutinins) that agglutinate RBCs at low temperatures.
  • Seen in Mycoplasma pneumoniae, EBV, and some lymphomas.

 

Incorrect Pair :

 

Pair 1. Direct Coombs test – Detects unbound maternal antibodies:

 

  • Detects already bound antibodies or complement on fetal/newborn RBCs.
    Used in Hemolytic Disease of the Newborn (HDN) or autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
  • Indirect Coombs detects free antibodies in maternal serum, NOT direct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Agglutination Tests:

questions.text:
Which of the following parasites defy traditional definitive-intermediate host definitions due to lack of sexual reproduction?

 

  1. Leishmania species
  2. Trypanosoma brucei
  3. Schistosoma species
  4. Cryptosporidium species
  5. Taenia solium

 

Choose the correct combinations:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Option 1. Leishmania species: True. It lacks a sexual stage in both human and sandfly hosts. Terminology of "vertebrate" and "invertebrate" host is more accurate.

 

Option 2. Trypanosoma brucei: True. Like Leishmania, it reproduces asexually in both hosts. No sexual cycle occurs. Terminology of "vertebrate" and "invertebrate" host is more accurate here too.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option 3. Schistosoma species: False. This trematode undergoes sexual reproduction in humans, making humans the definitive host.

 

Option 4. Cryptosporidium species: False. Undergoes both asexual and sexual reproduction within humans. Thus, humans are the definitive host.

 

Option 5. Taenia solium: False. Has a well-defined sexual cycle in humans, making them the definitive host.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parasites like Leishmania and Trypanosoma brucei lack a sexual stage, making the definitive/intermediate host terminology less meaningful. 
  • Their host relationships are better described using vertebrate-invertebrate classification.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about competitive inhibition is/are correct? 

 

  1. The inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate.
  2. Competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the enzyme reaction.
  3. Excess substrate can overcome the inhibition.
  4. In the presence of competitive inhibition, Km increases, while Vmax remains the same.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Statement 1, 3, 4 

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the enzyme's active site.

 

Statement 1. The inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate: The inhibitor in competitive inhibition is typically a structural analogue of the substrate Meaning it has a similar shape but does not undergo the reaction.

 

Statement 3. Excess substrate can overcome the inhibition: Excess substrate can overcome competitive inhibition by outcompeting the inhibitor for the enzyme’s active site.

 

Statement 4. In the presence of competitive inhibition, Km increases, while Vmax remains the same: In competitive inhibition, the Km increases (i.e., the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases), but the Vmax remains unchanged, because the enzyme’s catalytic efficiency is not reduced at high substrate concentrations.

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

Statement 2. Competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the enzyme reaction: Incorrect. Competitive inhibition does not decrease Vmax. While the enzyme's apparent affinity for the substrate (Km) increases, the Vmax remains unchanged because sufficient substrate can still achieve maximal enzyme activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate, the inhibition is reversible, Km increases, and Vmax remains the same. 
  • The inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

choices.text: Acetoacetate is metabolised to beta hydroxybutyrate
Acidaemia is the primary cause of intracellular potassium loss
Hepatic glucose production reaches a plateau within 4 hours of insulin withdrawal
Hepatic glucose production rises gradually over the first 6–8 hours following insulin withdrawal

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is admitted to emergency with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a 5-year history of type 1 diabetes with poor adherence to her therapy. Her current insulin regimen comprises insulin glargine and Aspart via a basal-bolus regimen. On examination, she is dehydrated and breathing deeply.

  • Blood Pressure: 98/66 mm Hg  
  • Pulse: 105 bpm

Investigations:

 

 

Which of the following is a feature of the pathophysiology of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic glucose production reaches a plateau within 4 hours of insulin withdrawal

 

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is an extension of the normal fasting state. Hepatic glucose production rises rapidly over the first 2–4 hours following insulin withdrawal, reaching a plateau after around 4 hours. 
  • These changes correlate with the initial acute rise in glucagon concentrations, with other counter-regulatory hormones being little affected initially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetoacetate is metabolised to beta hydroxybutyrate:
Both are produced during fatty acid oxidation; the ratio depends on the redox state (NADH/NAD⁺), not direct metabolism.

 

Option B. Acidaemia is the primary cause of intracellular potassium loss: Insulin deficiency and hyperosmolality, not acidosis, cause potassium to shift out of cells.

 

Option D. Hepatic glucose production rises gradually over 6–8 hours:
The rise occurs rapidly within 2–4 hours, not gradually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In DKA, insulin deficiency combined with glucagon excess leads to accelerated hepatic gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis.
  • Hepatic glucose output peaks within 4 hours of insulin withdrawal.
  • Ketone body formation results from enhanced fatty acid oxidation and increased acetyl-CoA availability.
  • Early glucagon surge precedes cortisol and catecholamine effects.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent vomiting, failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and massive adrenal calcification seen on abdominal imaging. Genetic testing identifies an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acid lipase

 

  • Wolman’s disease is a rare lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (acid lipase). 
  • This enzyme normally hydrolyzes cholesteryl esters and triglycerides in lysosomes. Deficiency leads to accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in multiple tissues, especially the liver, spleen, and adrenal glands, resulting in hepatosplenomegaly and adrenal calcification. 
  • Infants typically present with failure to thrive, malabsorption, diarrhea, vomiting, and growth retardation. 
  • It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. β-glucocerebrosidase: Deficiency causes Gaucher’s disease, characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, bone crises, and lipid-laden macrophages (“Gaucher cells”). Not associated with adrenal calcification.

 

Option C. Arylsulfatase A: Deficiency leads to metachromatic leukodystrophy, which presents with progressive demyelination, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. Not a storage disease involving triglycerides or adrenal calcification.

 

Option D. Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency results in Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by developmental regression, cherry-red spot on the macula, and neurodegeneration without hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wolman’s disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to hepatosplenomegaly, fat malabsorption, and adrenal calcification.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy undergoes a detailed second-trimester ultrasound. One fetus demonstrates oligohydramnios with a nearly absent bladder, while the co-twin has marked polyhydramnios. Fetal Doppler studies are concerning for imbalance in placental blood flow. The severity of this condition is assessed by which staging system?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quintero staging

 

  • Quintero staging is the recognized system for classifying the severity of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) in monochorionic pregnancies. 
  • It is based on ultrasound and fetal Doppler findings, describing the progression of disease from mild to severe:
    • Stage I: Oligohydramnios in the donor sac and polyhydramnios in the recipient sac.
    • Stage II: Donor bladder is not visible on ultrasound.
    • Stage III: Abnormal Doppler studies (e.g., absent or reversed end-diastolic flow).
    • Stage IV: Hydrops fetalis in either twin.
    • Stage V: Fetal demise.
  • This classification guides clinical decision-making, including timing and need for fetoscopic laser ablation of placental vascular anastomoses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg criteria: This is used to diagnose ovarian pregnancy (based on the location of gestational sac relative to ovarian tissue). It is not related to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Option C. Jones staging: There is no established "Jones staging" for TTTS; this is not a recognized system in obstetrics.

 

Option D. Sapporo criteria: These are used to diagnose antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS), which is associated with recurrent pregnancy loss and thrombosis, but not for classifying TTTS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The severity of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome in monochorionic twin pregnancies is classified using the Quintero staging system (Stages I–V), which is essential for guiding prognosis and management.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure from the histological slide given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Terminal bronchus

 

  • This histological image shows a section of lung tissue displaying various components of the respiratory pathway. 
  • The marked structure represents a terminal bronchiole (terminal bronchus), which is characterized by its relatively thick muscular wall compared to the surrounding structures.
  • The respiratory pathway follows a hierarchical organization: primary bronchus → secondary bronchus → tertiary bronchus (supplying bronchopulmonary segments) → terminal bronchioles → respiratory bronchioles → alveolar ducts → alveolar sacs → alveoli.
  • Terminal bronchioles are the final conducting airways before the respiratory zone begins. They are distinguished by:
    • Thick muscular walls with smooth muscle
    • No gas exchange occurs at this level
    • They divide to form respiratory bronchioles where gas exchange begins
    • Larger caliber compared to respiratory bronchioles
  • The marked structure shows the characteristic thick-walled appearance of a terminal bronchiole, distinguishing it from the thinner-walled respiratory bronchioles and alveolar structures visible in the surrounding tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory bronchus: These are thin-walled structures where gas exchange begins. They have alveolar outpouchings in their walls and appear much thinner than the marked structure. Respiratory bronchioles can be seen as the thinner-walled structures with small pouches (alveolar openings) in the image.

 

Option B. Bronchus: Larger bronchi have much thicker walls with cartilage support and are considerably larger in diameter than the marked structure. The marked structure is too small and lacks the cartilaginous framework characteristic of bronchi.

 

Option D. Alveoli: These are the thin-walled air sacs visible throughout the image as large, clear spaces. Alveoli are the sites of gas exchange and have extremely thin walls (respiratory membrane). The marked structure is clearly much thicker-walled and tubular compared to the spherical, thin-walled alveoli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminal bronchioles are thick-walled conducting airways that mark the end of the conducting zone and precede the respiratory zone where gas exchange begins in respiratory bronchioles.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. His liver function tests reveal a marked elevation in ALT, AST, and bilirubin. Which of the following anti-TB drug has least risk of hepatotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Streptomycin 

 

  • Streptomycin is considered non-hepatotoxic anti-tubercular drug and can be used in patients with significantly abnormal liver function. 
  • In such patients, minimizing the hepatic burden is essential to avoid worsening hepatotoxicity. 
  • Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside, is renally excreted and does not undergo hepatic metabolism. 
  • Ethambutol (not ethionamide) also has a relatively low hepatotoxic potential and is suitable for liver-compromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Causes dose-independent hepatotoxicity; manifests with elevated transaminases, sometimes severe hepatitis. Risk ↑ with age and alcohol. 

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Causes cholestatic jaundice and increases hepatotoxicity of INH/PZA by enzyme induction. 

 

Option C. Ethionamide: A second-line drug; structurally similar to INH; causes GI upset and hepatotoxicity. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with markedly abnormal liver function, the safest anti-tuberculosis regimen includes non-hepatotoxic drugs such as streptomycin and ethambutol. 
  • Avoid isoniazid, rifampicin, and pyrazinamide until liver function improves.

choices.text: Parathormone increases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)
Parathormone decreases calcium reabsorption in the PCT
Calcitriol increases phosphate reabsorption in the PCT
Calcitriol decreases phosphate absorption in the intestine

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a history of chronic vitamin D deficiency is started on calcitriol supplementation. Which of the following best explains the renal action of calcitriol on phosphate handling?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcitriol increases phosphate reabsorption in the PCT

 

  • Calcitriol (active vitamin D3) enhances both calcium and phosphate absorption. 
  • In the kidney, it stimulates phosphate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule and increases calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. 
  • This contributes to maintaining adequate mineralization of bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parathormone increases phosphate reabsorption in proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): Incorrect. PTH actually decreases phosphate reabsorption in the PCT, leading to phosphaturia, which prevents ectopic calcification.

 

Option B. Parathormone increases calcium reabsorption in PCT: Incorrect. PTH increases calcium reabsorption mainly in the distal convoluted tubule, not the PCT.

 

Option D. Calcitriol decreases phosphate absorption in the intestine: Incorrect. Calcitriol increases intestinal absorption of both calcium and phosphate, not decreases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calcitriol promotes phosphate reabsorption in the PCT and increases intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate. 
  • In contrast, PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption in the PCT but enhances calcium reabsorption in the DCT. 
  • Together, these hormones maintain calcium-phosphate homeostasis and bone mineralization.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea, deep dyspareunia, and 2 years of infertility. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a 4-cm endometrioma in the left ovary. She wishes to conceive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparoscopic cystectomy

 

  • In women with endometriomas ≥4 cm and infertility, the recommended management is laparoscopic cystectomy. 
  • Excision of the cyst wall improves pelvic anatomy, reduces pain, lowers recurrence risk, and enhances spontaneous conception rates compared with medical therapy or drainage alone. 
  • For patients who still do not conceive after surgery, assisted reproductive techniques (e.g., IVF) may be considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continuous oral contraceptive pills: Suppress ovulation and relieve pain but prevent pregnancy, making them unsuitable for a woman actively seeking fertility.

 

Option B. Total hysterectomy with oophorectomy: Definitive treatment for endometriosis but eliminates fertility altogether, so it is only used when childbearing is complete or symptoms are refractory.

 

Option D. GnRH analogs for 6 months: Induce a hypoestrogenic state, shrink lesions, and reduce symptoms, but inhibit ovulation during therapy. They are not appropriate for a patient who desires conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with ovarian endometriomas ≥4 cm and infertility, the best management is laparoscopic cystectomy, which improves both pain symptoms and fertility outcomes.

questions.text: A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with sudden onset severe back pain after bending forward to lift a light object. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and has been on long-term glucocorticoid therapy. On examination, she has localized tenderness over the lower thoracic spine and a noticeable decrease in height compared to her previous medical records. Her calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoporosis

 

  • A disease characterized by low bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue, leading to increased bone fragility and fracture risk. 
  • The bone mineral content is low, but the bone matrix is still normally mineralized.
  • Clinical Match:
  • Patient Profile: Postmenopausal woman (estrogen deficiency is a major risk factor) with a history of long-term glucocorticoid therapy (which accelerates bone loss by suppressing osteoblast activity and increasing osteoclast activity).
  • Presentation: Sudden, severe back pain after a low-energy mechanism (bending to lift a light object, often called a "fragility fracture").
  • Physical Exam: Localized tenderness over the spine and decreased height (consistent with an acute vertebral compression fracture).
  • Lab Findings: Normal calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels are the hallmark biochemical findings of uncomplicated osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteomalacia:

 

  • A condition characterized by defective mineralization of newly formed bone matrix (osteoid), usually due to severe and prolonged Vitamin D deficiency or phosphate wasting.
  • Patients usually have bone pain and muscle weakness. Lab findings are typically abnormal, showing low or low-normal serum calcium, low phosphate, and often a significantly elevated alkaline phosphatase (as osteoblasts try to produce more unmineralized osteoid). This contrasts with the patient's normal lab values.

 

Option C. Multiple Myeloma:

 

  • A cancer of plasma cells that accumulates in the bone marrow, leading to widespread destruction of bone via osteolytic lesions.
  • While it causes VCFs and severe bone pain, it is associated with specific findings such as anemia, renal failure, and often hypercalcemia (high calcium) due to lytic bone destruction. 
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by finding a monoclonal paraprotein (M-spike) in the serum/urine. The patient's presentation is more common for primary osteoporosis, and her basic labs are normal.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism:

 

  • Excess production of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which leads to excessive bone resorption to raise serum calcium. 
  • Severe, long-standing cases can cause osteitis fibrosa cystica (a specific pattern of bone loss).
  • The key laboratory finding is hypercalcemia (high calcium) and usually a low serum phosphate. 
  • The patient's calcium and phosphate levels are specifically noted as normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to connect the low-energy VCF in a high-risk patient with normal serum chemistry to the diagnosis of Osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with hoarseness of voice for the past three months. Laryngoscopy reveals the image shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal cord polyp

 

  • The image shows a unilateral swelling at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, which is characteristic of a vocal cord polyp.
  • Vocal cord polyps are typically unilateral, large, and sessile or pedunculated lesions that arise due to phonotrauma (e.g., excessive vocal strain).
  • They are associated with hoarseness of voice due to impaired vibration of the affected vocal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord nodule: Vocal cord nodules are typically bilateral and symmetric, located at the same junction as polyps. They are smaller and appear more like callous-like formations.

 

Option C. Reinke's edema: Reinke's edema involves bilateral, diffuse swelling of the vocal cords with a polypoidal appearance. It is commonly associated with smoking and low-pitched hoarseness, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Vocal cord cyst: A vocal cord cyst appears as a submucosal lesion within the vocal cord, typically white or translucent, with a smooth surface. It does not appear as the unilateral protrusion seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A vocal cord polyp is a unilateral lesion at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, commonly caused by phonotrauma and presenting with hoarseness of voice.

choices.text: Alpha-1 antagonism causing increased diastolic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following accurately reflects the hemodynamic effect of fenoldopam?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) D1-mediated arterial vasodilation decreasing afterload

 

  • Fenoldopam is a selective dopamine D1 receptor agonist that causes arteriolar vasodilation, particularly in the renal, mesenteric, and coronary circulation. 
  • This vasodilatory effect reduces systemic vascular resistance (afterload) and improves renal perfusion. It is often used in hypertensive emergencies, especially when renal protection is a therapeutic goal.
  • Unlike some vasodilators, fenoldopam has no significant venodilator activity and does not interact with alpha or beta receptors, making its mechanism specific and predictable.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Direct venoconstriction increasing preload: Incorrect. Fenoldopam does not cause venoconstriction; it has no significant effect on preload.

 

Option C. D2-receptor inhibition causing coronary vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Fenoldopam is selective for D1 receptors and does not affect D2. It actually promotes coronary vasodilation, not vasoconstriction.

 

Option D. Alpha-1 antagonism causing increased diastolic pressure: Incorrect. Fenoldopam has no alpha-1 antagonism. Alpha-1 blockade would typically lower, not increase, diastolic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fenoldopam reduces afterload via D1 receptor–mediated arteriolar vasodilation, improving renal perfusion and promoting natriuresis—making it useful in hypertensive emergencies, particularly with renal compromise.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statement regarding acute pancreatitis. 

 

  1. Serum amylase and lipase levels are useful for diagnosis but not for assessing severity.
  2. An elevated hematocrit (>44%) is associated with poor outcomes
  3. A rising BUN (>22 mg/dL) after fluid resuscitation indicates poor prognosis.
  4. The most common aetiology is binge drinking
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3 are true

 

Statement 1. Serum amylase and lipase are useful for diagnosis but not for assessing severity: This is correct. These enzymes help confirm the diagnosis but provide no prognostic value in determining whether the pancreatitis is mild, moderate, or severe.

 

Statement 2. An elevated hematocrit (>44%) is associated with poor outcomes: This is correct. A high or rising hematocrit suggests intravascular volume depletion and predicts an increased risk of pancreatic necrosis and systemic complications.

 

Statement 3. A rising BUN (>22 mg/dL) after fluid resuscitation indicates poor prognosis: This is correct. An elevated or increasing BUN reflects ongoing hypovolemia and renal hypoperfusion, both of which are associated with increased mortality in acute pancreatitis.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. The most common aetiology is binge drinking: Incorrect. The most common etiology is Biliary, no binge drinking. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute pancreatitis, serum amylase and lipase confirm diagnosis but do not predict severity; instead, hematocrit and BUN trends are valuable markers for assessing disease severity and guiding fluid resuscitation.

choices.text: Medical examination requested by a police officer of an arrested accused
A patient refusing treatment for a life-threatening condition
A patient undergoing a cosmetic procedure
A patient undergoing an experimental drug trial

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to the requirement for informed consent under the Doctrine of Informed Consent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medical examination requested by a police officer of an arrested accused

 

  • Under the Indian Penal Code, medical examination of an arrested accused can be performed without consent under Section 53 BNSS. 
  • This is a legal exception to the informed consent requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A patient refusing treatment for a life-threatening condition: This is not an exception. A patient’s refusal to consent to treatment must be respected, even in life-threatening situations unless the patient is incapacitated.

 

Option C. A patient undergoing a cosmetic procedure: Informed consent is always required for elective procedures, including cosmetic surgeries.

 

Option D. A patient undergoing an experimental drug trial: Informed consent is always required in experimental drug trials to ensure the patient understands the risks, benefits, and alternatives.

 

Educational Objective:


Exceptions to the requirement for informed consent include situations like emergencies, court-ordered examinations, and legal situations (e.g., medical examinations of arrested persons).

choices.text: A 40-year-old with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures
A 57-year-old with stable coronary artery disease on dual antiplatelet therapy
A 28-year-old with major depressive disorder controlled on sertraline
A 70-year-old male with mild cognitive impairment

questions.text: Which of the following patient profiles would raise the most concern for potential complications with varenicline, warranting a consideration of alternative therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A 28-year-old with major depressive disorder controlled on sertraline

 

  • Varenicline (brand name: Chantix) is a partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors used for smoking cessation.
  • While it is effective, it has been associated with neuropsychiatric adverse effects, particularly in patients with preexisting psychiatric illnesses such as depression, anxiety, or suicidal tendencies.
  • Therefore, a patient with major depressive disorder, even if currently controlled, is at increased risk of mood destabilization, agitation, or suicidal ideation after starting varenicline — making this the profile of greatest concern.
  • Varenicline is not strongly associated with seizures; risk is mainly with bupropion, another smoking cessation aid. Hence, this is not a major concern. 

 

Mechanism of concern:

 

  • Varenicline acts as a partial agonist → reduces nicotine cravings but still activates dopaminergic reward pathways.
  • This dopaminergic modulation can precipitate mood changes, depression, and suicidal ideation, especially in those with underlying psychiatric disorders.
  • FDA once issued a boxed warning (later removed after newer studies), but caution is still advised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 40-year-old with generalized tonic-clonic seizures: Varenicline is not strongly associated with seizures; risk is mainly with bupropion, another smoking cessation aid. Hence, this is not a major concern.

 

Option B. A 57-year-old with stable coronary artery disease on dual antiplatelet therapy: Earlier concerns about cardiovascular events were not strongly supported by later evidence. Varenicline can be safely used in stable CAD. 

 

Option D. A 70-year-old male with mild cognitive impairment: No significant contraindication. Cognitive effects are mild and uncommon. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Varenicline is a first-line smoking cessation agent that may cause neuropsychiatric adverse effects, especially in individuals with a personal or family history of depression or other mood disorders. 
  • Patients with such histories require close monitoring, and in some cases, alternative therapies (like nicotine replacement or bupropion) may be preferred.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis is started on low-dose methotrexate. Routine baseline investigations are ordered before initiating treatment. Which of the following is not routinely monitored during methotrexate therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ophthalmologic examination

 

  • Methotrexate requires routine monitoring of certain organ systems due to its dose-dependent toxicity, especially during long-term therapy for autoimmune conditions. 
  • Ophthalmologic exams are not routinely required for methotrexate, unlike hydroxychloroquine, which can cause retinal toxicity and mandates regular eye screening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver function tests (LFTs): Methotrexate is hepatotoxic, especially with chronic use, so LFTs are regularly assessed.

 

Option B. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs): Though not done in every case, baseline and follow-up PFTs are considered when there's concern for methotrexate-induced pneumonitis or fibrosis.

 

Option D. Complete blood count (CBC): Bone marrow suppression is a known adverse effect; hence, CBC is monitored routinely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients on methotrexate, regularly monitor LFTs, CBC, and pulmonary function when indicated. 
  • Ophthalmologic exams are not required, distinguishing it from drugs like hydroxychloroquine.

questions.text: A 36-year-old pre-menopausal woman is diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. She undergoes a core needle biopsy, and immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining is performed. The report shows the estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2-neu are all negative. Which of the following best describes the prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Poor prognosis

 

  • The immunohistochemistry details provided reveal that the tumor is triple negative—i.e., it lacks expression of estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2-neu. 
  • This subtype is referred to as Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC).
  • TNBC is more common in BRCA + women.
  • It is more aggressive with higher rates of recurrence and shorter disease-free intervals.
  • Lacks targeted therapy options like hormonal therapy (e.g., tamoxifen) or HER2-targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab).
  • While it may initially respond well to chemotherapy, long-term prognosis is generally poorer compared to receptor-positive cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Good prognosis: Incorrect. TNBC is associated with worse prognosis due to aggressive nature and lack of targeted therapies.

 

Option C. Good outcome with trastuzumab: Incorrect. Trastuzumab is only effective in HER2-positive cancers, but this case is HER2-negative.

 

Option D. Good outcome without trastuzumab: Incorrect. While some TNBCs may be chemosensitive, they still carry a worse long-term prognosis, and lack of HER2 overexpression makes trastuzumab ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC), characterized by the absence of ER, PR, and HER2 expression on immunohistochemistry, is associated with a poor prognosis due to its aggressive nature, lack of response to targeted hormonal or HER2-directed therapy, and higher recurrence risk despite chemosensitivity.

questions.text: In the context of anesthetic agents, what is a notable property of Xenon that differentiates it from many other agents?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low blood-gas partition coefficient 

 

  • Xenon has a low blood-gas solubility coefficient, which contributes to rapid induction and recovery from anesthesia, making it a suitable agent for outpatient procedures where quick turnaround is desired.
  • Xenon is non-explosive, making it safer to use in the operating room environment compared to some other anesthetic gases.
  • It is not associated with cardiotoxic effects. In fact, Xenon has minimal hemodynamic effects and is often considered cardioprotective because it does not depress myocardial function.
  • Xenon is considered organ-protective, especially for the liver and kidneys. It doesn’t undergo hepatic metabolism, making it ideal for patients with liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Xenon is a noble gas used as an anesthetic agent that is characterized by its low blood solubility, leading to rapid induction and recovery, non-explosive nature, and minimal cardiotoxicity.

questions.text:
A patient with multidrug-resistant Klebsiella shows susceptibility to polymyxins. Which of the following statements regarding membrane-targeting antibiotics is/are correct?

 

  1. Polymyxin B acts by disrupting the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria.
  2. Colistin is preferred drug for treatment of NDM (New Delhi metallo beta lactamase) producing Klebsiella.
  3. Daptomycin is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and is not used for pneumonia.
  4. All membrane-active drugs inhibit the synthesis of lipopolysaccharides.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 1, 2 and 3 are correct

 

Statement 1. Polymyxin B acts by disrupting the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria: Correct.

 

  • Mechanism: Polymyxins (B and E/colistin) are cationic detergents.
  • They bind to Lipid A portion of lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria.
  • This displaces calcium and magnesium ions → disrupts membrane integrity → leakage of intracellular contents → bacterial death.
  • Active only against gram-negative bacteria (no effect on gram-positive).

 

Statement 2. Colistin is the preferred drug for treatment of NDM (New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase) producing Klebsiella. Correct. 

 

  • NDM-producing organisms are carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE), often resistant to almost all β-lactams and many other antibiotics.
  • Polymyxins (especially colistin / polymyxin E) are considered last-resort drugs for such multidrug-resistant gram-negative infections, including NDM-producing Klebsiella.

 

Statement 3. Daptomycin is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and is not used for pneumonia. Correct.

 

  • Mechanism: Daptomycin (a cyclic lipopeptide) binds to bacterial membranes and causes rapid depolarization → inhibition of DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis → cell death.
  • Inactivated by lung surfactant, hence ineffective in pneumonia, but useful in bacteremia, endocarditis, skin/soft tissue infections due to MRSA or VRE.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 4. All membrane-active drugs inhibit the synthesis of lipopolysaccharides: Incorrect.

 

  • Polymyxins bind to and disrupt existing membranes; they do not inhibit LPS synthesis.
  • Daptomycin also acts on the cytoplasmic membrane, not LPS synthesis.
  • Thus, membrane-active drugs disrupt membrane function, not inhibit membrane synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membrane-targeting antibiotics such as polymyxins (B, E/colistin) disrupt bacterial membranes and are effective against multidrug-resistant gram-negative infections. 
  • Colistin’s nephrotoxicity and daptomycin’s inactivation by lung surfactant limit their clinical utility in certain infections like pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old HIV-positive man presents with several painless, purple-colored nodular lesions on his hard palate, as shown. Which of the following statements are true?

 

 

  1. The lesion represents a vascular tumor composed of spindle cells
  2. The most likely diagnosis is oral hairy leukoplakia
  3. The causative virus is associated with B-cell lymphomas
  4. The lesion is commonly seen in patients with CD4 <200/μL
  5. The tumor arises due to chronic inflammation and angiogenesis
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4 and 5

 

Statement 1. The lesion represents a vascular tumor composed of spindle cells: True. Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular tumor with spindle cells and blood-filled spaces.

 

Statement 3. The causative virus is associated with B-cell lymphomas: True. HHV-8 is linked to B-cell lymphomas like effusion lymphoma.

 

Statement 4. The lesion is commonly seen in patients with CD4 <200/μL: True. Lesions typically develop with advanced immunosuppression (CD4 <200).

 

Statement 5. The tumor arises due to chronic inflammation and angiogenesis: True. Tumor progression involves cytokine-mediated angiogenesis.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. The most likely diagnosis is oral hairy leukoplakia: False. Oral hairy leukoplakia appears as white corrugated plaques, not purple nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma is an angioproliferative tumor seen in AIDS patients, driven by HHV-8, and commonly affects mucosa, skin, and viscera.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer is started on targeted anticancer therapy. Six weeks later, she develops progressive fatigue, cold intolerance, and weight gain. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated TSH (28 µIU/mL) with low free T4, consistent with autoimmune thyroiditis–induced hypothyroidism. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pembrolizumab

 

  • This patient with metastatic NSCLC develops autoimmune thyroiditis leading to hypothyroidism after 6 weeks of therapy.
  • That time course and autoimmune pattern are classic for immune checkpoint inhibitors — particularly PD-1 inhibitors such as pembrolizumab. 

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 (Programmed Death-1 receptor) on T-cells.
  • By blocking PD-1, it enhances T-cell activation and immune response against tumor cells.
  • However, this also removes self-tolerance, leading to immune-related adverse events such as:
    • Autoimmune thyroiditis (→ hypothyroidism)
    • Hypophysitis
    • Pneumonitis
    • Colitis
    • Hepatitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erlotinib: EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor; adverse effects include rash and diarrhea, but not autoimmune thyroiditis. 

 

Option B. Cetuximab: EGFR monoclonal antibody; causes skin rash and hypomagnesemia, no autoimmune effects. 

 

Option D. Cisplatin: Cytotoxic drug; main toxicities are nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, and neurotoxicity, not thyroiditis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PD-1 inhibitors such as pembrolizumab are associated with immune-mediated endocrinopathies, especially hypothyroidism due to autoimmune thyroiditis.
  • Monitoring thyroid function is essential during treatment. This also causes immune-mediated colitis, pneumonitis.

questions.text:
In high-risk groups such as pregnant women, young children, and HIV patients, certain antitubercular drugs are contraindicated. Which of the following drug–contraindication pairs are correct? 

 

  1. Streptomycin – Contraindicated in pregnancy
  2. Ethambutol – Contraindicated in children <6 years
  3. Rifampicin – Contraindicated in AIDS patients on protease inhibitors
  4. Thiacetazone – Contraindicated in HIV patients due to risk of exfoliative dermatitis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) All 4 are correct

 

  • Statement 1. Streptomycin – Contraindicated in pregnancy: Correct. Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside that can cause fetal ototoxicity and vestibular damage.

 

  • Statement 2. Ethambutol – Contraindicated in children <6 years: Correct. Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis (red–green blindness), which cannot be reliably monitored in young children.

 

  • Statement 3. Rifampicin – Contraindicated in AIDS patients on protease inhibitors: Correct. Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome P450, reducing protease inhibitor concentrations and leading to HIV treatment failure.

 

  • Statement 4. Thiacetazone – Contraindicated in HIV patients: Correct. In HIV-positive patients, it can cause severe exfoliative dermatitis with high mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important Facts of Antitubercular Drugs:

 

  • The most effective anti-tubercular drug is Rifampicin.
  • The most bactericidal anti-tubercular drug is Rifampicin.
  • The most toxic anti-tubercular drug is Isoniazid.
  • The drug causing rapid sputum conversion is Rifampicin.
  • The drug causing orange discoloration of urine and body fluids is Rifampicin.
  • The first anti-TB drug to develop resistance is Isoniazid.
  • The drug contraindicated in AIDS patients on protease inhibitors is Rifampicin.
  • The drug contraindicated in HIV patients due to exfoliative dermatitis is Thiacetazone.
  • The drugs included in all phases of DOTS therapy are Rifampicin and Isoniazid.
  • The injectable first-line antitubercular drug is Streptomycin.
  • The anti-TB drug contraindicated in pregnancy is Streptomycin.
  • The anti-TB drug contraindicated in children <6 years is Ethambutol.
  • The drug causing optic neuritis with red–green color blindness is Ethambutol.
  • The drug causing vestibular damage is Streptomycin.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) comes for follow-up. Vitals and labs: BP 130/80 mmHg, height 182 cm, weight 85 kg (BMI 25 kg/m²), serum glucose 95 mg/dL, serum lipid concentrations within the normal range. Plasma testing shows an elevated homocysteine concentration of 19.3 μmol/L (N = 5–15). Which enzyme deficiency is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystathionine β-synthase

 

  • This 62-year-old male with CAD and hyperhomocysteinemia (homocysteine 19.3 μmol/L, normal 5–15) despite normal serum lipid concentrations, serum glucose 95 mg/dL, and BMI 25 kg/m² most likely has reduced activity/deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) in the transsulfuration pathway.
  • CBS converts homocysteine + serine → cystathionine, requiring vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate).
  • Deficiency (or B6 lack) causes accumulation of homocysteine, a recognized, independent risk factor for atherothrombotic disease (consistent with this patient’s coronary artery disease).
  • All other details provided—blood pressure 130/80 mmHg, height 182 cm, weight 85 kg, BMI 25 kg/m²—do not explain the elevated homocysteine concentration and serve to show that conventional risk markers are controlled, highlighting the metabolic etiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency causes phenylketonuria with elevated phenylalanine, neurocognitive impairment, and hypopigmentation. It does not cause isolated homocysteine elevation and is unrelated to CAD risk in this context.

 

Option C. Homogentisate oxidase: Deficiency results in alkaptonuria (ochronosis, dark urine, arthropathy). It is not associated with hyperhomocysteinemia (19.3 μmol/L) and does not address the patient’s serum lipid concentrations within the normal range or glucose 95 mg/dL.

 

Option D. Cystathionine γ-synthase: Not a human enzyme of the homocysteine pathway (plants/bacteria). Human downstream enzyme is cystathionine γ-lyase; deficiency there yields different patterns. This choice does not explain the elevated homocysteine concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperhomocysteinemia (e.g., 19.3 μmol/L; normal 5–15) with otherwise normal metabolic labs in an adult—especially one with CAD—is most classically linked to deficiency of the transsulfuration enzyme cystathionine β-synthase (B6-dependent).

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for acute leukemia develops fever, cough, and hypoxia. Chest imaging reveals new bilateral infiltrates, and bronchoalveolar lavage cultures grow Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. Which of the following antibiotics are considered appropriate treatment options for this organism?

 

  1. Azithromycin
  2. Aminoglycosides
  3. Co-trimoxazole (Trimethoprim–Sulfamethoxazole)
  4. Levofloxacin
  5. Ticarcillin–Clavulanate
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 and 4 only

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia affects individuals who are immunocompromised or have a history of prolonged hospitalization.
  • It is resistant to many antibiotics except:

 

Option 3. Co-trimoxazole: Correct. This is the first-line agent for S. maltophilia. It has reliable in-vitro and clinical efficacy.

 

Option 4. Levofloxacin: Correct. Fluoroquinolones like levofloxacin are considered effective alternatives, especially in patients with sulfa allergies or resistance.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option 1. Azithromycin: Incorrect. S. maltophilia is intrinsically resistant to macrolides like azithromycin.

 

Option 2. Aminoglycosides: Incorrect. Resistance is common due to efflux pumps and modifying enzymes. These agents are not effective.

 

Option 5. Ticarcillin–Clavulanate: Incorrect. It was historically used but is now largely ineffective due to widespread resistance.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Co-trimoxazole is the treatment of choice for Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. Levofloxacin is a reasonable alternative. 
  • This organism is intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, macrolides, and many beta-lactams.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with recent chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia presents with persistent fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotics. A (1,3)-β-D-glucan test is ordered to aid in identifying a possible fungal etiology. The result returns positive. Which of the following fungal infections is this diagnostic test most useful for detecting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Disseminated candidiasis

 

  • The (1,3)-β-D-glucan assay is a non-culture-based diagnostic test that detects (1,3)-β-D-glucan, a major cell wall component of many fungi, including:
    • Candida spp.
    • Aspergillus spp.
    • Fusarium spp.
    • Pneumocystis jirovecii
  • It is widely used to screen for invasive fungal infections, particularly in neutropenic or immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary mucormycosis: Mucorales fungi (e.g., Rhizopus, Mucor) lack significant β-D-glucan in their cell walls, so this test is typically negative.

 

Option C. Cryptococcal central nervous system infection: Cryptococcus neoformans has a thick polysaccharide capsule primarily composed of glucuronoxylomannan, and produces low levels of β-D-glucan. Cryptococcal antigen test is preferred.

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, which is not a true fungus, but rather a protist in the class Mesomycetozoea, and does not contain β-D-glucan.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

The (1,3)-β-D-glucan test is a pan-fungal assay useful for detecting invasive fungal infections such as candidiasis and aspergillosis, but it is not reliable for diagnosing mucormycosis, cryptococcosis, or rhinosporidiosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with recurrent springtime episodes of a red, scaly rash on sun-exposed areas such as the face, neck, and hands. He also experiences intermittent irritability, confusion, and difficulty with coordination. His diet includes adequate protein and vitamin intake. Laboratory studies show increased urinary excretion of neutral amino acids, but serotonin levels, 5-HIAA excretion, and urinary indole compounds are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hartnup disease

 

  • Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective transport of neutral amino acids (such as tryptophan) in the kidney and intestine.
  • This results in decreased tryptophan availability for niacin synthesis, predisposing to pellagra-like symptoms (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, photosensitive rash).
  • The clinical picture described — sun-exposed dermatitis, neuropsychiatric symptoms (confusion, irritability, ataxia), and increased urinary excretion of neutral amino acids with normal serotonin/indole metabolism — is highly characteristic of Hartnup disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B6 deficiency:

 

  • Vitamin B6 deficiency impairs transamination and decarboxylation of amino acids and reduces neurotransmitter synthesis.
  • It may cause irritability, seizures, and peripheral neuropathy but does not cause increased neutral amino acid excretion in urine.
  • There is xanthurenic aciduria due to Vitamin B6 deficiency.

 

Option B. Maple syrup urine disease:

 

  • Results from a defect in branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase.
  • Causes accumulation of leucine, isoleucine, and valine, leading to poor feeding, vomiting, seizures, and the classic "maple syrup" odor in urine.
  • It does not present with pellagra-like dermatitis and the labs here do not indicate branched-chain amino acid accumulation.

 

Option C. Phenylketonuria (PKU):

 

  • Caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, leading to elevated phenylalanine and low tyrosine.
  • Presents with intellectual disability, seizures, hypopigmentation, and musty odor.
  • The patient in this case has normal serotonin and indole metabolism and a clear description of neutral aminoaciduria, which rules out PKU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hartnup disease is characterized by defective transport of neutral amino acids in the intestine and kidney, leading to tryptophan deficiency, reduced niacin synthesis, and pellagra-like symptoms.

choices.text: PaCO₂ normal, PaO₂ normal, pH decreases, PvCO₂ high, PvO₂ low
PaCO₂ low, PaO₂ normal, pH decreases, PvCO₂ high, PvO₂ low
PaCO₂ high, PaO₂ low, pH increases, PvCO₂ high, PvO₂ low
PaCO₂ low, PaO₂ low, pH normal, PvCO₂ high, PvO₂ low

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoes a cardiopulmonary exercise test while running on a treadmill at near-maximal effort. She develops rapid breathing, muscle fatigue, and mild metabolic acidosis due to lactic acid accumulation. Arterial blood sampling and venous blood gases are analyzed. Which of the following findings is most consistent with her physiological state at peak exertion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PaCO₂ low, PaO₂ normal, pH decreases, PvCO₂ high, PvO₂ low

 

  • PaCO₂ low: Hyperventilation during heavy exercise causes excess CO₂ elimination.
  • PaO₂ normal: Despite increased oxygen use, arterial oxygenation remains adequate due to efficient pulmonary gas exchange.
  • pH decreases: Anaerobic glycolysis produces lactic acid, causing metabolic acidosis.
  • PvCO₂ high: Venous blood from active muscles carries increased CO₂ due to high metabolic activity.
  • PvO₂ low: Tissues extract more oxygen during exercise, lowering venous O₂ content.

 

Educational Objective:


At peak exercise, hyperventilation lowers PaCO₂, tissue oxygen extraction lowers PvO₂, venous CO₂ rises, and metabolic acidosis lowers pH — while arterial oxygenation is preserved.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections, including pneumonia and otitis media. His complete blood count shows normal white blood cell count and differential. Because of the frequent infections, further evaluation of neutrophil function is performed. Cytochemical staining of leukocytes demonstrates markedly reduced myeloperoxidase enzyme activity. Which of the following best explains his increased susceptibility to infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure to produce hydroxy-halide radicals (HOCl⁻)

 

  • Leukocytes, particularly neutrophils, are the frontline defense against bacterial pathogens. 
  • In suspected immunodeficiency with recurrent infections, evaluation often extends beyond counts to functional assays of leukocytes. 
  • Myeloperoxidase (MPO), an enzyme stored in azurophilic granules of neutrophils and monocytes, catalyzes the formation of hypochlorous acid (HOCl⁻) from hydrogen peroxide and chloride ions.
  • In this child, cytochemical testing reveals markedly reduced MPO activity. This means that although the respiratory burst (superoxide and hydrogen peroxide generation via NADPH oxidase) is intact, the neutrophils cannot generate hypochlorous acid. 
  • Without this final oxidative product, microbicidal killing is impaired, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections such as pneumonia and otitis media.
  • Thus, the most likely cause is failure to produce hydroxy-halide radicals (HOCl⁻).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defective neutrophil degranulation: Seen in Chediak–Higashi syndrome, due to lysosomal trafficking defects. Here, granules fail to release enzymes, leading to recurrent infections and albinism. In MPO deficiency, granules release normally; only HOCl⁻ formation is impaired.

 

Option B. Decreased oxygen consumption after phagocytosis: A feature of chronic granulomatous disease, where NADPH oxidase is defective. In MPO deficiency, oxygen consumption is normal, as superoxide and H₂O₂ production remain intact.

 

Option D. Failure to produce hydrogen peroxide: Also seen in chronic granulomatous disease, because NADPH oxidase cannot generate H₂O₂. MPO-deficient neutrophils produce hydrogen peroxide normally but cannot use it to form hypochlorous acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In myeloperoxidase deficiency, leukocytes produce hydrogen peroxide normally but cannot generate hypochlorous acid (HOCl⁻), impairing microbial killing and predisposing to recurrent bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath on exertion. Routine laboratory testing shows elevated liver enzymes. A liver biopsy is performed, and periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) staining reveals cytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the underlying cause of this patient’s pulmonary symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inter-alveolar septa destruction

 

  • This 30-year-old man with progressive exertional dyspnea and elevated liver enzymes has biopsy findings consistent with alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. 
  • The PAS-positive, diastase-resistant inclusions in hepatocytes represent misfolded AAT protein retained in the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • In the lungs, the absence of functional alpha-1 antitrypsin (an elastase inhibitor) permits unchecked neutrophil elastase activity, resulting in destruction of inter-alveolar septa. 
  • This leads to panacinar emphysema, most prominent in the lung bases, and manifests clinically as progressive exertional dyspnea.
  • Thus, the mechanism of dyspnea is inter-alveolar septa destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial infiltration: Seen in interstitial lung diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, sarcoidosis, and hypersensitivity pneumonitis. These present with restrictive physiology, not emphysema due to inter-alveolar septa destruction.

 

Option B. Bronchial hyper-reactivity: Characteristic of asthma, leading to episodic reversible airway obstruction, wheezing, and cough. This mechanism does not involve PAS-positive hepatocyte inclusions or liver involvement.

 

Option D. Intra-alveolar substance accumulation: Seen in conditions like pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, where surfactant-like material fills alveoli. This does not explain the liver biopsy findings or the emphysema mechanism of AAT deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency causes lung disease due to unchecked neutrophil elastase activity, resulting in inter-alveolar septa destruction and panacinar emphysema, while PAS-positive, diastase-resistant inclusions accumulate in hepatocytes.

choices.text: ASV is most effective for pit viper bites, as neutralizing antibodies develop quickly
The polyvalent ASV in India targets neurotoxic snakes only
