The first dose for both neurotoxic and vasculotoxic snake bites in India is administration of 10 vials of ASV
ASV should be given only when 20-minute WBCT is abnormal

questions.text: Regarding ASV (Anti-Snake Venom) administration in India, which of the following statements is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The first dose for both neurotoxic and vasculotoxic snake bites in India is administration of 10 vials of ASV

 

  • In India, the standard initial dose of polyvalent Anti-Snake Venom (ASV) for both neurotoxic (e.g., cobra, krait) and vasculotoxic (e.g., Russell’s viper, saw-scaled viper) envenomation is 10 vials, administered intravenously over one hour.
  • This standardization simplifies early management in resource-limited settings.
  • The Indian polyvalent ASV is effective against the “Big Four” snakes: cobra, krait, Russell’s viper, and saw-scaled viper — covering both neurotoxic and hemotoxic species.
  • The 20-minute Whole Blood Clotting Test (WBCT) is a screening tool for vasculotoxic bites, but ASV should not be delayed in the presence of neurotoxic symptoms such as ptosis or respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASV is most effective for pit viper bites, as neutralizing antibodies develop quickly: Incorrect. ASV is least effective for pit viper (Crotalidae) bites due to antigenic variation and weak cross-reactivity. It may be partially beneficial but is not the most effective.

 

Option B. The polyvalent ASV in India targets neurotoxic snakes only: Incorrect. The Indian polyvalent ASV targets both neurotoxic (cobra, krait) and vasculotoxic (Russell’s viper, saw-scaled viper) snakes. It is not limited to neurotoxins.

 

Option D. ASV should be given only when 20-minute WBCT is abnormal: Incorrect. ASV is administered in cases of suspected neurotoxic envenomation (e.g., krait, cobra) even if 20-min WBCT is normal. Clotting tests primarily help diagnose vasculotoxic snake bites like viper.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASV in India is polyvalent, covering all 4 medically significant snakes. In krait bites (neurotoxic, minimal local signs), clinical suspicion justifies ASV administration, regardless of clotting results. 10 vials of ASV neutralize the fatal dose (6 mg) of krait venom.

questions.text: A 72-year-old obese man presents with a 2-year history of progressive stiffness and mild, non-radiating pain in his mid-back that is worse in the mornings. He reports a limited range of motion when trying to bend or turn his torso. He has a medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical and radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis

 

  • Patient is a 72-year-old obese man with Type 2 Diabetes. 
  • DISH is common in older, male patients and is strongly associated with metabolic syndrome (obesity, diabetes, hypertension). 
  • Symptoms are often mild stiffness and pain.
  • The description of a "thick, undulating, 'flowing' ossification" along the anterolateral spine that spans multiple contiguous vertebral levels (T5-T10 is six levels) is the hallmark finding. 
  • Crucially, the intervertebral disc spaces are preserved, and there is no fusion of the facet or sacroiliac joints. 
  • This combination meets the diagnostic criteria for DISH (also known as Forestier disease).

 

Note:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis:

 

  • AS typically affects younger individuals (≤40 years old, predominantly male) with inflammatory back pain (worse at night, improves with exercise).
  • AS is characterized by slender, vertical syndesmophytes (thinner and less bulky than DISH ossification) and, most importantly, evidence of sacroiliitis (erosion and fusion of the sacroiliac joints) and facet joint fusion, findings that are explicitly absent in classic DISH.

 

Option B. Spondylosis Deformans:

 

  • Common in older adults, but back pain is often mechanical (worse with activity, better with rest).
  • This condition is characterized by osteophytes that arise from the vertebral endplates, and most significantly, by narrowing and degeneration of the intervertebral disc spaces. 
  • In contrast, DISH shows ossification anterior to the disc and requires preserved disc spaces for diagnosis. 
  • The osteophytes in spondylosis rarely form the robust, continuous, flowing bridge seen in DISH.

 

Option D. Spinal Metastases:

 

  • Metastatic disease typically causes severe, progressive, unremitting pain that is often worse at rest or at night. 
  • The pain history here is "mild, non-radiating" and 2 years long, which is inconsistent with cancer.
  • Metastases typically cause lytic (bone destruction) or blastic (uncontrolled bone formation) lesions that destroy the vertebral body, often resulting in a pathological fracture. 
  • They do not produce the smooth, thick, flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament seen in DISH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Distinguish DISH by the convergence of:

 

  • Patient Demographics: Older male with co-morbidities (DM/Obesity).
  • Spinal X-ray Triad:
    • Flowing, thick ossification of the anterolateral spine (at least four levels).
    • Preservation of disc height.
    • Absence of sacroiliac or facet joint fusion.

questions.text: From the given pressure–volume loop of the left ventricle, calculate the ejection fraction (EF):
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 66%

 

  • From the pressure–volume loop:
    • End-Diastolic Volume (EDV) = ~150 mL (point 1 on the x-axis, where filling ends)
    • End-Systolic Volume (ESV) = ~50 mL (point 2 on the x-axis, where ejection ends)
  • So:

SV = EDV - ESV = 150 - 50 = 100 mL

EF = SV/EDV = 100/150 = 66.7%

  • Thus, the ejection fraction is 66%, which falls in the normal range (55–70%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ejection fraction (EF) is the proportion of end-diastolic volume ejected with each heartbeat. 
  • It is calculated as: EF = {EDV - ESV}/ (EDV} 
  • Normal EF is 55–70%. 
  • A reduced EF indicates impaired systolic function (e.g., heart failure with reduced EF), while higher EF may occur in hyperdynamic states.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with progressive blurring and distortion of vision in both eyes for the past 2 years. He reports frequent changes in his glasses and increasing difficulty with night driving. There is no history of trauma or ocular surgery. On examination, best-corrected visual acuity is 6/18 in both eyes. He underwent the following treatment for his condition, as shown in the image. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Snowflake reflex 

 

  • The treatment shown in the image is C3R (Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking with Riboflavin), done for Keratoconus. 
  • Snowflake reflex refers to central, subcapsular, snowflake-like opacities seen in diabetic cataract, especially in young diabetics, not in keratoconus.
  • It is due to sorbitol accumulation in the lens fibers, leading to hydration and lens opacity.
  • It is not a feature of keratoconus (a corneal ectatic disorder).
  • Therefore, Snowflake reflex is not associated with the given condition (keratoconus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Munson’s sign: Correct. Bulging of the lower lid in downgaze due to conical cornea — seen in advanced keratoconus.

 

 

Option B. Vogt’s striae: Correct. Vertical fine stress lines in the deep stroma/Descemet’s membrane that disappear on pressure — typical of keratoconus.

 

 

Option D. Rizzuti sign: Correct. Sharp conical reflection on the nasal cornea when a light is shone from the temporal side — indicative of keratoconus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keratoconus is a progressive corneal ectasia characterized by thinning and conical protrusion of the cornea, leading to irregular astigmatism and visual distortion.
  • Typical signs include Munson’s sign, Vogt’s striae, and Rizzuti’s sign.
  • The Snowflake reflex is a feature of diabetic cataract, not keratoconus — helping distinguish corneal from lenticular pathology.

questions.text: In the diagram given below the solid line represents a normal individual, and the dotted line represents this patient. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary polydipsia

 

  • The graph shows reduced concentration of solute with increased volume in the dotted line compared to the solid line, which represents normal physiology. 
  • This is typical of primary polydipsia, a condition in which excessive water intake leads to dilutional polyuria. 
  • The kidneys excrete the excess free water, resulting in:
    • High urine volume
    • Low solute concentration (dilute urine)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute gastrointestinal hemorrhage: Incorrect. Acute blood loss reduces renal perfusion, leading to low urine output (oliguria) with higher concentration—not dilute urine.

 

Option B. Diabetes insipidus: Incorrect. Diabetes insipidus also causes high urine volume, but the urine remains dilute regardless of hydration status because of ADH deficiency/resistance. In primary polydipsia, dilution occurs because of water overload, not ADH dysfunction.

 

Option C. Hypertonic saline infusion: Incorrect. This would cause the kidneys to excrete a smaller volume of concentrated urine, the opposite pattern to what is shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In primary polydipsia, excessive water intake leads to dilutional hyponatremia with low solute concentration and high urine volume. 
  • Urine osmolality-volume graphs are a key diagnostic tool to differentiate between polydipsia, diabetes insipidus, and other causes of altered renal handling.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for weight gain. After consuming a carbohydrate-rich meal, her liver shows increased fatty acid synthesis. The rate-limiting enzyme of this pathway is activated by insulin through dephosphorylation and requires biotin as a cofactor. Which of the following best describes this enzyme and its product?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetyl-CoA carboxylase; malonyl-CoA 

 

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC) is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis.
  • Requires biotin (CO₂ carrier).
  • Activated by insulin and citrate (dephosphorylation).
  • Inhibited by glucagon, epinephrine, and palmitoyl-CoA.
  • Converts acetyl-CoA → malonyl-CoA, the 2-carbon donor for fatty acid elongation.
  • Malonyl-CoA also inhibits carnitine acyltransferase I (CPT I), preventing simultaneous FA oxidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fatty acid synthase; palmitate: Fatty acid synthase elongates the chain to produce palmitate (16:0) but is not the rate-limiting enzyme.

 

Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I; acyl-carnitine: This enzyme is in the mitochondria and regulates fatty acid oxidation, not synthesis. Inhibited by malonyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate carboxylase; oxaloacetate: This is the rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis, not fatty acid synthesis. It also requires biotin but functions in the mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis. 
  • It converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, requires biotin as a cofactor, and is activated by insulin via dephosphorylation.

choices.text: BCR-ABL1 transcript levels by quantitative PCR

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and WBC 200,000/µL. Peripheral smear shows myeloid precursors at all stages with eosinophilia. His cytogenetics reveal a balanced translocation between 2 chromosomes. Which laboratory marker is most specific for monitoring treatment response?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCR-ABL1 transcript levels by quantitative PCR

 

  • This 50-year-old man presents with splenomegaly, leukocytosis (WBC 200,000/µL), myeloid precursors at all stages, and eosinophilia. Cytogenetics reveal a balanced translocation, most likely the t(9;22) (q34; q11) Philadelphia chromosome, leading to formation of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.  
  • This is diagnostic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • The most specific laboratory marker for monitoring treatment response in CML is quantitative PCR measurement of BCR-ABL1 transcript levels.
  • This test detects minimal residual disease and is more sensitive than WBC counts, bone marrow examination, or LDH levels.
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib) target the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein, and response is assessed by the reduction in transcript burden.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. WBC count: Incorrect. Elevated WBC count is a nonspecific finding in CML and can also normalize with supportive treatment or other conditions. It does not accurately reflect molecular remission.

 

Option B. Bone marrow cellularity: Incorrect. Bone marrow findings (hypercellularity with granulocytic proliferation) help in diagnosis but are not reliable for tracking treatment response.

 

Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): Incorrect. LDH is a nonspecific marker of cell turnover and tissue breakdown. It is elevated in many hematologic and non-hematologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), the most specific marker for monitoring treatment response is quantitative PCR measurement of BCR-ABL1 transcript levels, which directly reflects disease activity at the molecular level.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man was admitted to the cath lab with an acute myocardial infarction. Following successful PCI, the following ECG was recorded. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute idioventricular rhythm

 

  • Accelerated idioventricular rhythm (AIVR) is a transient, wide-QRS ventricular rhythm with a rate between 40–100 bpm, usually appearing after successful reperfusion in acute myocardial infarction. 
  • It reflects enhanced automaticity of ventricular pacemaker cells due to sudden restoration of blood flow. 
  • The rhythm is typically regular, lacks preceding P waves, and often terminates spontaneously without hemodynamic compromise.

 

Key ECG features:

 

  • Regular wide-complex rhythm (QRS ≥120 ms)
  • Rate 40–100 bpm
  • No preceding P waves
  • May show fusion or capture beats
  • Occurs transiently post-PCI or after thrombolysis
  • AIVR is generally benign and does not require antiarrhythmic therapy unless it causes hemodynamic instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cabrera’s sign: A notch on the descending limb of the S wave in V3–V5, characteristic of left bundle branch block, not reperfusion rhythm.

 

Option C. Right bundle branch block: Shows ‘RSR′ pattern in V1 and broad terminal S wave in leads I and V6, not seen here.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Produces peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, and sine-wave pattern in severe cases, not the current rhythm pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Accelerated idioventricular rhythm is a reperfusion arrhythmia commonly seen after successful restoration of coronary flow in acute myocardial infarction. 
  • It is a benign, self-limiting ventricular rhythm that does not typically require treatment.

choices.text: Endometriosis ablation due to increased rate of endometriosis
To exclude Mullerian agenesis as a differential
Gonadectomy because of high risk of malignant transformation in retained gonads

questions.text: A 19-year-old female with primary amenorrhea undergoes evaluation, and genetic testing reveals a karyotype of 45X/46XY mosaicism. Imaging shows dysgenetic gonads. Which of the following is the most appropriate indication for performing laparoscopy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gonadectomy because of high risk of malignant transformation in retained gonads

 

  • Patients with 45X/46XY mosaicism (a form of gonadal dysgenesis) are at a markedly increased risk of malignant transformation within the dysgenetic gonads, particularly developing gonadoblastoma or dysgerminoma.
  • The presence of Y-chromosome material makes this risk clinically significant.
  • For this reason, laparoscopic gonadectomy is indicated as a preventive measure, even in the absence of symptoms, to eliminate the future risk of gonadal malignancy.
  • This is the primary and most appropriate reason for performing laparoscopy in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis ablation due to increased rate of endometriosis: Endometriosis is not associated with 45X/46XY mosaicism. Laparoscopy is not performed for this purpose in such patients.

 

Option B. To exclude Mullerian agenesis as a differential: Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) presents with absent uterus but normal 46,XX karyotype and functional ovaries. This is a separate diagnosis and not related to mosaicism. Hence, laparoscopy is not performed to rule this out in these patients.

 

Option D. Oophoropexy to prevent ovarian torsion: Oophoropexy is performed in women with normal ovaries at risk of torsion (e.g., elongated pedicle, recurrent torsion). In dysgenetic gonads with Y-chromosome mosaicism, torsion is not the concern—malignancy is. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with 45X/46XY gonadal dysgenesis, laparoscopy is indicated for prophylactic gonadectomy because dysgenetic gonads containing Y-chromosome material carry a high risk of malignant transformation (e.g., gonadoblastoma, dysgerminoma).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman in active labor is undergoing continuous intrapartum monitoring with cardiotocography (CTG). During the past hour, the tracing has shown repeated abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate of more than 15 beats per minute, each lasting about 30–60 seconds. Which of the following best explains the finding of these variable decelerations on CTG?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cord compression

 

  • On cardiotocography (CTG), variable decelerations are characterized by an abrupt onset and recovery, with a decrease in fetal heart rate ≥15 beats/min lasting ≥15 seconds but <2 minutes. 
  • Their timing and shape vary in relation to uterine contractions.
  • The most common cause of variable decelerations is umbilical cord compression. Compression of the cord temporarily impedes blood flow, causing fetal baroreceptor stimulation and a reflex deceleration of the heart rate. 
  • This explains why the changes are abrupt and vary from contraction to contraction, unlike early or late decelerations that have predictable timing.
  • Thus, the correct answer is cord compression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal hypoxia: Fetal hypoxia is more commonly associated with late decelerations on CTG, which are gradual decreases in fetal heart rate beginning after the start of a contraction and recovering after the contraction ends. While prolonged cord compression can eventually cause hypoxia, the direct mechanism of variable decelerations is cord compression, not hypoxia alone.

 

Option C. Head compression: Head compression usually causes early decelerations, which are gradual, uniform, and mirror uterine contractions. These are considered benign and reflect vagal stimulation from increased intracranial pressure. This does not match the description of variable decelerations.

 

Option D. Normal finding: Variable decelerations are not considered normal findings on CTG. While occasional brief decelerations may not be concerning, recurrent or pronounced variable decelerations usually signal cord compression and require monitoring and possible intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Variable decelerations on cardiotocography (CTG) are most commonly caused by umbilical cord compression, producing abrupt and inconsistent decreases in fetal heart rate.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with advanced HIV presents with new-onset seizures. CD4 count is 45/μL. MRI shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions. Serology is positive for Toxoplasma IgG. Which of the following statements regarding toxoplasma infection in immunocompromised patients are True?

 

  1. The patient is likely suffering from primary infection
  2. The most common manifestation in HIV is pulmonary toxoplasmosis
  3. Toxoplasmic encephalitis occurs when CD4 count is <100/μL
  4. PCR of CSF can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA
  5. The basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction are common sites of involvement
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 4 and 5

 

Statement 3. Toxoplasmic encephalitis occurs when CD4 count is <100/μL: True. Encephalitis due to Toxoplasma gondii generally arises when CD4 count <100/μL.

 

Statement 4. PCR of CSF can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA: True. CSF PCR can detect Toxoplasma DNA, especially in CNS involvement, and is useful in diagnosis when imaging and serology are inconclusive.

 

Statement 5. The basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction are common sites of involvement: True. Common sites on imaging include basal ganglia, corticomedullary junction, brainstem, and thalamus.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. The patient is likely suffering from primary infection: False. In HIV-positive patients with positive IgG, toxoplasmosis usually represents reactivation, not primary infection. For primary infection, IgM should be positive.

 

Statement 2. The most common manifestation in HIV is pulmonary toxoplasmosis: False. The most common clinical manifestation in AIDS patients is toxoplasmic encephalitis, not pulmonary disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In HIV-infected patients, Toxoplasma gondii commonly reactivates to cause encephalitis, particularly when CD4 count <100/μL. Imaging shows ring-enhancing lesions, especially in the basal ganglia. 
  • Diagnosis is supported by IgG seropositivity and confirmed with PCR of CSF.

questions.text: A preterm neonate develops respiratory difficulty soon after birth. Examination reveals subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and grunting. Despite supportive care, the baby struggles to maintain normal body temperature. Laboratory findings exclude significant electrolyte abnormalities. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in such preterm neonates?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates results from surfactant deficiency, leading to alveolar collapse and poor lung compliance. 
  • This impaired gas exchange and increased work of breathing contribute to the inability of the neonate to maintain adequate body temperature, making hypothermia a typical feature of RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperglycemia: Hypoglycemia can occur not hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Hypernatremia: May be seen in dehydration or fluid management issues, but it is not specifically linked to RDS.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Preterm infants are prone to hypocalcemia, but again, it is not characteristic of RDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm neonates, hypothermia is a hallmark feature of respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency and alveolar instability, while other metabolic abnormalities may occur independently but are not specific to RDS.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a painless thyroid nodule that has been slowly enlarging over the past 4 months. She denies dysphagia or hoarseness. On physical exam, a firm, non-tender nodule is palpated in the right thyroid lobe. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed, and the smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma of thyroid

 

  • A 32-year-old woman with a painless thyroid nodule that has been slowly enlarging over the past 4 months and who denies dysphagia or hoarseness most commonly has a well-differentiated thyroid malignancy. 
  • On physical exam, a firm, non-tender nodule is palpated in the right thyroid lobe. 
  • Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of papillary carcinoma typically shows papillary fronds with fibrovascular cores lined by cells demonstrating optically clear “Orphan Annie eye” nuclei, nuclear grooves, and sometimes intranuclear pseudoinclusions; psammoma bodies may be present. 
  • The smear shown below depicts these papillary features, making Papillary carcinoma of thyroid the most likely diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular adenoma: Benign, non-tender follicular neoplasm that forms micro- and macro-follicles without papillary architecture and lacks Orphan Annie eye nuclei and nuclear grooves. Diagnosis of follicular carcinoma (not adenoma) requires capsular and/or vascular invasion, which FNAC cannot establish; the FNAC smear shown instead favors papillary morphology.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Arises from parafollicular C cells, often associated with MEN2; cytology shows plasmacytoid/spindle cells with amyloid stroma (Congo-red positive) rather than papillary fronds. Symptoms can include diarrhea or flushing, not the asymptomatic painless nodule described in this 32-year-old woman who denies dysphagia or hoarseness.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of thyroid: Highly aggressive tumor in elderly patients presenting with a rapidly enlarging, painful mass causing dysphagia or hoarseness and showing pleomorphic giant/spindle cells with necrosis, not the slowly enlarging, firm, non-tender nodule or the papillary features on FNAC in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid—the most common thyroid cancer—shows papillary architecture with Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies on FNAC and typically presents as a painless, slowly enlarging thyroid nodule.

choices.text: Hysterectomy should be done in all cases
Diagnosed by a hysteroscopic guided biopsy or a dilation & curettage (D & C)
Majority will regress without any treatment
After biopsy, no other follow-up is required

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 15 mm. Given the suspicion of endometrial hyperplasia, the next step is considered. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnosed by a hysteroscopic guided biopsy or a dilation & curettage (D & C)

 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition characterized by proliferation of endometrial glands, often due to unopposed estrogen exposure. Accurate diagnosis is essential to exclude or detect atypia and to guide management.
  • Endometrial thickness of ≥12 mm in perimenopausal women is considered high.
  • The diagnosis is established by obtaining endometrial tissue, and the most reliable techniques are hysteroscopic guided biopsy or dilation & curettage (D & C). 
  • These methods allow histologic confirmation and distinction between simple hyperplasia, complex hyperplasia, and atypical hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy should be done in all cases: Hysterectomy is not performed in all cases of endometrial hyperplasia. It may be indicated for women with atypical hyperplasia who have completed childbearing or for those with recurrent disease. However, many cases without atypia are managed with medical therapy (e.g., progestins). Thus, the statement that hysterectomy should be done in all cases is incorrect.

 

Option C. Majority will regress without any treatment: Most cases of endometrial hyperplasia do not regress without treatment. Management with progestins, surveillance, or surgical therapy is required depending on histology. Leaving the condition untreated increases the risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Option D. After biopsy, no other follow-up is required: Follow-up is critical after biopsy. Patients are monitored with repeat endometrial sampling to ensure resolution or stability, especially in atypical hyperplasia. Saying that no follow-up is required is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial hyperplasia is diagnosed by endometrial sampling—most reliably by hysteroscopic guided biopsy or dilation & curettage (D & C).

choices.text: Increasing the dose of contrast media

questions.text: A nuclear medicine physician is reviewing a renal scan that shows prolonged retention of tracer in the pelvicalyceal system with minimal clearance over time. Which of the following techniques is most likely responsible for producing a dense persistent renogram?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dehydrating the patient

 

  • A dense persistent renogram refers to a renal scan where there is persistent radioactivity in the renal pelvis/calyces due to delayed drainage or poor flow. 
  • This is not due to obstruction, but may simulate it. It is functional, not structural.
  • Dehydration reduces urine flow → delays washout of the tracer → persistent accumulation in the pelvicalyceal system → causes a dense persistent renogram.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increasing the dose of contrast media: This increases tracer availability but does not cause persistent retention. It may improve visualization but won’t affect drainage pattern significantly.

 

Option C. Rapid (bolus) injection of dye: Used to create sharp time-activity curves for better phase delineation (vascular, parenchymal, excretory), but does not cause a persistent renogram.

 

Option D. Using nonionic media: Applies to contrast safety (especially in radiologic IVP/CT contrast studies), not relevant to nuclear renal scans (which use radiotracers like DTPA or MAG3).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A dense persistent renogram can occur in hydronephrosis or poor flow states, but dehydration is a common non-obstructive cause. 
  • Always assess hydration status before interpreting delayed clearance as obstruction.

choices.text: Plasma exchange for microangiopathic hemolysis before considering delivery
Immediate termination of pregnancy after maternal stabilization
Magnesium sulfate infusion + antihypertensives and await spontaneous labor
High-dose corticosteroids for HELLP syndrome and defer delivery for 48 hours

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 at 33 weeks presents with headache, visual blurring, and right upper quadrant pain. BP: 170/110 mmHg, urine dipstick: 3+ proteinuria. Labs: platelets 70,000/µL, AST 350 U/L, ALT 280 U/L, LDH 1200 U/L, peripheral smear: schistocytes. Fetal heart monitoring shows a baseline of 130bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate termination of pregnancy after maternal stabilization

 

  • The patient is a 28-year-old at 33 weeks gestation with:
    • Severe hypertension (170/110 mmHg)
    • 3+ proteinuria
    • Thrombocytopenia (platelets 70,000/µL)
    • Elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT >300 U/L)
    • Hemolysis (LDH 1200, schistocytes on smear)
  • This is HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets), a severe form of preeclampsia.
  • Definitive management = delivery, regardless of gestational age.
  • Maternal stabilization with IV antihypertensives and magnesium sulfate is performed first to reduce complications, but delivery should not be delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasma exchange for microangiopathic hemolysis before considering delivery: Incorrect. Plasma exchange is used for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or atypical HUS, not HELLP syndrome.

 

Option C. Magnesium sulfate infusion + antihypertensives and await spontaneous labor: Incorrect. Magnesium sulfate and antihypertensives are essential for stabilization, but awaiting spontaneous labor is unsafe. Delivery must be expedited.

 

Option D. High-dose corticosteroids for HELLP syndrome and defer delivery for 48 hours: Incorrect. Corticosteroids may be used for fetal lung maturity if <34 weeks, but in HELLP, delaying delivery is dangerous due to maternal risk (hepatic rupture, DIC, renal failure, stroke).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HELLP syndrome in pregnancy is an obstetric emergency. 
  • After maternal stabilization with antihypertensives and magnesium sulfate, the definitive management is immediate delivery, regardless of gestational age.

questions.text: All of the following require notification within 24 hours of diagnosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yellow fever

 

  • Immediately notifiable diseases must be reported to health authorities within 24 hours of diagnosis because of their extreme public health impact and rapid epidemic potential.
  • According to standard international reporting (e.g., WHO and national guidelines), SARS, Smallpox, and human influenza caused by a new subtype are immediately notifiable conditions.
  • Yellow fever, though notifiable, is usually classified as a disease to be reported promptly but not always within 24 hours, especially in areas where it is endemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SARS: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome is on the list of immediately notifiable diseases due to its high transmissibility and outbreak potential.

 

Option B. Human Influenza: Novel influenza strains are immediately notifiable because of their pandemic potential.

 

Option D. Smallpox: Eradicated globally but remains on the “immediately notifiable” list because a single case would represent a public health emergency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman (P2L2) presents with chronic pelvic pain and worsening dysmenorrhea. She previously underwent a tubectomy. Five years ago, she had surgery for endometriosis, which included adhesiolysis and excision of lesions, with temporary relief of symptoms. Now, she reports recurrence of pain, deep dyspareunia, and difficulty with daily activities. Imaging suggests recurrent endometriotic implants. Given her age, completed parity (P2L2), and history of failed conservative surgery, what is the most appropriate definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

 

  • This 36-year-old woman (P2L2) has completed her family (prior tubectomy) and already undergone surgery for endometriosis (adhesiolysis and excision of lesions). 
  • Her recurrence of symptoms despite both surgical and medical therapy indicates that conservative measures are no longer adequate.
  • The definitive treatment in such patients is hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO). 
  • Removal of the uterus eliminates uterine sources of pain, while removal of both ovaries eliminates the estrogen production that fuels the persistence and recurrence of endometriotic implants.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: While hysterectomy alone removes the uterus, retaining the ovaries allows continued estrogen production. This can lead to persistence or recurrence of endometriosis. Thus, hysterectomy by itself is not considered definitive.

 

Option C. Excision of endometriotic nodules: This is equivalent to adhesiolysis and nodule excision she already underwent in the past. It may provide temporary relief but does not address the hormonal drive of the disease, making recurrence likely.

 

Option D. Oral GnRH agonist therapy: Medical suppression with GnRH agonists can provide temporary relief by creating a hypoestrogenic state, but symptoms often recur once therapy is discontinued. This option is not definitive and is unsuitable for patients like this woman who already failed conservative and medical approaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with recurrent endometriosis who have completed childbearing (e.g., prior tubectomy, P2L2), the most definitive treatment is hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, since ovarian estrogen is the main driver of recurrence.

choices.text: Administer IV labetalol, corticosteroids, and proceed to immediate delivery
Administer IV labetalol and corticosteroids, plan delivery at 37 weeks
Administer IV labetalol and continue expectant management
Administer IV magnesium sulfate, IV labetalol, and expedite delivery

questions.text: A 35-week pregnant woman presents with headache, visual disturbance, and severe upper abdominal pain. Her blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. She also has a history of convulsions. On arrival, she is conscious but appears distressed. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administer IV magnesium sulfate, IV labetalol, and expedite delivery

 

  • This patient has eclampsia (pregnancy >20 weeks, hypertension, and seizures). 
  • At 36 weeks gestation, with symptoms of severe preeclampsia (headache, visual changes, epigastric pain, high BP) and convulsions, the correct management is:
  1. Stabilize the mother – Control seizures with IV magnesium sulfate (drug of choice for seizure prophylaxis and treatment).
  2. Control blood pressure – IV antihypertensives such as labetalol to reduce maternal risk of stroke and organ damage.
  3. Expedite delivery – Since the patient is already 36 weeks and symptomatic with eclampsia, delivery is the definitive treatment, regardless of cervical status.
  • Every word in the stem — 36 weeks, pain, headache, vision disturbance, BP 170/100, and history of convulsion — points toward eclampsia requiring stabilization and urgent delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV labetalol, corticosteroids, and proceed to immediate delivery: Corticosteroids are given <34 weeks to promote fetal lung maturity, not at 36 weeks. At this gestation, steroids are not needed, and the omission of MgSO₄ makes this option inappropriate.

 

Option B. Administer IV labetalol and corticosteroids, plan delivery at 37 weeks: This is correct only in preeclampsia without severe features or when pregnancy is <37 weeks and stable. In this case, symptoms and seizures indicate severe disease, so waiting until 37 weeks is unsafe.

 

Option C. Administer IV labetalol and continue expectant management: Antihypertensives alone will not prevent seizures or improve maternal outcomes in eclampsia. MgSO₄ is essential for seizure control, and delivery is mandatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In eclampsia at ≥34 weeks, the definitive management is maternal stabilization with IV magnesium sulfate and antihypertensives followed by prompt delivery.

choices.text: Begin allopurinol if uric acid level is elevated
Obtain ankle x-ray to rule out fracture

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with acute onset of severe pain and tenderness in his left ankle. There is no history of trauma. He takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. On examination, the ankle is swollen, erythematous, and exquisitely tender. There are no systemic signs such as fever or chills. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform arthrocentesis

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of acute monoarthritis, which may be due to gout, pseudogout, or septic arthritis. 
  • Since septic arthritis is a medical emergency, arthrocentesis should be performed as the first diagnostic step to identify the underlying cause.
    Synovial fluid analysis helps differentiate between:
    • Septic arthritis: Purulent fluid, WBC >50,000/mm³, positive Gram stain/culture
    • Gout: Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals
    • Pseudogout: Rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent calcium pyrophosphate crystals
  • Hydrochlorothiazide increases uric acid levels and can precipitate gout, but the diagnosis must be confirmed before starting urate-lowering therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin colchicine and broad-spectrum antibiotics: Empiric therapy should not be started before ruling out septic arthritis; inappropriate antibiotics may delay diagnosis.

 

Option C. Begin allopurinol if uric acid level is elevated: Allopurinol is not initiated during an acute flare; it is started later after inflammation subsides and diagnosis is confirmed.

 

Option D. Obtain ankle x-ray to rule out fracture: Not indicated unless trauma or fracture is suspected; joint aspiration takes precedence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with acute monoarthritis, arthrocentesis is the essential first step to differentiate crystal-induced from infectious arthritis before initiating treatment. 
  • Starting urate-lowering therapy or antibiotics without confirmation can obscure the diagnosis and worsen outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of gallstones undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the gallbladder is dissected, but there is accidental spillage of bile into the peritoneal cavity. The wound is closed primarily. On postoperative day 2, the patient remains afebrile. Which of the following best classifies the surgical wound in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Class III (Contaminated)

 

Explanation of Wound Classes:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Class III wounds carry a higher risk of postoperative infection due to intraoperative contamination. 
  • Recognizing this classification helps guide antibiotic prophylaxis, post-op monitoring, and infection control measures.

choices.text: Argatroban is preferred over lepirudin in renal failure.
Dabigatran’s anticoagulant effect can be reversed with idarucizumab.
All direct thrombin inhibitors are administered intravenously.
Bivalirudin has the shortest half-life among DTIs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) following cardiac surgery. His creatinine clearance is significantly reduced due to underlying chronic kidney disease. The hematology team decides to initiate anticoagulation with a parenteral agent. Which of the following statements regarding direct thrombin inhibitors is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) All direct thrombin inhibitors are administered intravenously

 

  • Dabigatran and Ximelagatran are oral agents. Others like hirudin, lepirudin, bivalirudin, and argatroban are parenteral.
  • Therefore, not all DTIs are IV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Argatroban is preferred over lepirudin in renal failure: True.
Argatroban is metabolized and excreted via the biliary system, making it safe in renal failure. In contrast, lepirudin is renally excreted and should be avoided in patients with impaired kidney function.

 

Option B. Dabigatran’s anticoagulant effect can be reversed with idarucizumab: True. Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody fragment that binds to dabigatran with high affinity, reversing its anticoagulant effect in emergencies like life-threatening bleeding or urgent surgery.

 

Option D. Bivalirudin has the shortest half-life among DTIs: True. Bivalirudin has a very short half-life (~25 minutes), making it useful in procedures requiring short-term anticoagulation, such as during percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct thrombin inhibitors act independently of antithrombin III to inactivate thrombin (factor IIa). 
  • Argatroban is preferred in renal failure, while dabigatran can be reversed with idarucizumab. 
  • Not all DTIs are intravenous, and bivalirudin has the shortest half-life among them.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent ear infections and persistent discharge from the right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida and a pearly white mass behind the tympanic membrane. Which theory of cholesteatoma formation is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory

 

  • Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory explains the formation of primary acquired cholesteatoma, which occurs due to the progressive retraction of the pars flaccida. 
  • Chronic negative middle ear pressure caused by Eustachian tube dysfunction results in retraction of the tympanic membrane, particularly in the pars flaccida. 
  • Over time, this retracted pocket traps keratin debris, forming a cholesteatoma.
  • In this case, the presence of a retraction pocket and a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane aligns with Wittmaack’s theory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ruedi’s basal cell hyperplasia theory: This theory suggests that cholesteatomas form due to hyperplasia of basal cells in the tympanic membrane, but it is less widely accepted and does not explain the findings in this case.

 

Option B. Habermann’s epithelial invasion theory: This theory is associated with secondary acquired cholesteatoma, which develops following a tympanic membrane perforation that allows squamous epithelium to invade the middle ear. However, this boy has no history of a tympanic membrane perforation, ruling out this theory.

 

Option D. Sade’s metaplasia theory: This theory suggests that chronic inflammation leads to metaplasia of middle ear mucosa into squamous epithelium, forming a cholesteatoma. While possible, this mechanism is not consistent with the retraction pocket seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory explains the formation of primary acquired cholesteatoma due to Eustachian tube dysfunction and progressive tympanic membrane retraction.

questions.text:
Which of the following should be used as the primary glucose-lowering treatment in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) to reduce cardiovascular risk? 

 

  1. Metformin
  2. GLP-1 receptor agonist
  3. Pioglitazone
  4. SGLT2 inhibitor
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 4

 

  • In patients with T2DM and established ASCVD, the goal of therapy extends beyond glycemic control to cardiovascular risk reduction.
  • Current guidelines recommend agents with proven cardiovascular benefit as first-line or early add-on therapy, even before metformin if ASCVD predominates.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

1. Metformin: Incorrect. Important for glycemic control but not the primary agent for CV risk reduction.

 

3. Pioglitazone: Incorrect. Not recommended due to risk of fluid retention and heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with T2DM and established ASCVD, GLP-1 receptor agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors are the preferred glucose-lowering therapies with Class I recommendations for reducing cardiovascular events, while metformin remains adjunctive.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 0, presents to the emergency department with sudden onset lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and dizziness. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 8 weeks ago. On arrival, her blood pressure is 78/46 mmHg, pulse 124/min, and she is noted to have altered sensorium. Pelvic examination demonstrates cervical motion tenderness (CMT+) and mild adnexal fullness. A transvaginal ultrasound (USG) reveals no intrauterine gestational sac but shows free fluid in the pouch of Douglas (POD). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

  • The combination of amenorrhea (~8 weeks after LMP), vaginal bleeding, CMT+, and USG showing free fluid in the POD indicates intra-peritoneal bleeding. 
  • The patient’s hypotension and altered sensorium imply hemorrhagic shock. These features together most strongly support a ruptured ectopic pregnancy (most commonly tubal), where blood collects in the pouch of Douglas and peritoneal irritation produces cervical motion tenderness.
  • Every clue—22-year-old, LMP 8 weeks, bleeding PV, hypotension, altered sensorium, CMT+, and USG free fluid in POD—points to acute rupture with hemoperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Missed abortion: Refers to fetal demise in utero with closed cervical os and usually minimal bleeding; patients are typically hemodynamically stable and USG shows retained products of conception, not free intraperitoneal fluid in the POD. Does not explain hypotension/altered sensorium or CMT+.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Classically presents as painless bleeding in the second or third trimester, not at 8 weeks since LMP. USG would locate placenta over the os; it does not cause free fluid in the POD or CMT+ early in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Threatened abortion: First-trimester vaginal bleeding with closed os and a viable intrauterine pregnancy on USG; patients are usually stable without hemoperitoneum, and CMT is not a typical feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a reproductive-age patient with amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, hemodynamic instability, CMT+, and USG free fluid in the pouch of Douglas, the most likely diagnosis is ruptured ectopic pregnancy. 
  • This pattern reflects hemoperitoneum from tubal rupture requiring urgent resuscitation and surgical management.

questions.text: When medical student were performing the amphibian experiments, they recorded a graph of a muscle contraction, in which latent period: 10ms, contraction period 40ms and relaxation period was 20ms. Calculate tetanizing frequency.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 25 Hz 

 

To calculate tetanizing frequency:

 

 

Given: 

 

  • Latent period: 10 ms   
  • Contraction period: 40 ms
  • Relaxation period: 20 ms

 

Convert contraction period to seconds

Thus, thetetanizing frequency is 25 Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tetanizing frequency is the minimum frequency of stimulation required to produce a smooth, sustained contraction (tetanus), preventing the muscle from relaxing between stimuli.
  • It is typically calculated as the reciprocal of the contraction period.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of lumbar back pain and night sweats. He has a history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair and bladder cancer treated with intravesical BCG immunotherapy. CT abdomen shows a 2-cm para-aortic mass contiguous to the AAA graft, suggestive of infection. Biopsy reveals granulomatous inflammation. Investigations:

 

  • Tuberculin skin test (TST): 11 mm (positive)
  • Interferon-gamma release assay (QuantiFERON-TB Gold): Negative

 

Which of the following agents should be avoided in his treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyrazinamide

 

  • This patient has disseminated Mycobacterium bovis infection due to intravesical BCG therapy.
  • M. bovis, including the BCG strain, is intrinsically resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA) because of a lack of the pncA gene, which encodes pyrazinamidase necessary for converting PZA to its active form.
  • Treatment regimen:
    • Isoniazid
    • Rifampin
    • Ethambutol
  • The negative QuantiFERON-TB Gold is consistent with M. bovis infection, as IGRA detects T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens (ESAT-6, CFP-10) absent in BCG and most M. bovis strains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethambutol: Active against M. bovis; used until drug susceptibility confirmed.

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Active component of standard regimen.

 

Option D. Rifampin: Essential first-line drug effective against M. bovis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • M. bovis and BCG strains are inherently resistant to pyrazinamide.
  • In disseminated or systemic BCG infection following intravesical therapy, standard anti-TB therapy should exclude pyrazinamide and include isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol.

questions.text: Match the anesthetic agent to its approximate MAC value for a healthy 40-year-old adult:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

  • 1 – D. Isoflurane's MAC is approximately 1.4% 
  • 2 – B. Sevoflurane's MAC is approximately 2%
  • 3 – C. Desflurane's MAC is approximately 6% 
  • 4 – A. Halothane's MAC is approximately 0.75%

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Each inhalational anesthetic has a characteristic MAC value reflecting its potency. 
  • Lower MAC values indicate higher potency. 
  • It's crucial to know these values to adjust the depth of anesthesia appropriately during surgical procedures.

questions.text:
In a clinical trial, 200 women used a new contraceptive method (Method X) for 12 months, during which 8 accidental pregnancies occurred. Which of the following statements are true regarding Method X?

 

  1. Pearl Index = 4.0
  2. Method X is less effective than IUDs
  3. Method X is more effective than female condoms
  4. Method X is equally effective as male condoms
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. Pearl Index = 4.0: True.

  • Formula:

  • Total woman-months = 200 × 12 = 2400.
  • Calculation = (8 ÷ 2400) × 1200 = 4.0.

 

Statement 3. Method X is more effective than female condoms: True.

  • Pearl Index of female condoms = 5–21.
  • Method X = 4.0, which is lower → more effective.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 2. Method X is less effective than IUDs: False.

  • Typical Pearl Index for IUDs = 1–5.
  • Method X = 4.0, which lies within the same range.
  • Therefore, Method X is not strictly less effective; it is comparable to IUDs.

 

Statement 4. Method X is equally effective as male condoms: False. 

  • Male condom Pearl Index = 2–14.
  • Method X = 4.0 lies within this range, but not equal → actual effectiveness depends on user compliance.
  • Therefore, “equally effective” is inaccurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is a standardized measure of contraceptive effectiveness, expressed as the number of accidental pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • A lower Pearl Index = greater efficacy.

choices.text: Red bag → Autoclaving then shredding of vials
White puncture-proof container → Dry heat sterilization

questions.text: A 55-year-old oncology nurse is performing an end-of-shift inventory in the chemotherapy preparation room. She discovers multiple expired vials of cisplatin and doxorubicin that were not returned to the pharmacy. Hospital protocol requires that cytotoxic drugs be discarded in compliance with biomedical waste management regulations to avoid environmental contamination. Which of the following is the most appropriate disposal method for these expired chemotherapy agents?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow bag → Incineration or encapsulation

 

  • Yellow bag: Used for human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, microbiological waste, and expired or discarded medicines, including cytotoxic (chemotherapy) drugs.
  • Expired chemotherapy drugs are hazardous and carcinogenic → must be disposed safely by incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or encapsulation in cement concrete to prevent environmental contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red bag → Autoclaving then shredding of vials: Wrong. For recyclable plastics (tubes, catheters, IV sets, gloves, syringes without needles). Treated by autoclaving/microwaving/hydroclaving + shredding → recycling. Not for drugs.

 

Option C. Blue box → Autoclaving then recycling: Wrong. For glassware (ampoules, vials without residual cytotoxic drugs) → disinfected/autoclaved → recycling. Expired chemo drugs cannot be recycled.

 

Option D. White puncture-proof container → Dry heat sterilization: Wrong. For sharps (needles, blades, scalpels, metal) → sterilized + shredding/encapsulation. Not for drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with concerns of increasing head size. The mother reports that the baby's head circumference has been crossing percentiles on the growth chart. Physical examination reveals a head circumference of 47 cm (>97th percentile), prominent forehead, and widely spaced sutures. The anterior fontanelle is full but not bulging. The baby has achieved age-appropriate milestones. Which of the following is not a cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

  • Rett syndrome is characterized by acquired microcephaly (decreasing head size) rather than macrocephaly (increasing head size) as presented in this case. 
  • Rett syndrome typically presents with normal development until 6-18 months of age, followed by developmental regression, loss of purposeful hand movements, development of stereotypical hand-wringing movements, and slowing of head growth. 
  • The head circumference in Rett syndrome initially follows a normal growth trajectory but then deviates downward, becoming progressively smaller relative to age-appropriate norms.
  • The clinical scenario described presents a classic case of macrocephaly as evidenced by:
    • Head circumference above the 97th percentile (47 cm at 6 months)
    • Crossing of percentiles upward on the growth chart
    • Widely spaced sutures and prominent forehead
    • Full anterior fontanelle (though not bulging)
    • Normal developmental milestones (suggesting a benign or compensated process)

 

Mnemonic for Rett Syndrome – “RETT HANDS”

 

R → Regression of motor and cognitive milestones (after normal early development)

E → Epilepsy (seizures are common)

T → Toddler-age onset (symptoms appear between 6-18 months)

T → Thin cortex (brain atrophy, deceleration of head growth → microcephaly)

H → Hand-wringing movements (stereotypical, repetitive)

A → Autistic-like behavior (social withdrawal)

N → Non-verbal loss (speech regression)

D → Dyspnea & Breathing abnormalities (hyperventilation, breath-holding spells)

S → Spasticity & Scoliosis (progressive motor dysfunction)

 

Bonus tip:

 

  • Only in girls (X-linked dominant, MECP2 gene mutation)
  • Developmental arrest + regression → Key diagnostic clue
  • Hand-wringing is a pathognomonic feature

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus: Is a common cause of macrocephaly resulting from accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the ventricular system. This can be due to overproduction of CSF, obstruction of CSF flow, or impaired absorption. Clinical features include increasing head circumference, full/bulging fontanelle, widely spaced sutures, and potentially developmental delays if untreated. This is consistent with the presented case.

 

Option C. Alexander disease: Is a leukodystrophy (white matter disease) characterized by progressive degeneration of white matter in the brain. It typically presents with macrocephaly, developmental delay, and seizures. The infantile form is the most common and presents with enlargement of the head, which matches the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Megalencephaly: Refers to an abnormally large brain due to increased growth of cerebral structures, not due to hydrocephalus. It can be idiopathic or associated with neurocutaneous disorders or metabolic conditions. This condition presents with macrocephaly and is often associated with normal development in the early stages, consistent with the case presented.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • When evaluating a child with abnormal head size, it's crucial to differentiate between macrocephaly (abnormally large head) and microcephaly (abnormally small head). 
  • While conditions like hydrocephalus, megalencephaly, and Alexander disease cause macrocephaly, Rett syndrome distinctively causes acquired microcephaly after a period of normal development.
  • Common Causes of Macrocephaly (ARO Saves My Health):
    • A: Anemia (chronic)
    • R: Rickets
    • O: Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • S: Subdural hematoma
    • M: Megalencephaly
    • H: Hydranencephaly/Hydrocephalus

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with multiple verrucous lesions on her external genitalia. She complains of mild itching and discomfort but denies pain or bleeding. On examination, they are as shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryotherapy

 

  • Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are caused by HPV 6 & 11.
  • In pregnancy, cryotherapy and trichloroacetic acid (TCA) are considered the safest and most effective treatments.
  • Cryotherapy destroys the wart tissue with freezing, is safe for the fetus, and gives good results without systemic drug exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Podophyllin:

 

  • Contraindicated in pregnancy because it is teratogenic and can be absorbed systemically, causing fetal toxicity.
  • Not used in pregnant women despite being effective in non-pregnant adults.

 

Option B. Imiquimod:

 

  • An immune response modifier used topically for genital warts.
  • Safety in pregnancy is not established; hence, it is avoided during gestation.

 

Option D. Surgical Excision:

 

  • Considered only for very large or obstructive lesions.
  • Not first-line in uncomplicated pregnancy cases because cryotherapy is safer and less invasive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnant women with genital warts (HPV 6/11), cryotherapy is the preferred treatment because it is both safe and effective. 
  • Podophyllin and imiquimod should be avoided due to fetal risks, while surgical excision is reserved for very large lesions.

choices.text: Holding the cervical lip during vaginal surgeries
Holding the edges of the uterine scar in a cesarean section

questions.text: The instrument displayed in the image is most commonly utilized in gynecologic and obstetric practice. What is its primary use?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inserting a post-placental intrauterine device

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is Kelly's forceps, which is commonly used in gynecological procedures, specifically for the insertion of a post-placental intrauterine device (PPIUCD). 
  • Kelly’s forceps have a distinctive fenestration at the tip and do not have a locking mechanism, which differentiates them from other forceps like sponge-holding or ovum forceps.
  • The key features of Kelly’s forceps:
    • No locking mechanism to avoid trauma to delicate tissues, such as the endometrium, during intrauterine procedures.
    • A fenestrated tip to allow secure gripping of the intrauterine device without causing damage.
    • These characteristics make Kelly's forceps ideal for inserting a PPIUCD immediately after the delivery of the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Painting parts prior to surgery: This would typically require a sponge-holding forceps, which has a locking mechanism and is used to hold gauze or sponges for painting parts prior to surgery. Kelly's forceps are not used for this purpose.

 

Option B. Holding the cervical lip during vaginal surgeries: A Valsalva forceps or tenaculum is used for grasping and holding the cervical lip, not Kelly’s forceps. These instruments are designed with teeth to grip the tissue firmly.

 

Option D. Holding the edges of the uterine scar in a cesarean section: For holding the uterine scar edges during a cesarean section, Allis forceps or Green-Armytage forceps are typically used, as they provide a wider surface area for grasping tissue and controlling bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kelly's forceps are primarily used for inserting a post-placental intrauterine device (PPIUCD) due to their design, which allows for secure handling of the device without causing trauma to intrauterine tissues. 
  • The absence of a locking mechanism and the fenestrated tip make them suitable for this procedure.

questions.text:
During an assisted delivery scenario, the team considers the use of a vacuum (ventouse). Which of the following are valid indications or prerequisites for proceeding with this intervention? 

 

  1. Prolonged second stage of labour
  2. Fetal heart tracing showing non-reassuring patterns
  3. Cephalic (vertex) presentation
  4. Gestational age below 34 weeks of pregnancy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

Vacuum (ventouse) delivery is an operative vaginal technique that can be performed when certain indications and prerequisites are met.

 

Statement 1. Prolonged second stage of labour: One of the primary reasons to perform vacuum delivery is failure of adequate progress during the second stage.

 

Statement 2. Fetal heart tracing showing non-reassuring patterns: This is an accepted indication, as vacuum can expedite birth when immediate delivery is required.

 

Statement 3. Vertex (cephalic) presentation: A fundamental prerequisite for vacuum delivery; malpresentation (such as breech) is a contraindication.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Gestational age below 34 weeks of pregnancy: This option wrongly includes gestational age less than 34 weeks (4), which is not an indication but a contraindication due to increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vacuum (ventouse) delivery is indicated for prolonged second stage of labour or non-reassuring fetal heart rate, and requires vertex presentation, but it is contraindicated when gestational age is less than 34 weeks.

choices.text: Measles or varicella infection during the time of testing
Severe malnutrition or ongoing immunosuppressive therapy
Prior exposure to environmental non-tuberculous mycobacteria
Advanced HIV/AIDS with CD4 count < 200 cells/μL

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is least likely to result in a false-negative result on a Mantoux tuberculin skin test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prior exposure to environmental non-tuberculous mycobacteria

 

  • Exposure to non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) can stimulate a cross-reactive immune response to PPD and thus cause a false-positive, not a false-negative, Mantoux test.
  • These environmental organisms share antigenic components with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, leading to induration even in the absence of TB infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles or varicella infection during the time of testing: Measles or varicella infections can cause transient immunosuppression, leading to anergy and inability to mount a DTH (delayed-type hypersensitivity) response, resulting in a false-negative Mantoux test.

 

Option B. Severe malnutrition or ongoing immunosuppressive therapy: Malnutrition and immunosuppressants (e.g., corticosteroids) blunt the T-cell response, contributing to an anergic state. The skin may not react despite latent or active TB infection, leading to false-negativity.

 

Option D. Advanced HIV/AIDS with CD4 count < 200 cells/μL: In advanced HIV/AIDS, especially with CD4 counts < 200 cells/μL, the impaired cell-mediated immunity often results in false-negative tuberculin skin tests, even in patients with TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantoux test is highly dependent on intact cell-mediated immunity. 
  • False reaction:

questions.text: While rescuing a child from a burning home, a firefighter was burned over 60% of his body. He is rushed to the emergency room and quickly taken into surgery. During the surgery, the anesthesiologist notices tall, peaked T waves and prolongation of the PR interval, accompanied by progressive widening of the QRS complex so that it appears to merge with the T waves. The patient goes into ventricular fibrillation, then asystole, and cannot be resuscitated. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient's electrocardiographic changes?
questions.solution:
Ans D) Succinylcholine

 

  • The electrocardiographic changes described in the scenario, including tall, peaked T waves, prolongation of the PR interval, progressive widening of the QRS complex, and subsequent ventricular fibrillation and asystole, are indicative of hyperkalemia.
  • Among the options provided, the agent most likely responsible for the patient's electrocardiographic changes and subsequent cardiac arrest is Succinylcholine.
  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used in anaesthesia for rapid sequence induction and tracheal intubation. 
  • However, it is known to cause a transient increase in serum potassium levels, especially in patients with burns or crush injuries. 
  • This increase in potassium can lead to hyperkalemia, which can affect the electrical conduction of the heart and cause the observed ECG changes and cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atracurium: Atracuriumand other non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents do not typically cause hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Baclofen: Is a muscle relaxant used in the treatment of spasticity. It does not typically cause hyperkalemia or the described ECG changes.

 

Option C. Halothane: Is an inhalation anaesthetic. While it can cause hepatotoxicity and malignant hyperthermia, it is not directly associated with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Succinylcholine, a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, can cause dangerous hyperkalemia in patients with upregulated extrajunctional acetylcholine receptors (e.g., burns, crush injuries, denervation). 
  • Alternative non-depolarizing agents (e.g., atracurium, rocuronium) should be used in such cases.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with several months of chronic cough, unintentional weight loss, and recurrent episodes of hemoptysis. Chest imaging shows a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. Biopsy of the lesion reveals collections of activated macrophages surrounded by lymphocytes, with multinucleated giant cells of the Langhans type. Which of the following best describes the immunologic mechanism responsible for this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type IV hypersensitivity reaction

 

  • This 47-year-old woman presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and hemoptysis. 
  • Imaging demonstrates a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe, and biopsy reveals granulomatous inflammation with epithelioid macrophages, lymphocytes, and multinucleated Langhans giant cells. 
  • This constellation is highly characteristic of pulmonary tuberculosis.
  • The immunopathology involves a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction (delayed-type hypersensitivity). 
  • CD4⁺ Th1 lymphocytes recognize antigens presented by infected macrophages and secrete interferon-γ, which activates macrophages.
  • Activated macrophages differentiate into epithelioid cells and fuse into Langhans giant cells. 
  • The aggregation of these cells with central necrosis leads to granuloma formation and cavitation.
  • Thus, the cavitary lesion in tuberculosis reflects a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apoptosis of infected cells: While apoptosis of infected macrophages may occur, it is not the mechanism that explains Langhans giant cells, granuloma formation, or cavitary lung lesions. The defining feature here is a cell-mediated delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, not isolated apoptosis.

 

Option C. Immune complex deposition: A Type III hypersensitivity mechanism, this leads to vasculitis and tissue damage in diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus or serum sickness. It does not cause granulomatous inflammation or giant cell formation.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid deposition: This is seen in immune-mediated vascular injury (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa), where immune complexes deposit in vessel walls with fibrinoid necrosis. It is not the mechanism behind granulomatous inflammation in tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatous inflammation with Langhans giant cells in tuberculosis results from a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, mediated by CD4⁺ T cells activating macrophages via interferon-γ.

choices.text: Pregnancy in PAH is generally well tolerated and associated with low maternal mortality
Riociguat and selexipag are considered safe during pregnancy
Calcium channel blockers and prostacyclin analogues are considered safe during pregnancy
Women with PAH should strictly avoid pregnancy under all circumstances

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) presents for preconception counselling. She is on verapamil with good functional status (WHO class II). She asks which of her medications can be continued if she becomes pregnant. Which of the following statements regarding PAH and pregnancy is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcium channel blockers and prostacyclin analogues are considered safe during pregnancy

 

  • Pregnancy in PAH carries very high maternal mortality (11–25%), primarily due to right ventricular failure during late gestation or postpartum. 
  • Despite improved outcomes with modern therapy, it remains a high-risk and generally contraindicated condition.
  • Relatively safe agents:
    • Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) in vasoreactive patients
    • Prostacyclin analogues (inhaled, i.v., or subcutaneous)
    • PDE5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil) may also be used
  • Contraindicated agents:
    • Endothelin receptor antagonists (bosentan, ambrisentan)
    • Riociguat and selexipag, due to teratogenicity
  • Guideline note: Women with PAH should be counselled early about pregnancy risks, advised against conception, and supported through multidisciplinary management if pregnancy occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregnancy in PAH is generally well tolerated and associated with low maternal mortality: Mortality remains high despite therapy; pregnancy is not well tolerated.

 

Option B. Riociguat and selexipag are considered safe during pregnancy: Riociguat and selexipag are teratogenic and contraindicated.

 

Option D. Women with PAH should strictly avoid pregnancy under all circumstances: Current guidelines advise strong counselling and shared decision-making, not absolute prohibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In PAH, pregnancy carries high mortality. 
  • If pregnancy occurs, CCBs and prostacyclin analogues are the safest pharmacologic options, while riociguat and endothelin antagonists must be avoided.

questions.text: Which of these lymph node groups are removed in supra-omohyoid neck dissection for oral cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Levels 1, 2 and 3

 

These nodes are removed in Supra-omohyoid neck dissection for oral cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levels 2, 3, and 4: Lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer typically involves the removal of lymph node groups in levels 2, 3, and 4. These levels are most commonly involved in the spread of oropharyngeal cancer and are therefore targeted during surgical treatment to ensure comprehensive removal of potentially affected nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SOHND entails removal of levels 1,2,3 while lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer involves removing lymph nodes in levels 2, 3, and 4 to manage and prevent the spread of cancer.

questions.text:
Which of the following injury patterns is incorrectly matched with its corresponding blast injury classification?

 

  1. Ruptured tympanic membrane – Primary blast injury
  2. Penetrating nail injury to the abdomen – Secondary blast injury 
  3. Fractured femur from body thrown into a wall – Quaternary blast injury.
  4. Flash burn with singed eyebrow – Tertiary blast injury
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 and 4

 

Statement 3. Fractured femur from body thrown into a wall – Quaternary blast injury

 

  • Incorrectly matched.
  • This is a Tertiary injury — caused by blast wind throwing the victim, leading to blunt trauma and fractures.

 

Statement 4. Flash burn with singed eyebrow – Tertiary blast injury

 

  • Incorrectly matched.
  • Flash burns are due to thermal radiation and are categorized as Quaternary injuries (miscellaneous).

 

Correct statements:

 

 Statement 1. Ruptured tympanic membrane – Primary blast injury

 

  • Correctly matched.
  • Primary blast injuries result from the blast wave (overpressure) affecting air–fluid interfaces.
  • TM rupture is a classic example due to its sensitivity to pressure changes.

 

Statement 2. Penetrating nail injury to the abdomen – Secondary blast injury

 

  • Correctly matched.
  • Secondary injuries occur due to sharpnel and fragments projected by the explosion.
  • Nail bombs are purposely designed for such injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blast injury classification:

 

  • Primary: Pressure wave → TM rupture, lung injury
  • Secondary: Shrapnel/projectiles → penetrating trauma
  • Tertiary: Body displacement → fractures, blunt trauma
  • Quaternary: Heat, smoke, radiation, PTSD → flash burns, crush injury

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with uncontrolled hypertension is found to have hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Imaging shows a small adrenal mass. On biopsy, the tumor is found to arise from the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex, labeled “A” in the diagram below. Which of the following hormones is secreted by this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aldosterone

 

  • The region marked “A” corresponds to the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. 
  • This layer exclusively produces aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid. Aldosterone plays a key role in sodium retention, potassium excretion, and blood pressure regulation via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). 
  • Overproduction (Conn’s syndrome) leads to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis—exactly as seen in the clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: Secreted mainly by the zona fasciculata (B), not zona glomerulosa. Cortisol is the major glucocorticoid involved in metabolism, stress response, and immune regulation.

 

Option C. Testosterone: While the adrenal cortex produces weak androgens (like DHEA and androstenedione) in the zona reticularis (C), testosterone itself is mainly secreted by testes, not zona glomerulosa.

 

Option D. Epinephrine: Secreted by the adrenal medulla, not cortex. The medulla contains chromaffin cells derived from neural crest that produce catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones with distinct secretory functions:

  • Zona glomerulosa (A): Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone)
  • Zona fasciculata (B): Glucocorticoids (cortisol)
  • Zona reticularis (C): Androgens (DHEA, androstenedione)

questions.text: During retro-pancreatic dissection of the neck of the pancreas in Whipple’s procedure, which of the following structures is the least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans C) Gastroduodenal artery

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery (GDA) is a branch of the common hepatic artery and supplies blood to the stomach and the duodenum. 
  • It courses anterior to the pancreas rather than posteriorly, making it less likely to be injured during retro-pancreatic dissection. 
  • Typically, it is ligated earlier in the surgery to prevent bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal vein: The portal vein runs posterior to the neck of the pancreas and is in close proximity during retro-pancreatic dissection. Therefore, it is highly prone to injury during this step of the Whipple’s procedure.

 

Option B. Superior mesenteric artery (SMA): The SMA lies posterior to the pancreas and to the left of the superior mesenteric vein. Although protected to some extent, the SMA is in the surgical field and could be at risk of injury during retro-pancreatic dissection if care is not taken.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric vein (SMV): The SMV is located posterior to the neck of the pancreas and runs alongside the portal vein. It is vulnerable during retro-pancreatic dissection and thus more likely to be injured compared to the GDA.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Gastroduodenal artery is the least likely to be injured because it lies anterior to the pancreas and is ligated during earlier phases of the procedure. 
  • The other structures—portal vein, SMA, and SMV—are located posterior to the pancreas and are within the surgical field during this dissection, increasing their risk of injury.

choices.text: Increased trabecular meshwork resistance due to extracellular fibrillar deposits
