Decreased aqueous humor production by the ciliary body
Obstruction of the angle by peripheral iris (angle-closure mechanism)
Direct autoimmune destruction of the trabecular meshwork

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic for progressively decreasing vision in her right eye over the past few months. She denies pain, redness, or photophobia. Her past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension. On slit-lamp examination, there are grayish-white flaky deposits seen at the pupillary margin and anterior lens capsule in a bull’s-eye pattern. The pupil shows poor dilation. Intraocular pressure is 28 mmHg in the right eye and 16 mmHg in the left. Gonioscopy reveals open angles. Fundus examination reveals optic disc cupping and thinning of the superior neuroretinal rim in the right eye. Which of the following best explains the patient’s ocular findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased trabecular meshwork resistance due to extracellular fibrillar deposits

 

  • Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PEX / PXF) is an age-related systemic disorder characterized by the production and accumulation of abnormal fibrillar extracellular material in ocular tissues — particularly the lens capsule, zonules, iris, and trabecular meshwork.
  • These deposits block the trabecular meshwork, leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma (PXF glaucoma).
  • Lens findings: Gray-white “dandruff-like” material with a central clear zone on the anterior capsule (from iris rubbing).
  • Pupil: Often poorly dilating due to iris sphincter involvement.
  • IOP: Raised due to reduced aqueous outflow, not overproduction.
  • Zonular weakness → predisposition to lens subluxation and complications during cataract surgery.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Decreased aqueous humor production by the ciliary body: Causes low IOP, not elevated; seen with ciliary body inflammation or ischemia.

 

Option C. Obstruction of the angle by peripheral iris (angle-closure mechanism): Describes angle-closure glaucoma, not pseudoexfoliation which is open-angle.

 

Option D. Direct autoimmune destruction of the trabecular meshwork: Not an autoimmune process; this mechanism is not involved in PXF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related systemic fibrillopathy that causes secondary open-angle glaucoma due to accumulation of fibrillar deposits in the trabecular meshwork, leading to increased outflow resistance and elevated intraocular pressure.

questions.text:
A patient presents with confusion, ataxia, and visual disturbances after ingesting windshield wiper fluid. Labs show high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Regarding the management, which of the following statements are true? 

 

  1. Fomepizole is the antidote of choice in this scenario.
  2. Ethanol can be used as an alternative treatment.
  3. Alkaline diuresis is the mainstay of therapy.
  4. Hemodialysis is indicated if severe acidosis or renal failure develops.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1, 2, and 4 are correct

 

  • This is a case of methanol poisoning, often caused by ingestion of products like windshield wiper fluid, which contain methanol. 
  • Methanol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase into formic acid, a toxic metabolite that causes retinal toxicity, CNS depression, and metabolic acidosis.
  • Statement 1. Fomepizole is the antidote of choice in this scenario: Is true.
    Fomepizole is the first-line antidote. It inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the formation of formic acid. This halts the progression of toxicity.
  • Statement 2. Ethanol can be used as an alternative treatment: Is true.
    Ethanol competes for alcohol dehydrogenase and is a second-line alternative if fomepizole is unavailable. It has a lower binding constant and can effectively prevent toxic metabolite formation.
  • Statement 4. Hemodialysis is indicated if severe acidosis or renal failure develops: Is true. Hemodialysis removes methanol and formate and is indicated in severe poisoning, especially if there is:
    • High methanol levels
    • Significant metabolic acidosis
    • Visual symptoms
    • Renal failure

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Alkaline diuresis is the mainstay of therapy: Is false. Alkaline diuresis is useful in salicylate poisoning, not methanol poisoning. In methanol toxicity, correcting acidosis is important, but urine alkalinization is not a treatment strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methanol poisoning presents with CNS symptoms, visual disturbances, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. 
  • Fomepizole is the first-line antidote, and ethanol can be used as an alternative. 
  • Hemodialysis is indicated in severe cases. Alkaline diuresis is not part of methanol poisoning management.

choices.text: Commonly occurs in older male smokers
Presents as a cystic lesion with lymphoid stroma
Typically affects younger females with a firm, painless swelling
Has very low risk of malignant transformation

questions.text: Which of the following features best distinguishes pleomorphic adenoma from Warthin tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Typically affects younger females with a firm, painless swelling

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign salivary gland tumor, especially in younger adults aged 30–40, with a female predominance. 
  • It typically presents as a slow-growing, firm, painless swelling in the parotid region, often located in the tail of the gland. 
  • Imaging usually reveals a well-defined, encapsulated mass. 
  • These features help distinguish it from other salivary gland tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly occurs in older male smokers: This describes Warthin tumor, not pleomorphic adenoma. Warthin tumor is strongly associated with smoking and typically affects older males aged 60–70.

 

Option B. Presents as a cystic lesion with lymphoid stroma: This is a hallmark of Warthin tumor. Histologically, Warthin tumors contain oncocytic epithelium and a prominent lymphoid stroma, often forming cystic spaces.

 

Option D. Has very low risk of malignant transformation: While Warthin tumor has a very low risk of becoming malignant, pleomorphic adenoma—though benign—can rarely undergo malignant transformation into carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with a history of intravenous heroin use is brought to the emergency department unconscious. On examination, he is unresponsive, his respiratory rate is 6/min, pupils are pinpoint, and oxygen saturation is 82%. Naloxone is administered, and he regains consciousness rapidly. Which of the following statements are true regarding the condition?

 

  1. Miosis is a classical finding in opioid overdose.
  2. Respiratory depression is the most life-threatening complication.
  3. Naloxone has a shorter half-life than most opioids.
  4. Benzodiazepines are the antidote of choice for opioid toxicity.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

Statement 1. Miosis is a classical finding in opioid overdose: True. Pinpoint miosis is a classic sign of opioid overdose.

 

Statement 2. Respiratory depression is the most life-threatening complication: True. Respiratory depression is the most dangerous and life-threatening effect of opioid toxicity.

 

Statement 3. Naloxone has a shorter half-life than most opioids: True. Naloxone has a shorter half-life (30–90 minutes) than most opioids (e.g., methadone), which may necessitate repeated dosing to prevent re-sedation.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Benzodiazepines are the antidote of choice for opioid toxicity: False. Benzodiazepines are not the antidote for opioid overdose. Naloxone is the antidote for opioid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Naloxone is the antidote, but its short duration of action requires close monitoring for re-sedation.

questions.text: During a routine well-baby checkup, the pediatrician examines the infant’s skull and notes that the anterior fontanelle is still open. The parents are curious about when this “soft spot” normally closes as part of healthy development. At what age is the anterior fontanelle expected to close in most children?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8–18 months

 

  • The anterior fontanelle is the largest fontanelle, located at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures. 
  • It typically closes between 8 and 18 months of age. This closure is part of normal cranial growth and ossification. 
  • Delayed closure beyond this period may indicate conditions such as rickets, hypothyroidism, hydrocephalus, or Down syndrome, while early closure can suggest craniosynostosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anterior fontanelle normally closes between 8 and 18 months of age.
  • Deviation from this range should prompt evaluation for underlying pathological conditions.

choices.text: A single dose of hepatitis B vaccine
An accelerated course of hepatitis B vaccination
Single dose of HBIG and an accelerated course of hepatitis B vaccine
Two doses of HBIG 1 month apart

questions.text:
A 45-year-old healthcare worker sustains a needlestick injury from a patient known to be HBsAg-positive and HBeAg-positive. The worker has been a nonresponder to two full courses of hepatitis B vaccination.
Serology of the healthcare worker:

 

  • HBsAg: Negative
  • Anti-HBs: 2 mIU/mL
  • Anti-HBc: Negative

 

What is the most appropriate post-exposure management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Two doses of HBIG 1 month apart

 

  • This healthcare worker is a confirmed nonresponder to hepatitis B vaccination (after two complete series) and has sustained a significant exposure to HBsAg-positive blood.
  • According to CDC, vaccine nonresponders after two full series should receive: Two doses of HBIG, administered one month apart.
  • HBIG provides passive immunity and is the only reliable protection in this setting. 
  • Further vaccination or booster doses offer no benefit to complete nonresponders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A single dose of hepatitis B vaccine: Ineffective in established vaccine nonresponders.

 

Option B. An accelerated course of hepatitis B vaccination: Offers no benefit after documented failure of two full series.

 

Option C. Single dose of HBIG and an accelerated course of hepatitis B vaccine: Recommended for nonresponders after one vaccine series, not two.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For healthcare workers with two failed hepatitis B vaccine series exposed to HBsAg-positive blood, the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis is two doses of HBIG given one month apart, as additional vaccination is ineffective in such nonresponders.

choices.text: HSV-1 has higher neurovirulence and causes neonatal herpes more commonly
HSV-2 has higher neurovirulence and is associated with increased CNS manifestations in neonates
HSV-1 causes more frequent genital relapses than HSV-2
HSV-2 has lower neurovirulence but higher reactivation potential

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate comparison regarding neurovirulence between HSV-1 and HSV-2?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV-2 has higher neurovirulence and is associated with increased CNS manifestations in neonates

 

  • Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) exhibits greater neurovirulence compared to HSV-1, especially in neonates, where it is a common cause of neonatal herpes.
  • HSV-2 is more likely to disseminate and cause meningitis, encephalitis, and systemic infection in the neonatal period, often with high mortality and neurologic sequelae.
  • HSV-1, while more commonly associated with encephalitis in adults, is less commonly implicated in neonatal CNS disease. 
  • The higher neurovirulence of HSV-2 in neonates is related to its greater capacity for CNS invasion and replication in immature immune systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSV-1 has higher neurovirulence and causes neonatal herpes more commonly: Incorrect. HSV-1 is less neurovirulent in neonates and causes fewer cases of neonatal herpes than HSV-2.

 

Option C. HSV-1 causes more frequent genital relapses than HSV-2: Incorrect. HSV-2 causes more frequent recurrences of genital herpes than HSV-1.

 

Option D. HSV-2 has lower neurovirulence but higher reactivation potential: Incorrect. HSV-2 does show higher reactivation potential, but it also has higher neurovirulence, not lower.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV-2 is more neurovirulent than HSV-1 in neonates and is more commonly associated with disseminated CNS infections, including neonatal encephalitis.

choices.text: Comparing the average cholesterol levels between two groups of patients taking different lipid-lowering drugs
Determining whether the proportion of schoolchildren who develop measles differs between vaccinated and unvaccinated groups
Comparing mean fasting blood sugar among four groups of diabetic patients on different insulin regimens
Estimating whether the average cost of hospitalization differs between surgical and nonsurgical cardiac patients

questions.text: A public health researcher wants to evaluate different hypotheses to decide which statistical test is most appropriate. In which of the following scenarios would the Chi-Square test be the most suitable?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Determining whether the proportion of schoolchildren who develop measles differs between vaccinated and unvaccinated groups

 

  • The Chi-Square test is most appropriate when comparing proportions or frequencies between two or more categorical groups. 
  • In option B, the researcher is comparing the proportion of measles cases in vaccinated vs. unvaccinated groups (categorical outcome: measles vs. no measles; exposure: vaccinated vs. unvaccinated). 
  • This is exactly what the Chi-Square test was designed for.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Comparing the average cholesterol levels between two groups of patients taking different lipid-lowering drugs: This involves comparing means of a continuous variable (cholesterol). The appropriate test is an unpaired Student’s t-test, not Chi-Square.

 

Option C. Comparing mean fasting blood sugar among four groups of diabetic patients on different insulin regimens: This is comparing means across more than two groups. The appropriate test is ANOVA, not Chi-Square.

 

Option D. Estimating whether the average cost of hospitalization differs between surgical and nonsurgical cardiac patients: Again, this compares means of a continuous variable (cost). The correct test is an unpaired t-test for two groups or ANOVA for more than two, not Chi-Square.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Chi-Square test is used to test for associations between categorical variables (e.g., proportions, frequencies). 
  • It is not used to compare means of continuous data, where t-tests or ANOVA are appropriate.

choices.text: Potassium permanganate → Foot baths before swimming pools
Ultraviolet radiation → Disinfecting drinking water and air
Microwaves → Sterilization of surgical scalpels and laparoscopic instruments
Pasteurization → 70°C for 30 minutes to kill pathogens except spores

questions.text: All of the following are correctly matched with their common use except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Microwaves → Sterilization of surgical scalpels and laparoscopic instruments

 

  • Microwaves are used for disinfecting contact lenses, dental instruments, dentures, milk, urinary catheters, and cultures, but not for heat-stable surgical instruments like scalpels or laparoscopic tools.
  • True sterilization of surgical instruments requires methods such as autoclaving (steam under pressure) or ethylene oxide gas, not microwaves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate → Foot baths before swimming pools: Correct. Used in aquariums, foot soaks before swimming pools, and washing fruits/vegetables.

 

Option B. Ultraviolet radiation → Disinfecting drinking water and air: Correct. Used for disinfecting air, drinking water, contact lenses, and surfaces like titanium implants.

 

Option D. Pasteurization →70°C for 30 minutes to kill pathogens except spores: Correct. Heating at 70°C for 30 minutes kills most pathogens but does not destroy spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disinfection vs sterilization: Disinfection removes most pathogens; sterilization kills all including spores.
  • Microwaves are disinfectants, not sterilizers.
  • Surgical instruments require sterilization (autoclaving), not microwave disinfection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a bulge in the left groin that has progressively enlarged over the past year. On examination, the bulge becomes more prominent when the patient coughs and decreases in size when lying down. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). On further inspection, a part of the bowel appears to be forming a wall of the hernia sac as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sliding hernia

 

  • Inguinal hernias are sometimes referred to as ‘sliding’ in type. These are acquired indirect hernias arising at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. 
  • Retroperitoneal fatty tissue is pushed downwards along the inguinal canal. As more tissue enters the hernia, peritoneum is pulled with it, thus creating a sac. However, the sac has formed secondarily, distinguishing it from a classic indirect hernia. 
  • On the left side, the sigmoid colon may descend into a sliding hernia (the caecum may do so on the right). 
  • Surgeons need extra caution during repair because the bowel may form part of the sac itself and can be damaged during the dissection. 
  • This is the correct term for a hernia in which part of the hernia sac wall is formed by an organ that "slides" into it. In this case, the image and the history suggest that part of the bowel (possibly the sigmoid colon) has become part of the hernia sac, which is characteristic of a sliding hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Richter’s hernia: Where a knuckle of bowel wall/circumference of bowel forms the content.

 

 

Option B. Maydl’s hernia: Where two loops of bowel form the content.

 


Option C. Pantaloon Hernia: This term describes a situation where both an indirect and a direct inguinal hernia are present simultaneously, creating a "pantaloon" shape as the hernia sacs straddle the inferior epigastric vessels. This is not what is being shown in the provided image.


Educational Objective: 

 

  • A sliding hernia is one in which an organ, such as the sigmoid colon or bladder, forms part of the hernia sac wall and can "slide" into the sac. 
  • This condition is particularly risky during surgical repair due to the potential for organ injury.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with complaints of ocular discomfort, redness, and photophobia in the right eye. On slit-lamp examination, dendritic lesions are noted on the corneal surface, raising suspicion for herpetic keratitis. The ophthalmologist instills a diagnostic dye to highlight the lesion, but the patient immediately experiences significant stinging and burning after instillation. Which of the following dyes was most likely used?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rose Bengal

 

  • Rose Bengal is a diagnostic dye used in ophthalmology to stain devitalized cells and highlight the margins/edges of corneal ulcers.
  • It is especially useful in detecting herpetic epithelial dendrites, superficial punctate keratitis, and meibomian gland dysfunction. 
  • However, a well-known side effect is that it causes significant stinging or discomfort upon instillation, due to its toxicity to healthy ocular surface tissues and its slightly acidic nature.
  • In contrast to Fluorescein, which highlights the base of epithelial defects, Rose Bengal stains non-viable epithelium at the edges and margins of corneal ulcers.
  • It is also virucidal, so culture samples should be taken before staining.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lissamine Green: Like Rose Bengal, it stains devitalized or membrane-damaged cells, but does not cause stinging and does not stain healthy ocular surface epithelium, making it more comfortable and better tolerated in patients.

 

 

Option B. Alcian Blue: This dye binds mucin and filaments and is not typically used to evaluate herpetic dendrites or devitalized epithelium. It also doesn’t cause stinging or discomfort upon use. This is used for corneal dystrophies specifically Lattice dystrophy.

 

Option C. Fluorescein: Fluorescein stains denuded epithelium, especially the base of corneal ulcers, and is visualized as green under cobalt blue light. It is generally painless and non-irritating.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rose Bengal is used to stain devitalized tissue and ulcer margins. It is useful in evaluating herpetic keratitis and other epithelial defects, but it is associated with significant stinging upon instillation, a feature not typically seen with other ocular dyes like Lissamine Green or Fluorescein.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with a history of hypertension and asthma is referred for evaluation of chronic kidney disease. His serum creatinine is 1.8 mg/dL, and a 24-hour urine collection shows 370 mg/day of protein with a bland urinary sediment. He is somewhat anemic and mildly acidotic. He previously worked in a paper factory and frequently did painting. Review of old records shows his serum creatinine was 1.9 mg/dL fifteen years ago, Comprehensive testing reveals a serum lead level of 13 μg/dL, confirming lead nephropathy. What other co-existing illness is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gout

 

  • Lead toxicity is highly associated with gout.
  • Approximately 50% of patients with chronic lead toxicity develop gout due to reduced urate excretion and interference with proximal tubular transport mechanisms.
  • The patient was treated with lead chelation on five different occasions over the next five years, after which blood lead levels decreased to less than 5 μg/dL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis C: No known association with lead nephropathy.

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis: Degenerative joint disease, unrelated to lead exposure.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Not linked with lead toxicity or nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic lead nephropathy causes chronic interstitial nephritis with slowly progressive renal dysfunction, minimal proteinuria, and bland urinary sediment.
  • Coexistent gout is a hallmark feature, seen in up to half of cases.
  • Occupational exposure (battery work, painting, smelting, or paper industries) and long-standing exposure history are typical clues.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling in the upper part of his right leg. Imaging shows a periosteal reaction in the diaphysis of the proximal tibia. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and the histopathological image is given below. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for synaptophysin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

  • This 15-year-old male with pain and swelling in the upper right leg has imaging that shows a periosteal reaction involving the diaphysis of the proximal tibia. 
  • The biopsy reveals small, round blue cells with immunohistochemical positivity for synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99).
  • These findings are characteristic of Ewing sarcoma, a highly malignant small round blue cell tumor of bone in children and adolescents. 
  • Ewing sarcoma commonly arises in the diaphysis of long bones such as the femur or tibia, and classically produces a periosteal onion-skin reaction on imaging. 
  • The tumor cells often express MIC-2 (CD99), which is a highly relevant diagnostic marker.

 

  • Thus, the most likely diagnosis in this case is Ewing sarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoclastoma: Typically arises in the epiphysis, not the diaphysis. Histology shows multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts, not small round blue cells. It does not stain with synaptophysin or MIC-2 (CD99).

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma: Malignant tumor of cartilage usually seen in adults, not a 15-year-old boy. Imaging would reveal a cartilage-based tumor, not a diaphyseal lesion with periosteal reaction. Immunohistochemistry with synaptophysin and MIC-2 is not a feature.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Malignant bone tumor often found in the metaphysis, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia). Histology reveals malignant osteoid production, not small round blue cells. Synaptophysin and MIC-2 positivity do not apply here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is a malignant small round blue cell tumor of bone in children and adolescents, typically arising in the diaphysis of long bones. 
  • It is associated with MIC-2 (CD99) positivity and may show an onion-skin periosteal reaction on imaging.

questions.text: A national leprosy control task force is validating data used to evaluate disease control strategies. As part of their audit, they must match various performance indicators with their correct classification used in public health surveillance systems. Which of the following sets of matches is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

1. No. of new cases detected → A. Operational Indicator: This measures the performance and outreach of the program in identifying cases. It's used to monitor program activity levels.

 

2. % of Multi-bacillary cases on regular treatment → B. Case Detection Indicator: This reflects the nature and severity of newly identified cases. It helps understand disease trends and challenges in early diagnosis.

 

3. No. of relapses → C. Quality of Service Indicator: Relapse rates help determine the effectiveness of treatment regimens and whether patients were diagnosed and treated appropriately.

 

4. Prevalence as a measure of case load → D. Epidemiological Indicator: Prevalence reflects the total burden of disease and helps with long-term resource planning and intervention strategies.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Autoimmune destruction of ductal epithelial cells with chronic inflammation
Primary squamous carcinoma of the nipple epidermis without ductal involvement
Malignant cells infiltrating the epidermis of the nipple from underlying ductal carcinoma
Direct invasion of dermis by metastatic carcinoma cells from a distant primary site

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressive nipple changes, including erythema, crusting, and pruritus of the left breast. She reports occasional bloody discharge from the nipple. On physical exam, there is thickened skin with eczematous changes around the areola and a firm subareolar nodule is palpated. A mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection is performed. The image of the mastectomy specimen and histopathology are shown below. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malignant cells infiltrating the epidermis of the nipple from underlying ductal carcinoma

 

  • The 68-year-old woman has a 6-month history of progressive nipple changes—erythema, crusting, and pruritus—with occasional bloody discharge, thickened skin showing eczematous changes around the areola, and a firm subareolar nodule on exam. 
  • After mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection, the mastectomy specimen and histopathology (image) demonstrate large pale malignant cells within the epidermis (Paget cells). 
  • This clinicopathologic picture is classic for mammary Paget disease, whose underlying pathogenesis is epidermotropic spread of malignant ductal epithelial cells from an underlying ductal carcinoma (often DCIS) that tracks up the lactiferous ducts into the nipple–areolar epidermis.
  • This mechanism explains the patient’s nipple changes, subareolar nodule, and the findings in the images.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune destruction of ductal epithelial cells with chronic inflammation: Incorrect. Mammary Paget disease is neoplastic, not autoimmune; there is no chronic immune-mediated destruction causing the erythema, crusting, pruritus, bloody discharge, or the subareolar nodule seen in this 68-year-old woman.

 

Option B. Primary squamous carcinoma of the nipple epidermis without ductal involvement: Incorrect. Paget disease requires ductal involvement; it is not a primary squamous carcinoma confined to the epidermis without ductal involvement.

 

Option D. Direct invasion of dermis by metastatic carcinoma cells from a distant primary site: Incorrect. The process is not direct invasion of dermis from a distant metastasis; the key pathogenesis is malignant ductal cells extending to the epidermis of the nipple from a subareolar ductal carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mammary Paget disease results from malignant ductal epithelial cells (often from subareolar DCIS) spreading through lactiferous ducts to infiltrate the nipple–areolar epidermis, producing eczematous, pruritic, crusted nipple changes and sometimes bloody discharge.

questions.text: The process shown in figure is an important method of transfer of drug resistance in bacteria. This mechanism of horizontal transfer of drug resistance is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conjugation

 

  • Horizontal transfer of drug resistance in bacteria refers to the transfer of resistance genes between different bacterial species. 
  • This transfer can occur through Conjugation.
  • This is the transfer of genetic material between bacteria by direct cell-to-cell contact. 
  • During conjugation, a plasmid (a small, circular piece of DNA) that contains a resistance gene can be transferred from one bacterium to another, allowing the recipient bacterium to become resistant to the drug. 
  • It is most common method of horizontal transfer of drug resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transduction: This is the transfer of genetic material between bacteria by a bacteriophage (a virus that infects bacteria). If the genetic material contains a resistance gene, the bacterium can incorporate it into its genome and become resistant to the drug.

 

Option C. Transformation: This is the uptake of free DNA from the environment by a bacterial cell. If the DNA contains a resistance gene, the bacterium can incorporate it into its genome and become resistant to the drug. It is least common method of horizontal transfer of resistance

 

Option D. Transposition: This is the movement of a DNA sequence (such as a resistance gene) from one location in the genome to another. Transposition occurs due to jumping genes called transposons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bacteria spread antibiotic resistance through horizontal gene transfer.
  • Conjugation (via pilus) is the most common method.
  • Transduction uses a bacteriophage, transformation involves uptake of free DNA, and transposition occurs via jumping genes.
  • Conjugation is the key mechanism driving rapid resistance spread among bacteria.

choices.text: Step 1 → Internal validity; Step 2 → External validity
Step 1 → Face validity; Step 2 → Criterion validity
Step 1 → Conclusive validity; Step 2 → Internal validity
Step 1 → External validity; Step 2 → Criterion validity

questions.text:
A research team develops a new screening questionnaire for early detection of Alzheimer’s disease.

 

  • Step 1: Senior neurologists review the questionnaire and agree that the items “appear to appropriately assess early memory loss and cognitive decline.”
  • Step 2: The questionnaire is then tested against standardized neuropsychological testing (considered the gold standard), and its sensitivity and specificity are calculated.

 

Which types of validity are demonstrated in Step 1 and Step 2, respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Step 1 → Face validity; Step 2 → Criterion validity

 

  • Step 1. Senior neurologists review the questionnaire and agree that the items “appear to appropriately assess early memory loss and cognitive decline”: When experts review the questionnaire and judge that it “appears” to measure what it intends to → this is Face (or logical) validity. It is subjective and superficial but often the first step in tool development.
  • Step 2. The questionnaire is then tested against standardized neuropsychological testing (considered the gold standard), and its sensitivity and specificity are calculated: When the new tool is tested against a gold standard and its diagnostic accuracy expressed as sensitivity/specificity → this is Criterion validity. It demonstrates how well the new test matches established standards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.
  • Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity:

questions.text: A mutation in a protein leads to replacement of alanine by another amino acid, resulting in an increased tendency of the protein to undergo phosphorylation. Which amino acid substitution is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serine

 

  • Phosphorylation in proteins typically occurs on amino acids that have hydroxyl (-OH) groups in their side chains. 
  • The most common sites of phosphorylation are serine, threonine, and tyrosine.
  • In this question, the mutation replaces alanine (which lacks an -OH group and cannot be phosphorylated) with serine (which has a hydroxyl group). 
  • This structural change introduces a site where kinases can add a phosphate group, thereby increasing the tendency of the protein to be phosphorylated.
  • Thus, replacement of alanine with serine explains the increased phosphorylation potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valine: Valine is a nonpolar, branched-chain amino acid. It does not contain a hydroxyl group and therefore cannot be phosphorylated. Substitution with valine would not increase phosphorylation.

 

Option B. Leucine: Leucine, like valine, is a nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acid. It lacks a hydroxyl group, so no phosphorylation would occur. This substitution would not account for the finding.

 

Option D. Proline: Proline is a nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acid. It lacks a hydroxyl group, so no phosphorylation would occur. This substitution would not account for the finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serine is the most common amino acid involved in phosphorylation because of its hydroxyl side chain. 
  • Replacement of a non-hydroxyl amino acid such as alanine with serine introduces new phosphorylation sites in proteins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain is colicky in nature and associated with mild nausea. On examination, there is tenderness over the left costovertebral angle (CVA). His urine dipstick shows microscopic hematuria. After controlling his colic, the following imaging is done. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plain CT KUB

 

  • In a patient presenting with acute flank pain suggestive of ureteric colic, the gold standard for evaluation is non-contrast CT KUB (Kidneys, Ureters, Bladder), which is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting urinary calculi.
  • Plain X-ray KUB, while useful for detecting radio-opaque stones, does not visualize uric acid stones or small stones and cannot assess obstruction.
  • CT KUB is preferred because it identifies even radiolucent stones and determines the exact location, size, and degree of obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL):

 

  • ESWL is a treatment modality, not a diagnostic step. It is used only after confirming the stone's location and size, typically for stones <2 cm in the kidney or proximal ureter.
  • Without confirming stone characteristics on CT, proceeding directly to ESWL is inappropriate.

 

Option B. Uretero-renoscopic removal (URS):

 

  • URS is indicated if the stone is < 10 mm, causing obstruction, or if ESWL fails.
  • Since the diagnosis is not yet confirmed, immediate intervention is not appropriate.

 

Option C. Wait and Watch:

 

  • Observation is considered for small (<5 mm) non-obstructing stones that are likely to pass spontaneously.
  • Before deciding on conservative management, imaging confirmation with CT KUB is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with suspected renal colic, non-contrast CT KUB is the gold standard for diagnosing urinary stones.
  • It identifies stone size, location, and degree of obstruction, guiding further management.
  • X-ray KUB alone is inadequate, as it may miss radiolucent stones.
  • ESWL, URS, or conservative management should only be considered after confirming stone characteristics on imaging.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a history of uterine prolapse undergoes a Manchester (Fothergill’s) operation for surgical correction. During counselling, she is informed about potential pregnancy-related complications associated with this procedure. Which of the following outcomes is she least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) First trimester abortion

 

  • The Manchester (Fothergill’s) operation involves cervical amputation with uterine ligament plication, which shortens and supports the cervix.
  • Common obstetric complications after this surgery include:
    • Cervical dystocia (rigidity of the cervix in labor due to scarring).
    • Premature labor (shortened cervix and reduced competence).
    • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) (weakened cervical integrity).
  • However, first trimester abortion is not a recognized complication of this operation, making it the least likely outcome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Premature rupture of membranes: Can occur due to cervical incompetence after surgical alteration.

 

Option B. Cervical dystocia: A well-documented complication resulting from cervical scarring and fibrosis after cervical amputation.

 

Option C. Premature labor: Due to reduced cervical competence after surgery, increasing the risk of preterm delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following Fothergill’s (Manchester) repair for uterine prolapse, patients may experience cervical dystocia, premature labor, or PROM, but first trimester abortion is not a typical complication.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old college student presents with pallor and intermittent jaundice. Laboratory evaluation is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Several statements regarding hemolytic anemias are listed below:

  1. Sickle cell anemia demonstrates high osmotic fragility and increased mechanical fragility.
  2. Raised HbA2 levels are typically seen in iron deficiency anemia.
  3. The Mentzer index is used to differentiate iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia trait.
  4. Donath–Landsteiner antibodies are associated with cold hemolysin disease

Which of the following combinations contains the incorrect statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statements 1 and 2

 

Statement 1. Sickle cell anemia demonstrates high osmotic fragility and increased mechanical fragility: Incorrect. Sickle cell anemia does not have high osmotic fragility — that is a feature of hereditary spherocytosis. Mechanical fragility may increase due to rigid sickled cells, but osmotic fragility is not typically elevated.

 

Statement 2. Raised HbA2 levels are typically seen in iron deficiency anemia: Incorrect. Increased HbA2 is a hallmark of β-thalassemia trait, not iron deficiency anemia.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 3. The Mentzer index is used to differentiate iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia trait: Correct. Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) >13 suggests iron deficiency anemia; <13 suggests thalassemia trait.

 

Statement 4. Donath–Landsteiner antibodies are associated with cold hemolysin disease: Correct. This is classically true — these IgG antibodies cause complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis in the cold.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In hemolytic anemia, increased HbA2 is a feature of β-thalassemia trait (not iron deficiency), and high osmotic fragility is seen in hereditary spherocytosis (not sickle cell anemia). 
  • The Mentzer index differentiates iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia trait, and Donath–Landsteiner antibodies are diagnostic for paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.

questions.text: Match the following pancreatic islet cells with their predominant secretions:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d, 5-e, 6-f

 

  1. Alpha cells → a. Glucagon, Pancreastatin, Glicentin
    • Function: Alpha cells secrete glucagon, which increases blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver.
    • They may also produce pancreastatin and glicentin, which are related to proglucagon processing.
  2. Beta cells → b. Insulin, Amylin, Pancreastatin
    • Function: These cells are the most abundant (≈70%) in the islets and secrete:
      • Insulin – decreases blood glucose by promoting uptake in tissues.
      • Amylin – modulates gastric emptying and inhibits glucagon secretion.
      • Pancreastatin – modulates insulin action.
  3. D cells → c. Somatostatin
    • Function: D cells secrete somatostatin, which inhibits the release of several other hormones like insulin, glucagon, and GH.
    • Acts as a paracrine regulator within the islet.
  4. PP cells → d. Pancreatic Polypeptide
    • Function: Secretes pancreatic polypeptide, which regulates both endocrine and exocrine pancreatic secretions and may affect hepatic glycogen levels and GI secretions.
  5. G cells → e. Gastrin
    • Function: Though mainly found in the gastric antrum, G cells can be present in the pancreas in small amounts.
    • They secrete gastrin, which stimulates gastric acid secretion.
  6. D2 cells → f. Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP)
    • Function: These neuroendocrine cells release VIP, which promotes smooth muscle relaxation, intestinal water secretion, and vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alpha → Glucagon, Pancreastatin, Glicentin
  • Beta → Insulin, Amylin, Pancreastatin
  • D → Somatostatin
  • PP → Pancreatic Polypeptide
  • G → Gastrin
  • D2 → VIP

questions.text: A premature infant undergoes MRI of the brain, which is as shown below. What is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

 

  • Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is a form of white matter injury, typically seen in premature infants. 
  • It results from hypoxia and ischemia of the vulnerable periventricular white matter supplied by end-arteries. 
  • The hallmark MRI finding is cystic degeneration and necrosis around the ventricles. 
  • PVL is strongly associated with birth asphyxia, sepsis, and prolonged hypotension. 
  • Long-term consequences include spastic cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningitis: Usually shows meningeal enhancement, ventriculitis, or diffuse parenchymal involvement, not isolated PVL.

 

Option C. Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH): Manifests as blood within the ventricles or germinal matrix, not cystic necrosis of white matter.

 

Option D. Reye’s Syndrome: Characterized by acute liver failure with cerebral edema, not periventricular leukomalacia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Periventricular leukomalacia with cystic necrosis in infants is a classic neuroimaging feature of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), resulting from impaired cerebral perfusion and oxygenation. 
  • It is a leading cause of cerebral palsy in preterm infants.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic gout presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right great toe for the past 12 hours. On examination, the joint is warm and tender, consistent with acute gouty arthritis. Which of the following drugs should not be prescribed to avoid further worsening of his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allopurinol

 

  • During an acute gout attack, urate-lowering therapy such as allopurinol, febuxostat, or probenecid should not be initiated or adjusted. 
  • Starting or altering these agents during an active flare can mobilize urate stores from tissues, transiently increasing serum uric acid fluctuations and worsening or prolonging inflammation.
  • Allopurinol is used for long-term prevention by inhibiting xanthine oxidase, thereby reducing uric acid production. 
  • It should be started only after the acute episode has completely resolved (usually after 2–3 weeks).
  • Initial treatment of an acute attack focuses on anti-inflammatory agents such as NSAIDs (e.g., naproxen), colchicine, or glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naproxen: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that rapidly reduces pain and inflammation; it is a first-line treatment for acute gout attacks.

 

Option B. Prednisolone: A corticosteroid that can be used when NSAIDs or colchicine are contraindicated (e.g., renal impairment or peptic ulcer disease). It is effective and safe in acute gout.

 

Option C. Colchicine: Decreases neutrophil migration and microtubule formation, thereby reducing inflammation; useful early in the course of an acute attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Allopurinol and other urate-lowering drugs should not be started or adjusted during an acute gout attack, as they may exacerbate or prolong the inflammation. 
  • Acute attacks are treated with NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids.

questions.text: A woman develops choking, hoarseness of voice, and a foreign body sensation in the throat while eating fish. On examination, a fish bone is found lodged in the pyriform fossa. Which nerve is primarily responsible for mediating this sensation of irritation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal branch of SLN

 

  • The pyriform fossa (piriform recess) is located in the laryngopharynx, on either side of the laryngeal inlet.
  • The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), provides sensory innervation to:
    • The mucosa of the pyriform fossa
    • Laryngeal mucosa above the vocal cords
    • Pharyngeal wall near the pyriform recess
  • When a fish bone or other foreign body lodges in the pyriform fossa, the irritation and foreign body sensation are transmitted primarily via this internal branch of the SLN.
  • Injury or irritation of this nerve can also contribute to hoarseness, choking, and cough reflex due to its sensory role in protecting the airway.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX):

 

  • Provides sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and tonsillar area.
  • Does not supply the pyriform fossa, hence not responsible here.

 

Option B. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN):

 

  • Provides motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid and sensory supply below the vocal cords.
  • It is not the nerve that mediates irritation from the pyriform fossa.

 

Option D. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve (SLN):

 

  • Provides motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle.
  • It has no sensory role in the pyriform fossa, so it is not the nerve responsible for irritation in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve) supplies sensory innervation to the pyriform fossa and mediates the foreign body sensation when a fish bone is lodged there.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought for developmental evaluation. The parents report that the child has not achieved toilet training and tends to avoid eye contact during interactions. Based on these features, which developmental disorder is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

 

  • Autism Spectrum Disorder is characterized by deficits in social interaction and communication along with restricted or repetitive behaviors.
  • Avoidance of eye contact is a hallmark social deficit. Additionally, delayed toilet training is often associated with developmental delays and behavioral rigidity commonly seen in ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): Characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, but not typically associated with poor eye contact or lack of toilet training.

 

Option C. Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD): Involves defiant, argumentative, and hostile behavior toward authority figures, but not deficits in social reciprocity or communication.

 

Option D. Speech Sound Disorder: Involves difficulty with articulation and phonological processes, but does not account for social avoidance or toilet training delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autism Spectrum Disorder should be suspected in young children with social deficits (such as avoiding eye contact) and developmental delays (such as lack of toilet training). 
  • Early recognition is crucial for initiating behavioral and developmental interventions.

choices.text: The acetabular labrum attaches directly to the transverse acetabular ligament without blending into the joint capsule
Capsule is attached to the intertrochanteric line anteriorly and extends posteriorly only to the neck of the femur, not the intertrochanteric crest
The nerve to quadratus femoris is the principal motor supply to the hip abductors
The psoas major tendon lies posterior to the capsule before inserting into the lesser trochanter

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hip joint is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Capsule is attached to the intertrochanteric line anteriorly and extends posteriorly only to the neck of the femur, not the intertrochanteric crest

 

  • The hip joint capsule is a strong fibrous structure enclosing the joint.
  • Anteriorly, it attaches to the intertrochanteric line of the femur.
  • Posteriorly, however, it does not reach the intertrochanteric crest; instead, it attaches more medially to the femoral neck.
  • This anatomical arrangement makes Option B the true and correct statement regarding the capsule of the hip joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The acetabular labrum attaches directly to the transverse acetabular ligament without blending into the joint capsule: Incorrect. The acetabular labrum forms a fibrocartilaginous rim around the acetabulum and does blend with the capsule, not remain separate.

 

Option C. The nerve to quadratus femoris is the principal motor supply to the hip abductors: Incorrect. The superior gluteal nerve (not nerve to quadratus femoris) is the main supply to hip abductors such as gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.

 

Option D. The psoas major tendon lies posterior to the capsule before inserting into the lesser trochanter: Incorrect. The iliopsoas tendon passes anterior to the capsule (separated by a bursa), not posterior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hip joint capsule is attached anteriorly to the intertrochanteric line and posteriorly to the femoral neck, not to the intertrochanteric crest.

questions.text:
All of the following are correct regarding Parvovirus B19 infection, except: 

 

  1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  2. Gianotti–Crosti syndrome
  3. Papular-purpuric rash of hands and feet (“gloves and socks” syndrome)
  4. Aplastic crisis in patients with hemolytic disorders
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 only

 

Statement 2. Gianotti–Crosti syndrome: Incorrect. Not caused by Parvovirus B19. Instead, this condition is linked to Hepatitis B, Epstein-Barr virus, and enteroviruses, typically presenting with monomorphic papular eruptions on face, buttocks, and limbs.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease): Correct. Classic childhood illness caused by Parvovirus B19, known as fifth disease, presenting with slapped cheek appearance and lacy rash on limbs.

 

Statement 3. Papular-purpuric rash of hands and feet (“gloves and socks” syndrome): Correct. A known manifestation of Parvovirus B19, especially in adolescents and adults, presenting with painful, pruritic, purpuric rashes on hands and feet.

 

Statement 4. Aplastic crisis in patients with hemolytic disorders: Correct. Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid precursor cells, leading to transient red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with sickle cell disease or other hemolytic anemias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, gloves and socks syndrome, aplastic crisis, and fetal hydrops, but is not associated with Gianotti–Crosti syndrome, which is linked to Hepatitis B and EBV.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man sustains blunt trauma to the back of the head after falling from a ladder. CT reveals a fracture involving the skull base and the atlas (C1) vertebra. He is noted to have active bleeding from the vertebral artery, and surgical exposure is planned through the suboccipital triangle. Which of the following muscles extends from the transverse process of C1 to the occipital bone and forms the lateral border of this triangle, providing an important landmark for the surgical approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obliquus capitis superior

 

  • The clinical setting of a C1 fracture with vertebral artery hemorrhage requires surgical access via the suboccipital triangle.
  • Knowing the boundaries of this triangle is key for surgeons to approach the artery safely.
  • The obliquus capitis superior muscle specifically originates from the transverse process of C1 (atlas) and inserts on the occipital bone.
  • This course makes it the muscle that forms the lateral border of the suboccipital triangle, which is precisely the corridor used in this patient’s planned surgery.
  • Thus, in the context of this trauma, the obliquus capitis superior is not just an anatomical fact — it is directly relevant to surgical exposure for vertebral artery control.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectus capitis posterior major:

 

  • Extends from the spinous process of C2 to the occipital bone.
  • It forms the medial border of the suboccipital triangle, not the lateral border.
  • Therefore, although part of the triangle, it does not match the description in the question.

 

Option B. Splenius capitis:

 

  • A superficial muscle that extends from the lower cervical and upper thoracic spinous processes to the mastoid process and occipital bone.
  • It is not part of the suboccipital triangle and does not form any of its borders.
  • Hence, it cannot be the correct answer here.

 

Option C. Rectus capitis posterior minor:

 

  • Originates from the posterior tubercle of C1 and inserts into the medial portion of the occipital bone.
  • This small muscle does not form the boundary of the suboccipital triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In vertebral artery surgery through the suboccipital triangle, the obliquus capitis superior forms the lateral border (transverse process of C1 → occipital bone), serving as a critical anatomical landmark.
